Tribune Media Company responded Tuesday to Federal Communications Commission chairman Ajit Pai's statement on Monday that he had "serious concerns" about its merger with Sinclair Broadcast Group, Inc. Tribune MediaTRCO, -0.03% said in a statement that it was "disappointed" in Pai's proposal to refer issues relating to Sinclair'sSBGI, +0.36%divestiture of TV stations prior to the deal's closing to an administrative law judge. On Monday, Pai expressed concern about deals Sinclair made to divest its TV stations, saying in a Twitter post that the deals "would allow Sinclair to control those stations in practice, even if not in name, in violation of the law." Tribune Media shares have fallen 24% so far this year, and Sinclair shares have fallen 23%. The S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has risen 4.7%.

The financial sector traded significantly off its lows on Friday, paring an earlier drop as JPMorgan Chase & Co. shrugged off an early decline to trade higher in the wake of its better-than-expected results. The sector fell 0.3%, having previously dropped as much as 1.4%. JPMorgan JPM, -0.98% gained 0.7% after its results, bucking the negative trend of other companies that reported. Citigroup Inc. C, -2.39% fell 2.3% after its revenue missed forecasts. Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, -0.67% sank 1.4% as both earnings and revenue failed to match consensus analyst expectations. Both were also off their lows of the trading day. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% rose 0.3% while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was up 0.2% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% was up 0.1%.

President Donald Trump told The Sun newspaper that a so-called "soft" Brexit would kill the chances for a trade deal between the U.K. and the U.S. after the country leaves the European Union. Tweets from The Sun's political reporter quote the president as saying such a move would make it more difficult for the U.S. "If they do a deal like that, we would be dealing with the European Union instead of dealing with the UK, so it will probably kill the deal," he said. Several ministers, notably Boris Johnson, have quit the U.K. cabinet over Prime Minister Theresa May's plan released last week. Trump also reportedly said May ignored his advice on how to negotiate Brexit. Trump is in the U.K. visiting May as part of his European tour.

President Donald Trump took aim at ally Germany in particular in his first public comments at an opening breakfast at NATO's annual summit Wednesday. "Germany, as far as I'm concerned, is captive of Russia because it is getting so much of its energy from Russia," Trump said, referencing Germany's gas deal. Trump again all-but ordered members of the alliance to increase their defense spending "immediately." Trump had signaled ahead of the trip that his mission was to secure greater spending into NATO from other members, but critics were skeptical of the tough-talk approach, with some relations already strained by recent trade moves. Trump is set to meet with both German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Emmanuel Macron on Wednesday. He meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin on July 16.

The head of Uber Technologies Inc.'s human resources department resigned Tuesday following allegations that she dismissed racial discrimination complaints at the company, Reuters reported. Chief Executive Dara Khosrowshahi announced the resignation of Chief People Officer Liane Hornsey in an email seen by Reuters. Hornsey, who was one of Uber's leading voices on workplace diversity and discrimination, was reportedly under investigation for systematically dismissing internal racial-bias complaints. Uber has faced a number of complaints and lawsuits alleging sexual and racial discrimination and harassment, including a female software engineer who sued in May. In March, Uber agreed to settle a class-action discrimination lawsuit by 420 female and minority employees for $10 million. Khosrowshahi, who took over as CEO from founder Travis Kalanick last year, has pledged to clean up Uber's corporate culture.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% said Tuesday it will create more than 600 jobs in the Ottawa, Canada suburb of Orleans as it plans to build a one-million square foot fulfillment center. That would be the fifth facility in Ontario. Currently, Amazon employs 2,000 full-time associates in Ontario and has more than 6,000 employees in Canada. The company's 2017 annual report said it had 566,000 employees as of Dec. 31. Amazon's stock was little changed in premarket trade. It has soared 21% over the past three months, to close Monday at $1,739.02, or just 0.6% below its June 20 record close of $1,750.08. In comparison, the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF XLY, -0.84% has rallied 9.8% over the past three months and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.8%.

Celgene Corp. CELG, -0.77% reported positive results from a late-stage trial of a treatment for breast cancer Tuesday, saying the trial met its co-primary endpoint of progression-free survival. The trial, which was sponsored by Roche, involved 902 patients and sought to evaluate the combination of the investigational combination TECENTRIQ plus ABRAXANE in triple negative breast cancer, a type that has a high unmet need. "This is the first phase III study to demonstrate a statistically significant PFS improvement in first-line metastatic or unresectable locally advanced triple negative breast cancer (TNBC)," Celgene said in a statement. The results will be presented at a coming medical meeting. Celgene shares rose 2% premarket on the news but have fallen 19.7% in 2018 through Monday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.1%.

Alphabet Inc.'s GOOG, -0.92%GOOGL, -0.95% Google Cloud Platform confirmed Tuesday its Chief Operating Officer Diane Bryant is no longer with the company following news reports of her departure. "We can confirm that Diane Bryant is no longer with Google," the company said in an emailed statement to MarketWatch. "We are grateful for the contributions she made while at Google and we wish her the best in her next pursuit." As of publication early Tuesday, Bryant was still listed on Google Cloud's staff page. Bryant was in the COO slot for less than a year, having come over from Intel Corp. INTC, -2.57% in November. One analyst feels that Bryant is a likely candidate for Chief Executive at Intel, following the abrupt resignation of CEO Brian Krzanich in late June.

A federal judge awarded the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation the maximum damages possible, $625.3 million, on Monday for PricewaterhouseCoopers' negligence in auditing Colonial Bank. Colonial was one of the twenty-five largest banks in the United States when it went bankrupt in 2009 with over $26 billion in assets. In a fraud that began in 2002 and was exposed by regulators in 2009, Colonial Bank employees conspired with Taylor, Bean & Whitaker Mortgage Corporation executives. The judge had previously ruled after a bench trial that PwC violated its professional duties to Colonial by negligently performing its 2003-2005 and 2008 audits. The judge said PwC did not design its audits so as to enable it to detect fraud and PwC did not obtain sufficient competent evidence to support any of those opinions.

St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said Wednesday that the Fed's benchmark interest rate could already be at a neutral level and the central bank may go "too far" if it stays on its path of further rate hikes. "A misinterpretation of where we are is a distinct possibility," Bullard said, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. "That's why I'm trying to push against faster rate hikes," he said. Earlier this month, the Fed lifted the benchmark rate to a range between 1.75% and 2% and penciled in two more rate hikes this year. Bullard, who has been arguing for going slow on rates all year, said he thinks the neutral rate might be 2%. The majority of Fed officials think the neutral rate is closer to 3%.

Shares of Universal Display Corp. OLED, +13.54% are down 3.4% in Tuesday morning trading, marking the sixth straight day that the stock is down and the ninth day out of the last 10 trading sessions. UDC's stock recently changed hands at $87. and is on pace to close at a 52-week low. Shares closed at $87.55 on April 25. The stock has been hammered in recent days amid concerns about Apple Inc.'s AAPL, -0.30% plans for its next iPhone lineup. The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Apple expects more than half of iPhones sold this fall to have liquid-crystal-display screens rather than organic-light-emitting-diode screens. Universal Display makes OLED technology. The stock is off 27% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

Yum Brands Inc.'s YUM, +0.25% Pizza Hut restaurant chain said Tuesday it will move to serve chicken that has been raised free of antibiotics important for human medicine by 2022 as part of its commitment to serve healthier food. The company said the move will apply to all chicken served at its restaurants, including its WingStreet wings. Pizza Hut will become the first national pizza chain to commit to an antibiotic policy for its chicken, the company said in a statement. Food companies and restaurants have been changing their supply chain to remove artificial additives and preservatives for the past few years, as consumers demand healthier options. Yum Brands shares were not yet active premarket, but have gained 1.5% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

President Donald Trump sharply escalated trade tensions with China late Monday, announcing plans for an additional $200 billion in tariffs on Chinese imports, and threatening another $200 billion in tariffs on top of that. In a statement, Trump said he has ordered the U.S. Trade Representative to identify $200 billion in Chinese goods that will face additional 10% tariffs. The new tariffs are a tit-for-tat measure in response to China's retaliatory tariffs announced after the $50 billion in tariffs that the U.S. put into effect Friday. The $200 billion in new tariffs will go into effect if China does not drop its retaliatory measure, Trump said. Trump also said that if China responds in kind, "we will meet that action by pursing additional tariffs on another $200 billion of goods."

MGM Growth Properties LLC MGP, -0.98% said Friday it raised its quarterly dividend by 2.4%, to 43 cents a share from 42 cents a share. The real estate investment trust said the new dividend will be payable July 16 to shareholders of record on June 29. Based on Thursday's stock closing price of $30.40, the new annual dividend rate implies a dividend yield of 5.66%, compared with the yield on the SPDR Real Estate Select Sector ETF XLRE, -0.96% of 3.35% and the implied yield on the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% of 1.90%, according to FactSet. MGM's stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has climbed 14% over the past three months, while the REIT ETF has tacked on 0.8% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1.3%.

Shares of Chinese streaming company iQiyi Inc. IQ, +0.79% are up 14% in Thursday trading, putting the stock on pace for the best single-day percentage gain in its history. Shares have posted five double-digit percentage gains since the beginning of May. IQiyi, which was split from Baidu Corp. BIDU, +0.10% in March, made a number of announcements Thursday, including that it was adding Jane Sun, the Chief Executive Officer of Ctrip.com International Ltd. CTRP, -1.01% as an independent director of its board. The company also said it was starting an artificial-intelligence competition centered on "video-based multimodal biometric recognition." The stock is now trading at more than double its March IPO price of $18. Shares are up 51% so far this month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.1%.

Shares of Lumentum Holdings Inc. LITE, +0.26% are down 2.6% in premarket trading after the optical-equpiment company announced that its chief financial officer would be leaving the company, but Needham analyst Alex Henderson is upbeat about the transition. "As Lumentum becomes a much larger company the skills required call for a more seasoned CFO with large company experiences and merger skills," he wrote. The company plans to acquire Oclaro Inc. OCLR, +0.89% and ramp up its 3D-sensing business. "We think this is a move from a position of strength and indicative of the strong trajectory of Lumentum," Henderson said. He rates the stock a strong buy with an $80 price target. The stock is down 6.1% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Needham analyst Scott Berg raised his price target on Zuora Inc. ZUO, +0.82% shares to $33 from $27 on Wednesday, after attending the company's customer conference. He and his team "came away with more conviction on the positive momentum within the subscription economy" and were "impressed to hear how big industries like car ownership and in-theater movies will move towards subscription models." Berg also saw positive signals for the company's RevPro product, which helps companies adjust to new accounting standards around revenue recognition. "Customer interest in RevPro was significantly higher than our expectations going into the conference," Berg wrote. Zuora shares are up 3.6% in Wednesday morning trading and up 51% over the past month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.3%. The company went public in mid-April.

AMC Entertainment Holdings, Inc. AMC, +3.25% will receive $45 million in cash in a transaction where private equity firm Abry Partners will take a controlling interest in Screenvision Media, in which AMC acquired a stake in 2016. AMC will retain a minority equity position in the privately-held company, which provides on-screen and in-lobby advertising in theaters. Since August, AMC has been monetizing certain assets in an effort to raise $400 million, including selling its stake in Open Road Releasing, LLC, now known as Global Road Entertainment, announcing a sale leaseback agreement for seven of its U.S. theaters and selling 15.8 million shares of National CineMedia, Inc. NCMI, +0.46% between September and June. AMC shares have fallen 2.3% in 2018 so far, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.8%.

Shares of Shake Shack Inc. SHAK, +0.19% fell in Thursday's extended session after the casual restaurant chain issued a weak same-stores sales guidance for 2018. Shake Shack reported its second-quarter earnings rose to $7.6 million, or 26 cents per Class A share, from $4.9 million, or 19 cents per Class A share, a year ago. On an adjusted basis, it would have earned 29 cents a share. Revenue grew 27% to $116.3 million while same-store sales rose 1.1%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 18 cents a share on revenue of $111 million. The company now expects 2018 revenue in a range of $446 million to $450 million. However, same-store sales are projected to be either flat or grow 1%, slower than the average 1.2% forecast by analysts. Shake Shack shares declined 5.8% after hours.

Sirius XM Holdings, Inc. SIRI, -0.50% reported second-quarter earnings early Wednesday that beat revenue and subscriber expectations. Profit for the latest quarter rose to $292 million, or 6 cents a share, from $202 million, or 4 cents a share, in the same quarter a year ago, matching the FactSet consensus of 6 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.43 billion from $1.35 billion a year ago, beating the FactSet consensus of $1.42 billion. The company reported adding 483,000 net new self-pay subscribers in the second quarter, beating the FactSet consensus of 339,200. The company raised its revenue guidance for the full year, saying it now expects revenue over $5.7 billion, more than the FactSet consensus of $5.74 billion. The stock has shot up 30.2% over the past year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has risen 5.5%.

Shares of Boston Scientific Corp. BSX, -0.89% shot up 4.3% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the medical technology company beat earnings and revenue expectations, and provided an upbeat outlook. Net income rose to $555 million, or 40 cents a share, from $146 million, or 11 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to 41 cents, above the FactSet consensus of 34 cents. Revenue rose to $2.49 billion from $2.26 billion, just above the FactSet consensus of $2.47 billion. The company adjusted its 2018 revenue outlook to $9.80 billion to $9.88 billion from $9.75 billion to $9.90 billion, and affirmed its adjusted EPS outlook of $1.37 to $1.41. The stock has soared 35% year to date through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.5%.

Constellation Pharmaceuticals Inc. CNST, -0.20% priced its initial public offering late Wednesday right in the middle of the expected range, but cut the size of its offering by 25%. The IPO priced at $15 a share, according to Nasdaq, but the shares offered was reduced to 4.0 million from the 5.34 million, to raise $60 million instead of $80.1 million. The biotechnology company is developing cancer therapies that modulate abnormal genes. The company had a net loss of $53.8 million in 2017, after a loss of $49.5 million in 2016, and had no revenue. The stock is expected to begin trade on Thursday. The company is looking to go public at a time that the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% has rallied 7% over the past three months while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.6%.

YayYo Inc. yayo disclosed Wednesday terms of its initial pubic offering, in which the ridesharing and taxi services company could raise up to $11.25 million. The Beverly Hills, Calif.-based said it is offering 1.25 million shares of common stock, with the IPO expected to price between $7 and $9 a share. If all the options granted to the underwriters to buy additional shares are exercised, the company could raise up to $12.94 million. YayYo expects the stock to list on the Nasdaq Capital Market under the ticker symbol "YAYO." The company reported a gross profit of $22,579 in 2017 and revenue of $235,690. YayYo is looking to go public at a time that the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% has gained 6.3% over the past three months while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has tacked on 3.7%.

Instinet analyst Dan Dolev reiterated his upbeat stance on Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% on Wednesday, given his latest look at Square Cash app downloads. Dolev said that downloads of Cash, Square's peer-to-peer money transfer app, accelerated in May and June. That acceleration is notable given that bitcoin BTCUSD, +1.74% has witnessed a sharp price decline in recent months, and Square Cash also enables users to buy and sell bitcoin, Dolev wrote. As such, he concluded that Square is not a bitcoin play and contrasted the app's continued momentum with a decline in Coinbase app downloads. Dolev's $82 price target makes him the most bullish analyst on the stock who's tracked by FactSet. Square shares are down 0.6% in premarket trading but up 155% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 15%.

Shares of Caterpillar Inc. CAT, -1.88% slumped 1.2% in morning trade Friday, enough to pace the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% decliners, as the first round of tariffs between the U.S. and China went into effect. Meanwhile, the Dow was up 6 points. Caterpillar has a lot to lose in a escalating trade war, as 59% of the machinery maker's revenue in 2017, 2016 and 2015 was from overseas. In 2017, 57% of Caterpillar's 98,400 employees were outside the U.S. And in the company's latest report, among the risks to its business that Caterpillar listed were the imposition of "burdensome tariffs" or quotas, changes in trade agreements and the imposition of new trade sanctions by the U.S. or foreign governments. The stock has shed 6.2% over the past three months, while the Dow has gained 1.8%.

Shares of Madison Square Garden Co. MSG, +0.31% are up more than 10% in premarket trading after the company said it received board approval to explore the possibility of spinning off its sports businesses into a separate company. Jefferies analyst John Janedis upgraded the stock to buy from hold on Thursday, raising his price target to $350 from $233. "MSG possesses a collection of unique, world class sports and entertainment assets which are largely underappreciated by investors," Janedis wrote. "As MSG intends to separate the Sports and Entertainment businesses in a tax-free spin, we expect the discount to fair value to narrow and shares to better reflect the considerable intrinsic value of the assets." MSG shares were up 33% over the past 12 months, as of Wednesday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 11%.

Shares of Spotify Technology SA SPOT, +0.90% are up 2.5% in Tuesday trading after Barclays analyst Ross Sandler initiated coverage of the stock with an overweight rating and $210 price target. "Our optimism around SPOT stems from the company's history of creating best-in-class products and user experience and innovating ahead of peers, a recipe for market cap accretion in consumer internet," he wrote. "While structural differences may make Spotify somewhat less desirable than Netflix Inc. NFLX, -1.00% long term, at a $30 billion market cap, the risks are skewed to the upside in our view." Also on Tuesday, Spotify said that Dawn Ostroff, formerly the president of entertainment at Conde Nast, is becoming the music-streaming company's chief content officer. Spotify shares are up 11.5% over the past month, while the S%P 500 SPX, -0.71% is little changed.

Shares of PagSeguro Digital Ltd. PAGS, -0.70% are down 11.3% in premarket trading Tuesday after the Brazilian payments company announced a follow-on offering. In a filing late Monday, PagSeguro said it was proposing to issue 11.6 million new Class A common shares. Selling shareholder Universo Online is proposing to sell 21.5 million existing Class A common shares, according to the filing. "Our first reading is negative, as it indicates controller is selling off even before the original lock up was ended," J.P. Morgan analyst Domingos Falavina wrote in a note to clients. "We note lock up could be released by underwriters, still uncommon to us to see second issuance so close to the IPO." Pag Seguro went public in a January IPO. The stock was up nearly 50% from its $21.50 IPO price as of Monday's close.

The U.K. House of Commons on Tuesday rejected a proposal that would have given Parliament the final say on terms of the U.K.'s exit from the European Union if no deal could be reached with European Union negotiators. The vote of 324 to 298 is considered a win for Prime Minister Theresa May. The upper House of Lords in March sought a "meaningful vote" amendment to the bill that takes the U.K. out of the EU. The pound GBPUSD, -0.2192% bought $1.3400 after Tuesday's vote, edging back from $1.3417 just before the vote. The pound had risen above $1.3400 late in Tuesday's session after the government defeated five other amendments put forth by the House of Lords. Debate on other amendments will continue on Wednesday, then the Brexit bill will be sent back to House of Lords.

Shares of Brink's Co. BCO, -0.87% ran up 13% in morning trade Thursday, after the cash management and transportation company provided an upbeat outlook as part of its announcement that it bought cash-management company Dunbar Armored Inc. for $520 million. Brink's said it now expects 2019 adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) of $625 million to $685 million, up from previous guidance of $625 million, assuming the Dunbar deal is completed by the end of 2018. Brink's said it will fund the purchase of Dunbar, which was said to be the fourth-largest cash management company in the U.S., with available cash. The stock is currently on track to close at the highest level since Feb. 6. It has still lost 2.5% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has tacked on 1.5%.

Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. LGF.A, +4.62%LGF.B, +4.19% said Wednesday it has acquired a majority stake in talent management and production company 3 Arts Entertainment. 3 Arts is the company behind a roster of directors, producers, actors, writers and comedians, and TV production including It's Always Sunny in Philadelphia, Man With A Plan, 30 Rock, King of the Hill, The Office, Parks and Recreation, Marlon, Brooklyn Nine Nine, The Mindy Project, Champions, Master of None, Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt, Insecure, American Vandal, and Silicon Valley. The deal, which is effective immediately, will allow Lions Gate to combine its global distribution infrastructure with production expertise and talent relationships. 3 Arts will operate under its current leadership. Lionsgate shares were slightly higher, but are down 13% in the last 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

Shares of Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% rallied Thursday to an all-time intraday high, before paring some gains, although rival Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. 005930, -0.77% unveiled its new Galaxy Note 9 smartphone. The world's largest smartphone maker's newest flagship device, unveiled at Brooklyn's Barclays Center, didn't look too new, according to a WSJ report. The unveiling comes about a month before Apple is expected to unveil its own new iPhones. Apple's stock climbed as much as 1.1% to an intraday high of $209.59, above the previous intraday record of $209.50 reached on Tuesday. It was last up 1%, above Monday's record closing price of $209.07. Apple's market-capitalization was $1.01 trillion. The stock has fun up 23.7% year to date, while Samsung shares have lost 8.0% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 3.4%.

Analysts at Canaccord Genuity on Friday started their coverage of Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% stock with a hold rating, saying that while Tesla "should be applauded for disrupting the auto industry in such a short period of time, we see several risks around the company's financing, cash burn, and general maturity in the Industry." The Canaccord analysts set a $336 price target on the shares, which represents a 4% downside to Friday prices and compares with an average of $311.79 from 27 analyst price targets compiled by FactSet. Tesla shares rose 0.4% on Friday and looked set to end the week 18% higher after the company reported mixed second-quarter results on Wednesday but investors seemed to like the renewed promises of profitability in the second quarter and a more muted performance for Chief Executive Elon Musk.

Wayfair Inc. W, +3.07% shares rose nearly 6% in Thursday premarket trading after the online home retailer reported better-than-expected second-quarter revenue. Wayfair had a net loss of $100.7 million, or $1.13 per share, wider than the $38.9 million, or 45-cent loss, last year. Adjusted loss was 77 cents per share exceeding the FactSet consensus for a 73-cent loss. Revenue was $1.66 billion, up from $1.12 billion last year, and ahead of the $1.60 billion FactSet consensus. Wayfair said the quarter included its biggest revenue day ever with Way Day, a shopping event. The number of active customers increased 34% year-over-year to 12.8 million. Average order value was $254 compared with $258 last year. Wayfair shares have gained 33.6% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 5.2% for the period.

U.S. government bonds Wednesday afternoon mostly unchanged after the Federal Reserve left benchmark rates unchanged and made few significant alterations to its policy statement, leaving the likelihood of further rate hikes in September and December still on the table. The 10-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.54% ticked down to 2.986%, from a high of about 3% intraday, while rates for the 2-year Treasury [ s: TMUBMUSD02Y], a maturity that is among the most sensitive to the interest-rate outlook, held at 2.678%, little changed from its level before the policy update at 2 p.m. Eastern. Yields for the so-called long bond, as the 30-year Treasury TMUBMUSD30Y, -0.22% is called by bond investors, was at 3.112%, edging slightly lower. The Federal Open Market Committee kept federal-funds futures rates at a range between 1.75% and 2%, as had been expected.

Shares of Juniper Networks Inc. JNPR, -0.19% are down 7.3% in premarket trading after the company delivered a disappointing forecast for its current quarter. BMO Capital Markets analyst Tim Long downgraded the stock to market perform from outperform Thursday night. "We do not think there will be adequate visibility into the cloud business for the next several quarters, and we are unsure of the extent to which revenue growth will return once the transition is complete," he wrote. "Services have stalled as well, though ASC-606 has had an impact. We are impressed with the rebound in Security, but it only represents 7% of total revenues." Long lowered his price target to $27 from $30. Shares were up 1.6% over the past 12 months, as of Thursday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 15%.

Nasdaq-100 futures fell sharply on Thursday after Facebook Inc. reported disappointing results and warned over revenue. Nasdaq futures NQU8, -0.47% dropped 68.75 points, or 0.9%, to 7,400.55, while those for the Dow Jones Industrial Average YMU8, -0.41% inched up 21 points to 25,423, while S&P 500 futures ESU8, -0.38% fell 7 points, or 0.3%, to 2,834.50. Facebook lost around one-fifth of its value in late trading on Wednesday after the social media giant reported flat user growth and sales that were weaker than forecast, and Chief Financial Officer David Wehner said a fall in revenue growth would continue. Disappointment over Facebook triggered a ripple effect, with Twitter Inc. TWTR, +0.16% and Snapchat parent company Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% also declining late Wednesday. Another tech behemoth, Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% will report after the close on Thursday.

Citrix Systems Inc. CTXS, +0.23% shares rose 3.9% late Wednesday after the technology company beat Wall Street earnings expectations for the second quarter. Citrix said it earned $107 million, or 73 cents a share, compared with $109 million, or 70 cents a share, in the second quarter of 2017. Adjusted for one-time items, Citrix earned $178 million, or $1.28 a share, compared with $158 million, or $1.03 a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 7% to $742 million, from $693 million a year ago, the company said. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of $1.20 a share on sales of $716 million. Citrix said it expects revenue between $2.92 billion to $2.95 billion in 2018, and adjusted EPS between $5.30 to $5.40 for the year. Shares ended the regular trading day 1.5% higher.

BTIG analyst Richard Greenfield initiated coverage of Spotify Technology SA SPOT, +0.90% with a buy rating and $230 price target on Monday. "Waiting for a better entry point into the stock has not worked and we believe the Spotify platform is simply too powerful/valuable to wait any longer to embrace SPOT," Greenfield wrote. He likes that the product has global reach, works across devices and has earned a place on many users' home screens. The company also has a direct credit-card billing relationship with about 57 million users. Greenfield is optimistic about Spotify's ability to drive more paying users who have started with its free service as well as its potential to leverage podcasts and in-car listening. The stock is up 16% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.9%.

Shares of Capital One Financial Corp. COF, -1.56% rose 1% late Thursday after the bank holding company reported second-quarter earnings above Wall Street forecasts. Capital One said it earned $1.9 billion, or $3.71 a share, in the quarter, compared with $1 billion, or $1.94 a share, in the second quarter of 2017. Adjusted for one-time items, Capital One earned $3.22 a share, compared with $1.96 a share a year ago. Net revenue rose to $7.2 billion, from $6.7 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of $2.64 a share on sales of $6.93 billion. "We saw credit improvement across our businesses, and growth math is now helping overall domestic credit card trends," founder and Chief Executive Richard D. Fairbank said in a statement. Shares ended the regular trading day down 1.8%.

President Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, a senior White House adviser, still lacks the highest security clearance, the Washington Post reported Thursday night, so he has been blocked from seeing parts of the President's Daily Brief. Experts told the Post that that could be severely hamper him from doing his job. In May, Kushner finally received a permanent security clearance after more than a year in his White House position. But the Post reported he only has "top secret" clearance, which prevents him from seeing the most classified materials. The CIA appears to have not yet approved Kushner's higher access, the Post said, though it was unclear exactly why. Kushner has been interviewed twice by special counsel Robert Mueller's investigators, and his name has come up on a number of occasions in the Russian meddling investigation.

U.S. oil prices pared much of their earlier losses Wednesday after the Energy Information Administration reported that domestic crude supplies plunged by 12.6 million barrels for the week ended July 6. Analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts had forecast a fall of 4.8 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday reported a drop of 6.8 million barrels, according to sources. Gasoline stockpiles fell by 700,000 barrels for the week, but distillate stockpiles jumped 4.1 million barrels higher for the week, according to the EIA. The S&P Global Platts survey forecast a supply decrease of 1 million barrels for gasoline and a rise of 1.7 million barrels for distillate stocks. August crude clq8 fell 40 cents, or 0.5%, to $73.71 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up from $73.27 before the supply data.

Arlo Technologies Inc., the security-camera making unit of Netgear Inc. NTGR, +0.52% has filed for a initial public offering, seeking to sell up to $100 million in shares. In a filing Friday, Arlo listed pro forma revenue of $101 million in the three months ended April 2, and pro forma earnings of $930,000 in the same period. It said it had 1.9 million registered users, and a share of 40% of the U.S. consumer network-connected camera systems market. The company plans to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol ARLO. It filed as an "emerging growth" company, facing fewer requirements. Underwriters include BofA Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank, and Guggenheim. Netgear announced the Arlo's spinoff in February. Shares of Netgear rose 3% late Friday after ending the regular trading day up 1.7%.

Shares of China Lending Corp. CLDC, -16.92% plummeted 30% in midday trade Friday, enough to make them the biggest decliner trading on major U.S. exchanges, after the China-based direct-lending company announced a direct placement of $2 million worth of ordinary shares with two institutional investors. The shares were sold at $2.60 a share, or 20% below Thursday's closing price of $3.26. The company will issue 769,232 ordinary shares, and will also issue Series A warrants to buy up to 576,924 shares at an exercise price of $2.60 and Series B warrants to buy up to 462,843 shares to the two institutional investors. The company has about 23.8 million shares outstanding, according to FactSet. Despite the selloff, the stock was still up 26.5% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.1%.

Embattled Environmental Protection Agency chief Scott Pruitt urged President Donald Trump to fire Attorney General Jeff Sessions and give the job to him, CNN reported late Tuesday. CNN, citing multiple sources, said Trump's advisers rejected the proposal. According to the report, Pruitt offered to temporarily replace Sessions, then he would step down and run for public office in his home state of Oklahoma. It was unclear exactly when Pruitt floated his plan, but Trump has publicly complained about Sessions for months, and as recently as April suggested replacing him with Pruitt. Late Tuesday, Priutt denied the report, saying it was "simply false" and that "I want nothing more than to see [Sessions] succeed in his role." Pruitt is facing more than a dozen federal investigations over his spending habits, allegedly improper lobbying and questionable ethical conduct.

Barnes & Noble Inc. BKS, +0.83% announced the termination of its chief executive Tuesday afternoon, saying that he had committed "violations of the company's policies." The bookstore chain did not go into more detail on why its board had decided to fire Demos Parneros, only explaining it had been advised by an outside law firm on the decision. A trio of top executives -- CFO Allen Lindstrom, CMO Tim Mantel and Carl Hauch -- will share CEO duties in the interim, with assistance from Executive Chairman Leonard Riggio. The company said it will begin searching for a new CEO immediately, and reaffirmed previous financial guidance. Barnes & Noble stock closed with a 4% decline at $6 a share, and have declined 10.5% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has added 2%.

Nordstrom Inc. JWN, +0.06% was downgraded to market perform from outperform at Cowen on a number of concerns, among them same-store sales at the off-price Rack chain that lag behind other off-price retailers. Nordstrom stock is down 1% in Monday premarket trading. Competing off-price names include TJX Cos.' TJX, +0.89% T.J. Maxx and Burlington Stores Inc. BURL, +0.13% Analysts are also concerned about same-store sales at the full-line Nordstrom stores and the potential need to shutter some locations. Some worries aren't specific to Nordstrom. "[T]he future of department stores remains a relevant topic," analysts wrote, as digitally-native names, their "highly-experiential retail concepts," and increased direct-to-consumer activity all gain market share quicker than Nordstrom. Nordstrom shares are up 9.3% for 2018 so far, outpacing the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% which is up 1.7% for the period.

Shares of General Electric Co. GE, -1.31% surged 1.5% in premarket trade Wednesday, adding tothe big rally in the prior session, after Oppenheimer backed off its bearish stance because of the industrial conglomerate's break-up plan. Analyst Christopher Glynn upgraded GE to perform from underperform, citing the "potential for [GE's] portfolio plan to unlock some value, and diminish liabilities." He estimates the separation of GE Healthcare could yield $50 billion of equity value, GE's stake in Baker Hughes, a GE Co. BHGE, +0.23% is currently worth about $23.5 billion and the company's pending deal in its transportation business is valued at over $12 billion. The stock has shed 21% year to date through Tuesday, while the SPDR Industrial Select Sector ETF XLI, -0.88% has lost 4.9% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has slipped 1.8%.

AT&T Inc. T, -0.71% is planning to make another content acquisition, according to Recode, which reported Wednesday that the telecommunications giant intends to acquire the rest of Otter Media, a company it co-owns with the Chernin Group. The Recode report said that the deal is expected to close this summer and was "on hold" until the company's Time Warner deal went through. Recode cites sources familiar with AT&T's plans and said that "industry observers" think the deal will give Otter Media a valuation of more than $1 billion. The Wall Street Journal reported late Tuesday that AT&T was also in talks to purchase AppNexus, an ad-tech company. AT&T shares are little changed in Wednesday morning trading, and they're down 16% over the past 12 months. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14% in that time.

Stifel analyst Scott Devitt wrote Monday that Google's recently announced investment in JD.com Inc. JD, -0.64% is an endorsement of the internet economy in Southeast Asia. "This transaction will better-position Google's retail efforts in the region," he said. Alphabet Inc.'s Google announced Monday that it would be investing $550 million in JD and that the two companies would begin a strategic partnership. "Notably, the investment is being made by the operating unit of Google versus one of Alphabet's investment vehicles," Devitt wrote. "The transaction is Google's second major investment in the greater Asia region this year, following the company's participation in Indonesian ride-railing service company Go-Jek's $1.2 billion fundraising round in January." JD.com shares are up 2.5% in Monday morning trading, while Alphabet shares have gained 0.2%. The S&P 500 is down 0.6% in Monday's session.

Shares of Nucor Corp. NUE, +0.06% rallied 2.4% in premarket trade Thursday, after the steel maker provided a second-quarter earnings-per-share outlook that was more than double the results from a year ago. The company said it expects EPS of $2.05 to $2.10 for the current quarter, up from $1.00 last year. That FactSet EPS consensus is $1.72. The outlook is also well above sequential first-quarter EPS of $1.10 because of higher selling prices and increased profitability across all steel mill product groups. "Our improved earnings are the result of much stronger market conditions that we believe have been positively impacted by deregulation, tax reform and higher, stable oil prices," the company said in a statement. the stock had gained 1.2% over the past three months through Wednesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 1%.

The Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection said it's reached a settlement with South Carolina's Security Group Inc., which is privately held, for allegedly making improper in-person and telephonic collection attempts on consumer installment loans and retail sales installment contracts. The agency said the actions taken included physically preventing consumers from leaving their homes and visiting and calling consumers' places of work while knowing that those contacts could endanger the consumers' employment. The company is barred from certain collection practices, has to correct inaccurate information about consumers furnished to credit-reporting agencies and was fined $5 million. It's the second enforcement action since Mick Mulvaney became interim director of the agency. In a statement, Security Group noted it didn't admit to any of the bureau's claims and said it disagrees with the allegations and "strongly disputes any wrongdoing."

Shares of First Data Corp. FDC, -0.12% are up 2.5% in Tuesday trading after the company's investor day in New York. The company reiterated its annual guidance and extended its medium-term outlook, which called for mid-single-digit revenue growth, to now cover the 2019-2021 period. First Data also said it expects to generate low-double-digit earnings growth over the three-year period, according to Piper Jaffray analyst Jason Deleeuw. He said that the company's "transformation has reached escape velocity" and increased his price target to $31 from $29. He highlighted the company's Clover product, which is an alternative to Square Inc.'s SQ, +1.76% offerings for small businesses, and will come to new countries including Germany, Austria, and Canada this year. First Data's stock is up 15% over the past 12 months, in line with the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71%

Shares of Roku Inc. ROKU, +1.27% are up 4.7% in Monday morning trading after KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst Evan Wingren said that his checks indicate "accelerating growth in customers on the Roku platform," based on his look at a database of credit and debit cards. Wingren also sees growth acceleration in virtual multichannel video programming distributors (vMVPDs), which he thinks also bodes well for Roku. "When vMVPDs and other content publishers sign agreements to be on the Roku platform, they typically share economics," he wrote. "We expect that accelerating vMVPD growth would accelerate platform growth for Roku, and bolster ad-supported video adoption on The Roku Channel." Wingren has an overweight rating on the stock and a $44 price target. Shares are down 21% so far this year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.1%.

Dish Network Corp. DISH, -3.88% disclosed Friday that Chief Financial Officer Steve Swain has resigned, effective Aug. 22, after about seven years with the company. The satellite pay-TV company did not give more details on the resignation. Swain, who joined the satellite pay-TV company in 2011 as vice president of corporate financial planning and analysis, also served as principal financial officer of both Dish Network and Dish DBS. Separately, Brookdale Senior Living Inc. BKD, -3.66% named Swain as CFO, effective Sept. 4. Dish said it designated Paul Orban, who has been chief accounting office since December 2015, as the principal financial officer of Dish Network and Dish DBS, effective Aug. 22. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has shed 23% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.7%.

LendingClub Corp. LC, +0.27% disclosed a Massachusetts investigation into its advertising and disclosure practices Thursday, sending shares down in after-hours trading following a rough regular session. In its quarterly filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the online lender said that it had received a civil investigative demand from the Massachusetts attorney general in June. The company also noted that it had "responded to inquiries from the California Department of Business Oversight and the New York Department of Financial Services regarding the operation of the company's business and the overall 'FinTech' industry." LendingClub did not disclose the investigations in its earnings report nor in its related conference call Tuesday afternoon. LendingClub stock plunged 10% in Wednesday's regular session after the earnings were released, and declined another 2% in after-hours trading after the new disclosure circulated.

Many details around Tesla Inc.'s TSLA, +0.86% plan to go private remain "unknowable," given in part the "vague verbiage" used to describe it, and as a result "the deal is unlikely to succeed in the very near-term, if it succeeds at all," analysts at Piper Jaffray said in a note Wednesday. For the "true believers with a multi-year time horizon," the suggested go-private valuation is "unpalatable," and gaining shareholder approval easier than gaining funding, the analysts said. The Piper Jaffray analysts kept the equivalent of a buy rating with a price target of $389 on Tesla stock. Chief Executive Elon Musk stunned markets Tuesday saying he was considering taking Tesla private at $420, and analysts have decried the lack of specifics around the proposal. Tesla shares fell 1.2%, paring some of their earlier losses Wednesday.

The total value of all cryptocurrencies fell to its lowest level in 2018 as the price of the No. 1 digital currency, bitcoin fell by as much as 10% Tuesday after the Securities and Exchange Commission delayed the ruling on a proposed bitcoin-related exchange-traded fund from VanEck and SolidX. The market cap for all digital currencies fell to $230 billion in Wednesday trading, its lowest level since Nov. 17, and $600 billion off its all-time high on Jan. 7. The digital-asset market has been in steady decline for the better part of the year, dogged by a number of exchange hacks and regulatory concerns centered on the integrity of the nascent technology. A single bitcoin BTCUSD, +1.73% last changed hands at $6,455.81, down 6.2% since Tuesday 5 p.m. in New York on the Kraken exchange.

Weight Watchers International Inc. WTW, -2.98% shares fell in the extended session Monday even after the weight-loss company's quarterly results and outlook topped Wall Street estimates. Weight Watchers shares fell 4.7% after hours, following a 0.7% gain to close the regular session at $92.21. The company reported second-quarter net income of $70.7 million, or $1.01 a share, compared with $45.2 million, or 67 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $409.7 million from $341.7 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated earnings of 88 cents a share on revenue of $409.5 million. For the year, Weight Watchers raised its earnings outlook to a range of $3.10 to $3.25 a share, up from a previous range of $3 to $3.20 a share. Analysts expect earnings of $2.92 a share.

Sempra Energy shares SRE, -0.25% slid more than 5% in premarket trade Monday, after the company posted a loss for the second quarter and weaker-than-expected revenue. Sempra said it had a net loss of $561 million, or $2.11 a share, in the quarter, after earnings of $259 million, or $1.03 a share, in the year-earlier quarter. The loss was driven by a $755 million impairment charge related to the planned sale of certain U.S. midstream assets, as well as a $145 million charge related to the planned sale of U.S. wind investments. Adjusted per-share earnings came to $1.35, ahead of the FactSet consensus of $1.18. Revenue rose to $2.564 billion from $2.533 billion, missing the FactSet consensus of $2.643 billion. Shares have gained 9.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.2%.

Brookstone Co. Inc. said Thursday it has filed for bankruptcy, to facilitate the sale of the specialty travel and entertainment products retailer. The company said it has begun a process to close its remaining 101 mall stores, citing continued deterioration of retail mall traffic, while it will continue to operate its airport, e-commerce and wholesale businesses. "Today we have taken several important steps to restructure the business and ensure that Brookstone will be well-positioned to succeed for years to come," said Chief Executive Piau Phang Foo. The company said it has secured $30 million in post-petition financing to support its operations during the sale and restructuring process. The bankruptcy comes as the SPDR S&P Retail ETF XRT, +0.06% has rallied 20.3% over the past 12 months and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13.6%.

The Bank of England on Thursday, as expected, raised its bank rate by 25 basis points, or a quarter of a percentage point, to 0.75%. The nine-member Monetary Policy Committee voted unanimously for the hike. "Since the May Inflation Report, the near-term outlook has evolved broadly in line with the MPC's expectations," the committee said in a statement. "Recent data appear to confirm that the dip in output in the first quarter was temporary, with momentum recovering in the second quarter. The labor market has continued to tighten and unit labor cost growth has firmed." In a nod to difficult Brexit negotiations, the MPC said it "continues to recognize that the economic outlook could be influenced significantly by the response of households, businesses and financial markets to developments related to the process of EU withdrawal.:

KLA-Tencor Corp. KLAC, -2.18% shares rose in the extended session Monday after the equipment maker for the chip industry reported that quarterly results topped Wall Street estimates and forecast a strong outlook. KLA-Tencor shares rose 4% after hours, following a 1.2% decline to close the regular session at $106.30. The company reported fiscal fourth-quarter net income of $348.8 million, or $2.22 a share, compared with $256.2 million, or $1.62 a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $1.07 billion from $939 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated $2.13 a share on revenue of $1.05 billion. For the September-ending quarter, KLA-Tencor estimates adjusted earnings of $2.04 to $2.36 a share on revenue of $1.03 billion to $1.11 billion. Analysts expect earnings of $2.06 a share on revenue of $1.04 billion.

Shares of NXP Semiconductor Inc. NXPI, -1.17% are down 3.8% in premarket trading Wednesday, as the deadline for Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, -0.40% to obtain Chinese regulatory approval for its planned acquisition of NXPI looms at the end of the day. The companies said in April that they would end the deal if they didn't win China's approval by the end of the day on July 25. The deal is thought to be caught up in trade-war tensions between the U.S. and China. Reuters reported Wednesday that one source said Qualcomm was hitting a "stone wall" as it tried to negotiate with China's regulators, while another said that deal approval on Wednesday looks unlikely. Shares of Qualcomm, which would have to pay a $2 billion break-up fee if the deal doesn't happen, are down 0.4% premarket.

Hess Corp. shares HES, +0.42% rose 2.7% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the energy company posted a narrower-than-expected second-quarter loss and blew past revenue estimates. Hess said it had a net loss of $130 million, or 48 cents a share, in the quarter, narrower than the $449 million loss, or $1.46 a share, posted in the year-earlier period. Adjusted loss per share came to 23 cents, narrower than the 28 cents loss FactSet consensus. Revenue rose to $1.566 billion from $1.202 billion, topping the FactSet consensus of $1.338 billion. Exploration and production net income came to $31 million, after a net loss of $354 million in the year-earlier period. Midstream net income came to $30 million, up from $16 million. Shares have gained 37.1% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.5%.

Shares of United Technologies Corp. UTX, -0.85% surged 2.7% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the building systems and aerospace company reported second-quarter earnings and revenue that rose above expectations. Net income increased to $2.14 billion, or $2.56 a share, from $1.44 billion, or $1.80 a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share of $1.97 beat the FactSet consensus of $1.86. Revenue grew 9% to $16.71 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $16.27 billion. The company raised its 2018 adjusted EPS outlook to $7.10 to $7.25 from $6.95 to $7.15, and its sales outlook to $63.5 billion to $64.5 billion from $63.0 billion to $64.5 billion. The stock has rallied 6% over the past three months while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has tacked on 4.3%.

U.S. stocks closed mostly higher on Monday, boosted by a rally in financial shares. Investors digested a raft of positive corporate earnings, though gains were capped by fresh geopolitical worries after President Donald Trump tweeted a strong warning to Iran. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 5.14 points, or 0.2%, to 2,806.97 with the financial sector leading gains, up 1.3%. Shares of large banks, such as J.P.Morgan Chase JPM, -0.98% and Bank of America BAC, -1.30% rose more than 2%. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% advanced 21.67 points, or 0.3%, to 7,841.87. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% ended 13.42 points, or less than 0.1%, lower at 25,044.70. Among the biggest gainers on the S&P 500, shares of Hasbro Inc. HAS, -0.52% jumped 12% after it reported second-quarter results that easily topped forecasts.

Halliburton Co. shares HAL, +1.04% slid 0.8% in premarket trade Monday, after second-quarter earnings failed to dazzle investors. The company said it had net income of $511 million, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $28 million, or 3 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $6.147 billion from $4.957 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of 58 cents and revenue of $6.111 billion. The year-earlier numbers were hit by impairment and other charges relating to a writedown of the company's remaining investment in Venezuela. By operating segment, completion and production revenue rose 9% from the first quarter to $4.2 billion. Drilling and evaluation rose 3% from the first quarter to $2.0 billion. Shares are down 7.5% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.8%.

Shares of Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% are up 0.3% in Monday trading after Wells Fargo analyst Ken Sena raised his price target on the stock to $250 from $230. He sees potential for the company to increase monetization of its Instagram Stories product, which lets users post photographic or video updates about their day that disappear after 24 hours. "We calculate that Instagram Stories currently monetize at 1/4th the rate of Instagram feed on a per minute basis or ~1/9th the rate of feed per DAU," Sena wrote. In general, he is upbeat on Instagram, which recently passed 400 million daily active users, and he predicts that growth in Instagram usage won't hurt the core Facebook platform. Shares are up 29% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

TV station operator Gray Television Inc. GTN, -2.69% said Monday it reached a deal to buy employee-owned local media company Raycom Media Inc. in a deal valued at $3.65 billion, including $100 million of Raycom cash. The deal will consist of $2.85 billion in cash, $650 million in a new series of preferred stock and 11.5 million shares of Gray common stock. The debt financing portion of the deal of $2.53 billion was underwritten by Wells Fargo. The deal, which is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2018, is expected to "substantially" add to free cash flow on a per-share basis. Gray's stock was inactive in premarket trade, prior to a trading halt for news. It has tumbled 24% year to date through Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3%.

Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Scott Pruitt faces yet more allegations of misconduct following a pair of reports Sunday. The New York Times reported that newly disclosed emails show Pruitt discussed hiring a friend of the lobbyists from whom he was renting a Washington condo for $50 a night. The emails also reportedly show evidence of closer ties between one of the lobbyists and the EPA than previously disclosed, contradicting Pruitt's assertions. Separately, Politico reported Pruitt is being investigated by the U.S. Office of Special Counsel for allegedly retaliating against EPA employees who objected to his spending habits, firing some and reassigning others. Pruitt is facing investigations into abouta dozen other scandals, ranging from lavish spending to having staff run personal errands for him to using his office to seek a job opportunity for his wife.

Shares of Stamps.com Inc. STMP, +2.98% are down more than 10% in Thursday trading after the White House announced a proposal to restructure the United States Postal Service. The proposal examines ways to "return it to a sustainable business model or prepare it for future conversion from a Government agency into a privately-held corporation." It argues that "like many European nations, the United States could privatize its postal operator while maintaining strong regulatory oversight to ensure fair competition and reasonable prices for customers." If the losses hold, it would be the largest single-day percentage drop for Stamps.com's stock since November 2017, when shares plunged 22.6%. The company sells mailing and shipping products online, and its stock is up 70% over the past 12 months. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13% in that time.

Shares of Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% closed at a record high Wednesday, rising 2.3% after the company said its Instagram platform now has 1 billion users. At an event, Instagram also announced a new app for watching "long-form, vertical video," which will compete with Alphabet Inc.'s GOOGL, -0.95% YouTube and Snap Inc.'s SNAP, +0.00% Snap. The service, called IGTV, will have its own app but also be available from within the Instagram app. Videos on IGTV can be up to an hour long, and videos will begin playing once you open the app. Instagram said in a release that this was "just like turning on the TV." Facebook's stock closed above $200 for the first time Wednesday and is up 33% in the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Spotify Technology SA SPOT, +0.90% shares are up 1.3% in Thursday morning trading, despite a lukewarm initiation note from Deutsche Bank analyst Lloyd Walmsley, who started coverage with a hold rating. "We are bullish on the music industry but struggle with the bull case on Spotify given its lack of content differentiation or visibility around long term margins," he wrote. "We do not think Spotify is Netflix NFLX, -1.00% 2.0." Walmsley provided a list of the factors that would make him more upbeat about Spotify, including significant market-share growth, valuable proprietary content, diversification away from the big labels, and a lower valuation. He has a $155 price target on the stock, which recently changed hands near $173. Spotify shares are up 10% so far in June, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.1%.

Shares of Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% are up 0.3% in Tuesday morning trading after KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst John Vinh said that iPhone inventory levels "have normalized" ahead of iPhone launch season later this year. "We would also highlight that current inventory levels are consistent with healthy levels observed in past cycles, which incrementally leaves us more constructive ahead of the 2H ramp of the new iPhone 9 cycle," Vihn wrote. He added that Samsung Galaxy S9 sell-through "continues to deteriorate." Vinh recommended that investors "continue to own" shares of Apple suppliers Broadcom Inc. AVGO, -2.01% Skyworks Solutions Inc. SWKS, -1.31% and Synaptics Inc. SYNA, -11.38% heading into the launch of the next iPhone. Apple shares are up 32% over the past 12 months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 19%.

Shares of Fitbit Inc. FIT, -1.78% are up 1.8% in premarket trading after gaining nearly 15% in Monday's session. The company has seen newfound enthusiasm for its health-solutions business, including from analysts at Citron Research, who made a bullish call on the stock Monday and argued that Fitbit makes an attractive takeover candidate for a company like Alphabet Inc.'s GOOGL, -0.95% Google. On Tuesday, Fitbit was granted a patent for a "monitoring device using radar and measuring motion with a non-contact device." According to the patent filing, the device would have "one or more microphones, a transmitter and sensors to determine air quality, sound level quality, light quality, ambient temperature and humidity" and communicate with a "cloud-based system." Shares are up 34% so far in June, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.8%.

Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, -0.67% on Tuesday announced it has struck a deal to sell 52 retail branches to Flagstar Bank, which is a subsidiary of Flagstar Bancorp FBC, -0.96% The affected branches are in Indiana, Michigan, Ohio, and Wisconsin. Approximately 490 Wells employees at those locations will receive job offers from Flagstar. The sale is part of a previously-announced plan to whittle Wells' branch footprint, the company said in a release. It comprises approximately $2.3 billion in deposits, and should close in the fourth quarter, Wells said. Both banks will communicate with customers who have deposits at those locations. Shares of Wells Fargo have declined nearly 10% in the year to date, compared to a 3% increase in the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% as the bank works to contain fallout from customer scandals.

The American Petroleum Institute reported Wednesday that U.S. crude supplies rose by 1 million barrels for the week ended May 25, according to sources. The API data also showed a fall of 1.7 million barrels in gasoline stockpiles, while inventories of distillates climbed by 1.5 million barrels, sources said. The data were released a day later than usual because of Monday's holiday. Supply data from the Energy Information Administration will be released Thursday morning. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts expect the EIA to report a fall of 600,000 barrels in crude supplies. They also forecast supply declines of 1.5 million barrels for gasoline and nearly 1.1 million barrels for distillates. July crude cln8 was at $68.23 a barrel in electronic trading, little changed from the contract's $68.21 settlement on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Moody's Investors Service late Friday placed Italy's debt rating on review for a downgrade, saying the country's faces "significant risk of a material weakening" in its fiscal strength given the plans of its new anti-establishment coalition government. Italy could also see some of its reform efforts stall and past reforms could be reversed, the ratings agency said. The review allows Moody's to seek more clarity on the new government's plans, which include calls for a flat tax and universal income. The Moody's action comes after Italy's new coalition between the 5 Star Movement and the League was granted authority to form a coalition government by President Sergio Mattarella. The parties have vowed to challenge the EU's budget rules and slash taxes, while increasing fiscal spending. Moody's rates Italian debt Baa2, two notches above "junk" status.

Trade Desk Inc. TTD, +37.13% shares surged in the extended session Thursday after the ad-tech company topped Wall Street estimates. Trade Desk shares rallied 13% after hours, following a 2.1% rise to close the regular session at $93.29. The company reported second-quarter net income of $19.3 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $18.8 million, or 43 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 60 cents a share. Revenue rose to $112.3 million from $72.8 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated 44 cents a share on revenue of $104 million. Trade Desk estimates revenue of $116 million for the third quarter, and $433 million in revenue for the year. Analysts expect revenue of $109.2 million for the third quarter, and $436.5 million for the year.

Shares of Green Dot Corp. GDOT, +0.24% are up 4.9% in Thursday morning trading after the prepaid-card company reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its June quarter. "Green Dot has exceeded our building growth expectations, delivering faster card growth and better yield," wrote SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst Andrew Jeffrey, who raised his price target on the stock to $100 from $75. He said that Green Dot's 16% organic revenue growth was fueled both by its legacy card business and its newer banking-as-a-service products. "Over time, we believe Green Dot's mobile platform solutions can fuel faster sustainable organic revenue growth, expand its TAM [total addressable market] and bring its products into the mainstream," Jeffrey wrote. Green Dot shares are up 86% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 16%.

Shares of Biogen Inc. BIIB, -1.12% rose 0.6% in premarket trade Friday, after the biotechnology company disclosed the authorization of a $3.5 billion share repurchase program. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said the repurchase program does not have an expiration date. The company said all shares repurchased under the program will be retired. The previous $5 billion share buyback program authorized in July 2016 was completed as of June 30, 2018. Based on Thursday's stock closing price of $347.93, the new program could buy back up to 10.06 million shares, or about 5% of the shares outstanding. The stock has run up 30.6% over the past three months, while the iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF BIIB, -1.12% has climbed 16.6% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 7.5%.

A major Trump campaign donor agreed to pay $10 million to Michael Cohen, then President Donald Trump's personal attorney, in exchange for securing successful funding for a nuclear power plant, which included a $5 billion government loan, the Wall Street Journal reported late Thursday. Anonymous sources told the Journal that real-estate developer Franklin Haney agreed to a contract with Cohen in April for help completing an unfinished nuclear-plant project in Alabama. Cohen is reportedly under federal investigation for possible unregistered lobbying, as well as potential campaign-finance violations and bank fraud, sources told the Journal. While such success fees are not by themselves illegal, experts told the Journal that they are widely seen as unethical, and a $10 million success fee would be significantly higher than is typical. A lawyer for Haney denied the report.

Sarepta Therapeutics Inc. SRPT, -2.58% shares fell in after-hours trading Wednesday, when the company announced a study of a potential drug for Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy had been halted by the Food and Drug Administration. The study of a potential gene-therapy approach to the disease "has been placed on clinical hold due to the presence of a trace amount of DNA fragment in research-grade third-party supplied plasmid," the company noted. Sarepta said it still plans to begin dosing patients in the study by the end of the year as long as the FDA accepts its plans to address the issue. Sarepta planned to hold a conference call at 5 p.m. Eastern time to address the issue. Sarepta shares initially fell more than 9% after the news was released, but declines soon settled to about 5.5%.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin says President Donald Trump, despite comments this week expressing opposition to monetary-policy tightening by the Federal Reserve, supports the U.S. central bank's independence. "I fully support the Fed's independence, as does the president," Mnuchin reportedly said on the sidelines of a G20 meeting of finance ministers and central bankers in Buenos Aires. Trump broke with long-standing precedent this week by saying he was "not happy" with recent interest-rate increases. He later said he "couldn't care less" about concerns that his comments could imperil the Fed's independence from politics because his views on interest rates have not changed since his days as a businessman. He harshly criticized former Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen for, he said at the time, maintaining low target lending rates for the political benefit of then-President Barack Obama.

Gabelli & Co. analyst Brett Harriss downgraded shares of Altaba Inc. AABA, +0.68% to hold from buy on Wednesday, in reaction to the company's recent announcement that it would sell about a third of its stake in Yahoo Japan to Softbank Group Corp. 9984, -0.49% "This marks the second taxable disposition of Y!J's holdings: On June 7th, 2018 Altaba announced a tender offer to repurchase Altaba shares using a combination of Alibaba BABA, +1.59% stock and cash," Harriss wrote. "We expect it is now more likely than not that Altaba liquidates its holdings in fully taxable transactions." Altaba shares are down 2% in Wednesday trading. Chinese tech companies and companies with links to China are trading broadly lower in the session, with Alibaba's stock down 1.7% and JD.com Inc.'s JD, -0.64% stock off 1.9%.

Claude Lanzmann, the French film-maker and journalist who is best known for the more than 9-hour holocaust documentary "Shoah," has died aged 92, French newspaper Le Monde reported Thursday. The news was confirmed by his family, although no cause of death was offered. Lanzmann spent 11 years making "Shoah," which has a running time of 560 minutes. The son of Russian Jewish immigrants to France won many awards for the documentary, which was released in 1985, including the New York Times Critics Circle award for best non-fiction film, the BAFTA award for best documentary, the Berlin International Film Festival Caligari film award, and the Los Angeles Film Critics Association special award. The director's final film, Napalm, was shown at Cannes in 2017 and centered around visits made to North Korea as a young journalist.

Boeing Co. BA, -1.25% and Brazil-based Embraer S.A. ERJ, -2.28%EMBR3, -0.49% announced Thursday a partnership to help both companies accelerate growth in the aerospace market. Boeing's stock rose 0.4% in light premarket trade, while Embraer's U.S.-listed shares were indicated up over 4%. The companies are planning to form a joint venture, of which Boeing will have an 80% stake. The deal would value Boeing's ownership in the JV at $3.8 billion, and value 100% of Embraer's commercial aircraft operations at $4.75 billion. Boeing expects the partnership to add to earnings beginning in 2020, and create annual cost synergies of about $150 million by the third year. Boeing's stock has rallied 13% year to date through Tuesday, while Embraer shares have climbed 9.5% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has slipped 2.2%.

Citing national security concerns, the Trump administration is attempting to block China Mobile Ltd 0941, -1.95% from accessing U.S. telecommunications markets. The state-owned telecommunications company applied for a license through the Federal Communications Commission to offer its services from within the U.S. back in 2011. The agency then went back to the Trump administration to get its opinion on that request, a response that came in a statement on Monday. "After significant engagement with China Mobile, concerns about increased risks to U.S. law enforcement and national security interests were unable to be resolved," said David J. Redl, assistant secretary for communications and information at Commerce Department, who said they would recommend the FCC deny that license request. The move comes as the Trump administration is engaged in a tense standoff with China over trade.

Shares of Star Bulk Carriers Corp. SBLK, -0.90% drops 6.9% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the Greece-based dry bulk shipping company said its largest shareholder sold off part of its stake, at a discount to current share prices. The company said a secondary public offering of 5 million shares offered by Oaktree Capital Management LP priced at $13.10 a share, or 6.9% below Tuesday's stock closing price of $14.07. Prior to the offering, Oaktree owned 32.58 million Star Bulk shares as of March 31, or about 50.8% the shares outstanding. After the offering, Star Bulk said Oaktree will own about 43% of the shares outstanding. Star Bulk will not receive any proceeds from the offering. The stock had rallied 25% year to date through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 1.9%.

Lockheed Martin Corp. LMT, -0.82% said it expects to create 150 to 200 new jobs, as it received a $1.2 billion contract from the U.S. government to build 16 new F-16 Block 70 aircraft for the Kingdom of Bahrain. The new jobs will be at company's Greenville, South Carolina facility, where the aircraft will be produced. "We value our long-standing relationship with the Kingdom of Bahrain and look forward to beginning production activities on their first Block 70 aircraft at our facility in Greenville," said Susan Ouzts, vice president of Lockheed's F-16 program. "This sale highlights the significant, growing demand we see for new production F-16s around the globe." The stock slipped 0.1% in premarket trade. It has slumped 11% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.4%.

Shares of MoviePass majority owner Helios & Matheson Analytics Inc. HMNY, -19.87% are down more than 30% in Wednesday morning trading after the company provided information about its July annual meeting. The company said that, at the meeting, it will to looking for approval for its plans to increase the number of its shares of common stock from to 2 billion from 500 million as well as to do a one-time reverse split. The company wants to do a reverse split "at a ratio of 1 share-for-2 shares up to a ratio of 1 share-for-250 shares, which ratio will be selected by the Company's Board of Directors." The meeting will be held on an unspecified date in July. HMNY shares are down 95% this year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% is up 3.6%.

Wedbush analyst Steve Koenig downgraded Oracle Corp. ORCL, -0.45% shares to neutral from outperform on Wednesday, following the company's latest earnings report. "We're stepping to the sidelines on Oracle, as we're less confident that the company can successfully navigate a transition to the cloud," Koenig wrote. "Oracle's issues likely go beyond execution: they appear more deeply rooted in more intense competition in the cloud, reliance on a perpetual model, and perhaps cultural inertia." He said that while Oracle beat expectations in the latest quarter, it likely missed its goals for cloud bookings. The company stopped breaking out its cloud business with the most recent numbers. Oracle shares are down 4.5% in premarket trading Wednesday, but they're up 0.9% over the past 12 months. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13% in that time.

Shares of Avalara Inc. AVLR, -7.74% soared on their public debut, with the first trade 50% above the initial public offering price, which was priced above the expected range. The first trade was at $35 at 10:39 a.m. ET, for 1.2 million shares. It has extended gains rocket 52% in morning trade. The IPO priced overnight at $24, above the expected range of $21 to $23, which was raised earlier this week from $19 to $21. The company sold 7.5 million shares to raise $180 million, and could raise an additional $27 million if the underwriters exercise all the options to buy additional shares. Avalara went public at a time that the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% has gained 5.4% the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has tacked on 0.6%.

Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% shares are up 0.3% in Monday morning trading after KeyBanc analyst Andy Hargreaves wrote that Instagram could be the company's "primary growth driver" come 2020. He sees Instagram generating 27% of incremental ad revenue this year and 58% by 2020. Hargreaves also projects that Insatgram will have more than 1.4 billion monthly active users and more than $22 billion in annual revenue by 2020. "As core Facebook matures, Instagram is the key to the next leg of growth," he wrote. "Core Facebook is clearly maturing, with ad load reaching a saturation point and pricing the last lever to pull, so we see Instagram driving an increasing portion of incremental advertising growth." The stock is up 27% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Treasury yields swung lower on Wednesday after trading higher in the morning. The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.19% was down 5.5 basis points to 2.920%, while the 2-year note yield TMUBMUSD02Y, +0.00% fell 3.2 basis points to 2.488%. The 30-year bond yield TMUBMUSD30Y, +0.11% slipped 5.9 basis points to 3.070%. Bond prices move in the opposite direction of yields. Some traders and analysts pointed to the selloff in the Brazilian stock market and in the Brazilian real USDBRL, -0.1553% as a potential driver of the bond market rally. Brazil's Bovespa index BVSP, -2.86% was down more than 5% on the day. Investors will often run into Treasurys during times of market turmoil. But some also said a bond trader may have made a "fat finger" mistake after a sudden spike in trading volumes.

U.s. government bonds on Friday retreated after a report on consumer prices for July indicated that inflation was percolating slightly--moderating an early morning rally in Treasuries. The 10-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.66% was yielding 2.903% from 2.893% just before the release of the closely watched consumer-price index. The 30-year Treasury note rate was at 3.052% from 3.047% before the reading, while the 2-year Treasury note yield was at 2.629%, compared with 2.621% earlier. Bond prices fall as yields rise. The CPI reading--a broad measure of U.S. citizens' expenses, rose 0.2% from a month earlier, the Labor Department said Friday. Excluding volatile food and energy, core CPI rose 0.2%. Earlier in the session, bonds were being bought as worries sparked by turmoil in Turkey's currency, which spread across European markets, fueled a flight to the perceived safety of government paper.
