The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% declined 52.67 points, or 0.7% to 7,839.11, but managed to end the week with a 0.4% gain.

The Turkish lira extended its slide on Friday as President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in a speech called on his population to exchange dollars and gold for lira. Having called for this before, Erdogan added that it would be an effective response to the West. He also said "Turkey won't surrender to economic hitmen." U.S.-Turkish relations have been strained over the detention of a U.S. pastor in Turkey. The lira hit a historic low against the U.S. dollar USDTRY, +7.2128% and the euro EURTRY, +6.8824% on Friday and spiked to session lows during the president's speech. The country will introduce its 2019-2023 economic program in early September. One dollar last bought 6.1323 lira, up 10.5%, while the euro fetched 7.0223 lira, up 9.8%, according to FactSet.

Crude-oil prices edged lower Thursday, settling in negative territory for a second straight session. West Texas Intermediate crude oil for September delivery CLU8, -0.35% closed off 13 cents, or about 0.2%, at $66.81 a barrel. Worries that demand has been weakening is a key theme that has recently weighed on crude prices. U.S. oil prices registered their steepest one-day drop in more than three weeks on Wednesday as the bullish narrative that had buoyed crude futures for the past two sessions-supply disruptions and strong demand-fizzled out. Investors are now fretting that demand from the second-largest economy and biggest oil importer, China, may be hurt as the country faces economic slowdown and as trade clashes between President Donald Trump and Beijing show apparent signs of intensifying.

Shares of ELF Beauty Inc. ELF, +3.35% tanked in Wednesday's extended session after the beauty-products retailer cut its revenue forecast for 2018. ELF reported its second-quarter net income shrank to $1.24 million, or 3 cents a share, from $4 million, or 8 cents a share, a year earlier. On an adjusted basis, the company would have earned 13 cents a share. Revenue rose 6% to $59.1 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 6 cents a share on revenue of $59.1 million. Meanwhile, ELF lowered its 2018 revenue outlook to low single digits from 6% to 8% and widened its adjusted earnings per share estimate to 56 cents to 61 cents versus 59 cents to 61 cents. ELF shares skidded 10% after hours.

MoviePass Films, the production arm of MoviePass, has recruited Bruce Willis to star in its first feature film, "10 Minutes Gone," according to a Deadline report published Tuesday. In May, MoviePass parent Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc.HMNY, -19.87% acquired Emmett Furla Oasis Films to launch MoviePass Films as a subsidiary to its ticket sales business. MoviePass has struggled for the past few months, burning through cash, implementing a 1-for-250 reverse stock split and introducing a number of pricing changes in an effort to accelerate its road to profitability. The company's most recent move was to slash its film allowance to three movies a month. Helios and Matheson shares have fallen 100% so far this year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 7%.

Sinclair Broadcast Group is launching CompulseOTT, an over-the-top advertising platform, the company SBGI, +0.36% announced Tuesday. CompulseOTT will offer advertisers 15- or 30-second commercials on platforms such as Roku ROKU, +1.27% , AppleTV AAPL, -0.30% , gaming consoles, Smart TVs and streaming sticks, the company said. Advertisers will be able to buy commercials in one or several designated market areas in one transaction. The new platform will also provide "granular targeting," Sinclair said, allowing advertisers to target beyond basic demographics like age, gender and household income. They will be able to target behavioral characteristics such as "intent to purchase a mid-sized sedan" or "travel enthusiast," Sinclair said. Sinclair shares have gained 31% so far this year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 7%.

Shares of Hertz Global Holdings Inc. HTZ, +0.00% rose 0.7% late Monday after the rental-car company swung to a narrower-than-expected adjusted loss in the second quarter. Hertz said it lost $63 million, or 75 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with a net loss of $158 million, or $1.90 a share, in the second quarter of 2017. Adjusted for one-time items, Hertz lost $16 million, or 19 cents a share, compared with an adjusted net loss of $52 million, or 63 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 7% to $2.4 billion, the company said. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted losses of 24 cents a share on sales of $2.3 billion. Hertz shares ended the regular trading session down 1.5%.

Shares of Arista Networks Inc. ANET, -0.18% are up 2.7% in Monday morning trading after the company said in a filing that it had entered into a binding term sheet with Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, +0.00% that result in the dismissal of patent-infringement litigation. Arista will pay Cisco $400 million by Aug. 20, per the terms of the agreement. The two companies have agreed to "a five-year stand-down period as to any utility patent infringement claims either may have against features currently implemented in the other party's products and services," per an Arista SEC filing, with some exceptions for certain acquisitions. Arista shares are up 12.6% so far this year, while Cisco's stock is up 12.1% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.4%.

Kellogg Co. K, +0.11% reported second-quarter net income of $596 million, or $1.71 per share, up from $283 million, or 80 cents per share, last year. The company said the jump was due to lower restructuring charges, favorable adjustments, and a one-time gain from a West Africa transaction. Adjusted EPS was $1.14, beating the $1.05 FactSet consensus. Sales were $3.36 billion up from $3.18 billion, ahead of the $3.30 billion FactSet guidance. Sales in North America slipped as the snacks and morning foods segments declined. Europe, Latin America and Asia Pacific reported sales growth. Kellogg shares are down 0.6% in Thursday premarket trading, but have gained 2.1% for 2018 to date. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 5.2% for the year so far.

Hedge fund Greenlight Capital, managed by David Einhorn, lashed out at several companies in its letter to investors late Tuesday, but Greenlight and Einhorn got personal with Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% According to the letter, Einhorn "is happy that his Model S lease ended (there were growing problems with the touchscreen and the power windows" and happy to switch to an electric Jaguar. Next year will be "a very challenging" year for Tesla, and the letter continued on a more personal tone saying that Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk "appears erratic and desperate." Replying to a tweet about Einhorn's lapsed lease, Musk said in the small hours of Wednesday that he'd send Einhorn "a box of short shorts to comfort him through this difficult time."

Sprint Corp. S, -0.82% shares gained 2.8% in premarket trade after the company reported first-quarter earnings early Wednesday, beating revenue and earnings expectations. Profit for the latest quarter fell to $173 million, or 4 cents a share, compared to $206 million, or 5 cents a share, a year ago. The FactSet consensus was that the company would break even in the first quarter. Revenue fell to $8.13 billion million from $8.16 billion a year ago, beating the FactSet consensus of $8.06 billion. The company had 57,000 wireless net additions, down from 61,000 a year ago. Service revenue was $5.74 billion compared to $6.07 billion a year ago. The stock has fallen 7.8% over the past year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.3%.

Bilibili Inc. BILI, -0.98% said Monday that its app had been temporarily removed by certain smartphone app stores in China, in accordance with a recent inspection of video platforms conducted by the Chinese government. Shares are down 3.9% in premarket trading. The Bilibili app has been removed from July 26 to Aug. 25, according to the company, which said in a release that it plans to quickly "implement the required measures" so its app can be reinstated. The current suspension doesn't affect users who have already downloaded Bilibili's app. Bilibili is a video-streaming and game platform in China. Shares were up 11% over the past three months, as of Friday's close, compared with a 6.5% rise for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% in that time.

The New Yorker will be publishing an article that includes sexual-misconduct allegations against CBS Corp. CBS, -1.96% Chief Executive Leslie Moonves, according to the Hollywood Reporter. The article, which The Hollywood Reporter said will run Friday, reportedly discusses allegations of instances of unwanted kissing and touching over two decades ago. This comes at a difficult time for Moonves, who is currently engaged in a contentious legal battle with Shari Redstone, the controlling shareholder of CBS and Viacom VIAB, +0.00% , over the future of the company. In November, CBS fired anchor Charlie Rose after the Washington Post reported that eight women had accused him of sexual misconduct. CBS shares have fallen 6% so far this year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.7%.

The Securities and Exchange Commission Thursday rejected a bid by Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss for the first-ever, bitcoin-related exchange-traded-fund. The SEC rejection marks another attempt by the duo to create the first bitcoin-pegged ETF that will pass muster with regulators. The news pushed the price of bitcoin [s:btcusd], the world's biggest digital currency lower, with a single coin last trading at $8,113.16, down 0.9% since 5 p.m. Wednesday on the Kraken Exchange. The SEC is yet to approve a digital-currency-related ETF citing concerns around liquidity and custody-the security and holding of the underlying digital asset. There remains at least two more proposals for a bitcoin ETF under review by the SEC, including one by Bitwise Asset Management and the joint proposal by VanEck and SolidX.

Mary Callahan Erdoes, CEO of J.P. Morgan's asset & wealth management unit, and one of the more prominent women on Wall Street, warned that financial advisers were standing in front of "a lot of never haves" in terms of macroeconomic conditions, citing the degree of quantitative easing and globalization, as well as the fact that there hasn't been a trade war in a half century. She also warned that a tapering or ending asset purchases by the European Central Bank could introduce a funding short-fall for public European companies. Speaking at CNBC's Delivering Alpha conference in New York on Wednesday she urged investors to be mindful of swings in currencies, including those of the U.S. dollar, which has been in a decided uptrend of late.

Shares of game-streaming platform Huya Inc. HUYA, +4.14% are up 4.7% in premarket trading Friday after the company said it signed a "strategic cooperation deal" with Tencent Games. Under the deal, the two entities "will promote deep cooperation in overseas game and live streaming," according to a release. Tencent is the second largest shareholder of Huya, which went public in May. The stock, which closed at $32.68 on Thursday, is trading significantly above its IPO price of $12. Shares of iQiyi Inc. IQ, +0.79% and Bilibili Inc. BILI, -0.98% two other Chinese streaming companies that recently went public, are up 4.2% and 2.7%, respectively, in premarket trading. Huya shares have gained 40% in the past month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has risen 1%.

U.S. stocks closed higher on Thursday, with major indexes shaking off an early decline as technology and financial stocks led a broad move higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% closed 0.4% higher, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% finished 0.6% up. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% registered the biggest gains out of the three majors, ending 0.8% higher. Technology stocks, the biggest sector in the U.S. by market capitalization, were among the biggest gainers of the day, up 1.1%. Among the most notable movers was Verizon VZ, -1.02% which rose 3.1%, and IBM Co. IBM, -0.20% up 1.9%. In other individual stocks, BJ's Wholesale Club Holdings Inc. BJ, -0.12% rallied 29.4% on its first public trading day after a seven-year hiatus.

Shares of Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% are up 0.7% in premarket trading after SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst Andrew Jeffrey raised his price target to $66 from $45 but kept his hold rating intact. Square's stock closed Wednesday near $60. "On one hand, the company has carved out an enviable growth niche, demonstrating an ability to monetize an ecosystem where others have not," Jeffrey wrote. "Conversely, barriers are low, in our view, evidenced by rapid growth of new solutions, like Clover," owned by First Data Corp. FDC, -0.12% Jeffrey is also concerned about Square's exposure to small- and medium-sized businesses, which he says "fare poorly in recessions." Square shares are up 147% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 11%.

Shares of Okta Inc. OKTA, -1.06% are up 2.2% in Wednesday trading after Needham analyst Alex Henderson upgraded the stock to buy from hold. He had downgraded the stock before its latest earnings report, due to his belief that the stock's valuation and investor expectations were too high, but he thinks the shares look attractive now after a recent pullback. "The moderated expectations help assuage the risk of not beating by enough, adding further upside potential to reported numbers," Henderson wrote. He also sees the company gaining momentum with enterprise customers, who may sign up for one Okta service and then expand to others. Okta's stock is down 12% so far this month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 0.7% in that time.

Dollar General Corp. DG, -0.63% shares rose 1.3% in Friday premarket trading after it was upgraded to strong buy from outperform at Raymond James, where analysts cited the company's 8% to 9% annual revenue growth potential. Analysts raised the price target to $115 from $100. Analysts led by Dan Wewer said revenue growth rates for large consumer packaged good companies are typically 2% to 3%. In addition, Dollar General is set to add 900 new location in 2019, announcing Thursday that it will add 7,000 jobs. Raymond James says new stores are an engine of growth for the company. Dollar General shares are up nearly 39% for the past year, outpacing the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% which is up 13% for the period. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/dollar-general-creating-7000-jobs-to-execute-growth-plan-2018-06-21

The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday approved the first implantable glucose monitoring system for diabetics, a product made by Senseonics Holdings Inc. SENS, -1.45% The system requires a small sensor to be surgically implanted in an outpatient procedure; the sensor uses light readings to relay blood-sugar levels to a mobile app for 90 days. "The FDA is committed to advancing novel products that leverage digital technology to improve patient care," FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb said in Thursday's announcement. "These technologies allow patients to gain better control over their health." Senseonic shares were halted ahead of the announcement and reopened less than a half-hour before the close, bounced between gains of 1% and 5% in heavy-volume trading into the close, when it was up 1.9%.

The U.S. Energy Information Administration reported Wednesday that crude supplies dropped by 5.9 million barrels for the week ended June 15. Analysts surveyed by S&P Global Platts had forecast a fall of 3.7 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute on Tuesday reported a decline of 3 million barrels, according to sources. Gasoline stockpiles, however, rose by 3.3 million barrels for the week, while distillate stockpiles climbed by 2.7 million barrels, according to the EIA. The S&P Global Platts survey forecast a supply fall of 1 million barrels for gasoline, and expected distillate stocks to be down by 700,000 barrels.. July crude cln8 rose 90 cents, or 1.4%, to $65.97 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up from $65.81 before the supply data.

A former CIA computer engineer was indicted for allegedly leaking classified government hacking tools that were posted on WikiLeaks, the Justice Department announced Monday night. Joshua Schulte, 29, was charged with 13 counts of illegally collecting and transmitting classified information. "As an employee of the CIA, Schulte took an oath to protect this country, but he blatantly endangered it," Assistant U.S. Attorney William F. Sweeney, Jr. said in a statement. Schulte was identified as a suspect in the breach last month after being charged separately with possessing child pornography. In 2017, WikiLeaks published over 8,000 pages of CIA documents describing how to break into computers, smartphones, messaging apps and TVs. It was described as one of the largest and worst damaging breaches in CIA history.

Instinet analyst Romit Shah raised his price target on Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% shares to $450 from $420 on Friday, citing his increased optimism about gross margins for the Model 3. "We believe Model 3 ASPs are coming in above forecast due to stronger-than-expected demand for all-wheel-drive and performance configurations," he wrote. "We now estimate blended Model 3 ASPs approaching $60,000 in 2H18." Shah also sees Tesla achieving more "cost leverage" as it ramps up production and reaches greater scale. "We believe that Tesla can lower per unit costs considerably in the coming months, driven by improved fixed cost absorption and higher labor efficiency," Shah said. Tesla shares are down 15% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Shares of semiconductor manufacturing company Marvell Technology Group Ltd. MRVL, -3.60% are up 2.2% in Thursday morning trading after Benchmark Research analyst Gary Mobley said that the U.S. deal with ZTE Corp. is a "positive" for the stock. "Within our coverage universe, the ZTE resolution should have the most favorable impact on Marvell ($28 million annual impact; est. for 3Q19 and 4Q19 may go up by $7 million for each quarter)," wrote Mobley, who covers a variety of semiconductor names. He sees likely benefits for MaxLinear Inc. MXL, +0.55% and Ceva Inc. CEVA, -0.34% as well. Marvell shares are up 28% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14% and the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has risen 28%.

Shares of Western Digital Corp. WDC, -2.00% are up 1.1% in Wednesday morning trading after Cowen & Co. analyst Karl Ackerman raised his price target on the stock to $105 from $100. Ackerman wrote that Western Digital looks well positioned in the June quarter, and he updated his estimates to account for buybacks during the quarter and "less draconian NAND ASP declines" for the calendar year. He also sees "improving bit growth and yields of 64L and 96L 3D NAND that should drive cost improvement of 25%" this calendar year. Ackerman has an outperform rating on shares, which are down 3.5% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13% and the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has risen 29%.

At its annual WWDC keynote on Monday, Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% announced new augmented-reality features for its next mobile operating system, iOS 12. The company said it was creating a new file format called USDZ that would support AR visuals. The company also showed off a measuring app that makes use of AR technology to map the dimensions of real-life objects, without the need for a measuring tape. Apple made upgrades to its ARKit platform as well, as the new ARKit will feature improved face tracking, 3D object detection, and multi-user AR. That will allow multiple users to play a game and interact with the same environment. Shares are up 1.4% in Monday trading, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% is up 0.7%.

Delta Air Lines Inc. DAL, -1.14% reported May load factor that declined from a year ago, as capacity growth outpaced the increase in traffic. Traffic rose 2.9% to 19.69 billion revenue passenger miles, with domestic traffic rising 3.7% and international traffic growing 1.7%. Capacity rose 3.5% to 22.83 billion available seat miles, as domestic seat supply grew 4.5% and international capacity increased 1.9%. Load factor declined to 86.3% from 86.7%, with domestic load factor falling to 86.7% from 87.4% and international load factor slipping to 85.5% from 85.7%. The stock rose 0.7% in premarket trade. It has tacked on 2.2% over the past three months, while the NYSE Arca Airline Index XAL, -1.22% has tumbled 9.9% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1.6%.

Deere & Co. DE, -1.99% raised its quarterly dividend by 15% on Wednesday, to 69 cents a share from 60 cents a share. The new dividend will be payable Aug. 1 to shareholders of record on June 29. Shares of the maker of equipment used in agriculture and construction industries rose 0.5% to $155.82 in morning trade. At that price, the new annual dividend rate implies a dividend yield of 1.77%, compared with the yield of 1.79% for the SPDR Industrial Select Sector ETF XLI, -0.88% and the implied yield for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% of 1.94%, according to FactSet. The stock has slipped 0.3% year to date, while the industrial ETF has lost 0.6% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1.6%.

Market research firm IDC said Wednesday that it expects the global smartphone market to contract again this year. The firm projects a 0.2% decline this year, which follows a 0.3% drop in 2017. IDC sees roughly 3% annual growth after that for the next few years. China was a major reason for the industry's decline last year and IDC projects that the smartphone market there will fall another 7.1% this year before flattening next year. The "biggest upside" in the Asia/Pacific region comes from India, which IDC sees posting 14% growth in 2018 and 16% growth in 2019. Though IDC projects an overall decline in the smartphone market this year, the firm expects that Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% will see iPhone volumes grow by 2.6%.

TransEnterix Inc. shares TRXC, +1.06% surged 12% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the company said it has won U.S. Food and Drug Administration approval for expanded indications for its Senhance Surgical System. Specifically, the company said the FDA has cleared the medical device company for laparoscopic inguinal hernia and laparoscopic cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) surgery. "There are approximately 760,000 inguinal hernia and 1.2 million laparoscopic cholecystectomy procedures performed annually in the U.S.," the company said. "With this clearance, Senhance System's total addressable annual procedures in the U.S. has more than doubled to over three million." Senhance is now approved for laparoscopic colorectal, gynecologic, inguinal hernia and cholecystectomy surgery. Shares have gained 566% in the last 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13%.

Financial stocks tumbled in premarket trade Tuesday, as part of a broad market selloff on worries that another Italian election could lead to the country leaving the shared currency. The SPDR Financial Select Sector ETF XLF, -1.17% dropped 1.5%, while futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average futures YMM8, +0.00% slumped 190 points. Among the financial ETF's most heavily weighted components, shares of J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% shed 1.3%, Bank of America Corp. BAC, -1.30% dropped 1.7%, Citigroup Inc. C, -2.39% fell 1.9%, Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, -0.67% slid 1.6% and Goldman Sachs Group Inc. GS, -1.78% gave up 1.3%. The financial ETF had lost 3.5% over the past three months through Friday, while the Dow DJIA, -0.77% had slipped 1.1%.

The U.S. stock market ended mostly lower on Thursday, as investors weighed the continuing trade dispute between the U.S. and China against the backdrop of strong corporate earnings and a healthy economic performance. The Nasdaq Composite, however, eked out modest gains, extending its winning streak to eight straight session, the longest since October. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% fell 4.12 points, or 0.1%, to 2,853.58, with energy, financials and industrials leading the losses. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% declined 74.45 points, or 0.3%, to 25,509.30. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% rose 3.46 points, or less than 0.1% to 7,891.78. Among the biggest decliners on the S&P 500, shares of Seagate Technology PLC. STX, -0.27% dropped more than 7% after Goldman Sachs analysts downgraded the stock.

U.S. Steel Corp. X, -0.96% shares ticked higher in the extended session Wednesday after the steelmaker topped Wall Street estimates for the quarter. U.S. Steel shares rose 1% after hours, following a 1.7% decline to close the regular session at $35.81. The company reported second-quarter net income of $214 million, or $1.20 a share, compared with $261 million, or $1.48 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were $1.46 a share. Revenue rose to $3.61 billion from $3.14 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated $1.13 a share on revenue of $3.46 billion. For the year, U.S. Steel estimated adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization of $1.85 billion to $1.9 billion. Analysts expect adjusted EBITDA of $1.82 billion for the year.

Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. CMG, -0.45% was upgraded to buy from hold at Jefferies on the restaurant chain's enhancements to handle digital and off-premise business. Jefferies raised its price target to $550 from $400. Analysts led by Andy Barish say they "have improved line of sight to mid-single digit same-store sales in '19/'20" highlighting things like delivery, marketing and operations. "With more predictable pricing and traffic-driven growth, we believe that restaurant-level margins can begin to expand back toward 20%+ levels," analysts wrote. Chipotle shares are down 3.7% in Tuesday trading after media reports of a store closure following food-related illness complaints in Ohio. Shares are up more than 55% for the year so far, outpacing the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% which is up 5.2% for the period.

Shopify Inc. SHOP, +1.90% shares rose 1.7% in Tuesday premarket trading after the cloud-based commerce platform reported second-quarter revenue that beat expectations. Shopify reported a net loss of $24.0 million, or 23 cents per share, after a loss of $9.4 million, or 15 cents per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was 2 cents per share. Revenue totaled $245.0 million, up from $151.7 million last year. The FactSet consensus was for a 3-cents-per-share loss and revenue of $235.0 million. Shopify expects third-quarter revenue in the range of $253.0 million to $257.0 million. The FactSet consensus is for third-quarter revenue of $253.2 million. Shopify shares have rallied 46.6% for 2018 so far, while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up nearly 5% for the period.

The largest exchange-traded fund to track social-media companies tumbled on Friday, dragged lower for a second straight session by a precipitous drop in Twitter shares, which tanked following disappointing quarterly results. The Global X Social Media ETF SOCL, -0.12% lost 4.5%, building on a 3.5% drop that came on Thursday. Twitter TWTR, +0.16% plunged 19% after giving a third-quarter outlook that was below forecasts. The disappointing results followed a similarly weak report from Facebook FB, -1.55% which suffered its biggest loss ever on Thursday. Facebook extended its decline on Friday, down 1.5%, while Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% was off 5.7%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% fell 0.4% while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was off 0.8% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% sank 1.7%.

The Chinese economy is at a "historic juncture" having to move from "high speed" growth to "high quality" growth, and how this shift is carried through will determine the country's development path for decades to come, the staff of the International Monetary Fund said in a report released Thursday. There are tensions in the government's strategy between, on the one hand, allowing market forces a decisive role and the pervasive role of the state, the report said. Relatively restrictive trade-and-investment regime in some areas and still unsustainable debt growth are other key challenges. To succeed, China must rein in credit growth, increase the role of market forces, and foster openness, the staff said. The risks are to the downside, including from the ongoing trade dispute with the U.S.

Shares of Expedia Group Inc. EXPE, -0.64% rallied 10% after the company reported second-quarter earnings that surpassed Wall Street expectations. Expedia said it earned $1 million, or a penny a share, in the quarter, compared with $57 million, or 36 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, Expedia earned $1.38 a share in the quarter, compared with 89 cents a year ago. Revenue rose 11% to $2.88 billion, from $2.58 billion a year ago. Excluding Trivago, which Expedia spun off in late 2016, the company posted adjusted earnings of $1.45 a share on sales of $2.71 billion. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of 89 cents a share on sales of $2.88 billion. Shares had ended the regular trading day down 1.4%.

Shares of Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% rose 0.5% late Thursday after the retailer reported fiscal third-quarter results that largely tracked Wall Street estimates. Starbucks said it earned $852.5 million, or 61 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $691.6 million, or 47 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, the company earned 62 cents a share, compared with 55 cents a share a year ago. Sales rose 11% to $6.31 billion, from $5.66 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected GAAP and adjusted earnings of 61 cents a share on sales of $6.26 billion. Starbucks said its global comparable-store sales increased 1%, the same growth that the analysts surveyed by FactSet expected. Shares ended the regular trading day down 0.3%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was trading near session lows in early morning trade as a decline in shares of financials buffeted the equity benchmark. The Dow DJIA, -0.77% was down 141 points, or 0.6%, at 25,057. Shares of American Express Co. AXP, -1.37% Travelers Cos. Inc. TRV, -0.53% and JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% were combining to produce a more than 60-point headwind for the price-weighted Dow. A $1 move in any one of the Dow's components equates to a roughly 6.8-point swing in the 122-year-old gauge. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% was off 0.5% at 2,802, with the financials sectors performing the worst on the day among the index's 11 sectors, while the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% traded 0.5% lower at 7,818.

The components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% that have reported earnings early Thursday, or late Wednesday, are accounting for nearly one-third of the Dow futures' YMU8, -0.36% 63-point loss. Shares of American Expres Co. AXP, -1.37% sank 3.2% in premarket trade, after the credit-card company beat earnings expectations but missed on revenue, which would shave about 21 points off the Dow's price. International Business Machines Corp.'s stock IBM, -0.20% rallied 2.4% premarket after earnings and revenue beat expectations, which would add about 25 points to the Dow. And Travelers Companies Inc.'s stock TRV, -0.53% dropped 2.7% after earnings missed big, but revenue beat, to be about a 24-point drag on the Dow. Combined, those three stock was cut the Dow's price by about 20 points.

Shares of J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. JBHT, -0.49% rallied 3.3% in premarket trade Monday, after the trucking company reported second-quarter earnings and revenue that beat expectations. Net income rose to $151.7 million, or $1.37 a share, from $97.9 million, or 88 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The FactSet consensus for earnings per share was $1.28. The effective tax rate declined to 26.0% from 37.4%. Revenue increased 24% to $2.14 billion from $1.73 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $2.06 billion, as revenue from all business segments topped expectations. The stock has climbed 33% over the past 12 months through Friday, while the Dow Jones Transportation Average DJT, -0.45% has gained 8.3% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has advanced 16%.

JetBlue Airways Corp. JBLU, -0.27% reported June load factor that rose 150 basis points (1.5 percentage points) to 87.0%, as a 7.8% rise in traffic outpaced a 5.9% increase in capacity. The air carrier raised its outlook for second-quarter per-gallon fuel costs to $2.28 to $2.30, compared with an estimate provided in April of $2.23, and the first-quarter realized fuel price of $2.09 a gallon. Separately, JetBlue affirmed its second-quarter outlook for revenue per available seat mile, to decline about 120 basis points, or to a range of down 2.5% to down 0.5%. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has dropped 13.7% year to date, while the NYSE Arca Airline Index XAL, -1.22% has lost 14.5% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

Roku Inc. said on Wednesday it is launching a marketplace for networks to deliver targeted advertising to its users. 21st Century FoxFOXA, -0.26% AT&T'sT, -0.71% WarnerMedia and Viacom Inc.VIAB, +0.00% have signed up to sell ads through Roku'sROKU, +1.27% "Audience Marketplace." According to Roku, networks will be able to use its user data to better target advertisements to specific customers. "Over-the-top distribution has been a key audience driver for Turner's portfolio of premium content," said Larry Allen, vice president of ad innovation and programmatic solutions at Turner, in a statement. "Participating in Roku's Audience Marketplace gives us access to rich insights and enhanced audience targeting capabilities." Roku shares are down 15% so far this year, and the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% is up 2%.

The Trump administration on Thursday released a proposal for the role of the government in housing finance, setting out a list of principles that are broadly similar to most consensus views on the topic, but which practically stand little chance of being enacted. The two government-sponsored mortgage enterprises, Fannie Mae FNMA, -0.63% and Freddie Mac FMCC, -1.10% would be reorganized as private entities, and would be able to issue mortgage bonds that have an explicit guarantee from the federal government, but which could only be used in catastrophic cases. Many housing industry participants believe some form of government guarantee is necessary to protect the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, and that the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage is, in turn, necessary to maintain the housing market and homeownership privileges Americans now enjoy.

Newell Brands Inc.'s stock NWL, -0.29% jumped 2.9% in premarket trade Monday, after the consumer goods company said it boosted its stock buyback program by $2.5 billion. That adds to the $1.1 billion remaining in its previously announced repurchase program. Based on Friday's stock closing price of $24.68, the new $3.6 billion program could allow the repurchase of about 145.9 million shares, which would be about 30% of the shares outstanding. The company, which brands include Paper Mate, Elmer's, Oster and Yankee Candle, said it continues to expects about $10 billion in proceeds from planned asset divestitures, which will be used to pay down debt and buy back stock. The shares had lost 20% year to date through Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 3.9%.

Shares of Israel-based Nano Dimension Ltd. NNDM, +0.99% rocketed 88% in premarket trade Monday, after the 3D printer maker said it has become a certified vendor for the U.S. Department of Defense. That means the company can do business directly with the U.S. government. Separately, the company said it sold a second DragonFly 2020 Pro 3D printer to a U.S.-based defense contractor. "Now, as a recognized U.S. government additive manufacturing supplier for defense projects, our DragonFly 2020 Pro 3D printer may play a crucial role in projects such as keeping risks down and solving complex design challenges, while speeding the R&D process up significantly," said Chief Executive Amit Dror. The stock had tumbled 57% year to date through Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% hs gained 3.9%.

Target Corp. TGT, +0.11% said Thursday that it is expanding its Shipt same-day delivery service and Drive Up online order pickup service across the Midwest and Southeast. Chicago will be the first city to have all four delivery and pickup options, which also includes Target Restock, which delivers essentials like laundry detergent and baby food the next day, and from-store delivery. By the end of June, Target will offer Shipt in 135 markets; Drive Up is now available in more than 600 stores in 20 states; Target Restock was expanded nationwide in May; and from-store delivery is available in 60 stores across five metro markets. Target shares are up 21.5% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 3.7% for the period.

The euro EURUSD, -0.3067% turned positive on Tuesday following reports that the European Central Bank would use its next policy meeting to discuss an exit from its quantitative easing program. Expectations for the ECB to normalize its monetary policy had waned in recent months as European economic data was sluggish and political developments in Italy took center stage. Market participants questioned whether the ECB could afford to halt bond buys if the economic recovery was slowing and Italy's government was euroskeptic. But following Tuesday's headlines, expectations for the central bank's actions perked up. The euro last bought $1.1719, up from $1.1699 late Monday in New York. Versus other rivals like the British pound EURGBP, -0.1455% or the Japanese yen EURJPY, -0.74% , however, the shared currency was weaker.

ADT Inc. ADT, +5.08% shares dropped in the extended session Wednesday after the home and business security company reported an unexpected loss on the quarter. ADT shares fell 6% after hours, following a 3.6% rise to close the regular session at $9.48. The company reported a second-quarter loss of $67 million, or 9 cents a share, compared with a loss of $93 million, or 14 cents a share, in the year-ago period. The adjusted loss was 7 cents a share. Revenue rose to $1.13 billion from $1.07 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated adjusted earnings of 10 cents a share on revenue of $1.13 billion. For the year, ADT estimates revenue of $4.5 billion to $4.55 billion, while analysts expect revenue of $4.52 billion.

MGM Resorts International MGM, -0.86% shares fell 5% Thursday in pre-market trade after the company reported second-quarter earnings that fell short of profit and revenue expectations. Profit for the latest quarter fell to $123.8 million, or 21 cents, compared to $209.9 million, or 36 cents a year ago. The FactSet consensus was earnings per share of 29 cents. Revenue rose to $2.86 billion from $2.65 billion a year ago, but fell short of the FactSet consensus of $2.97 billion. Casino revenue for the second quarter increased by 8% to $1.3 billion compared to the prior year, but occupancy at the company resorts dipped slightly to 93% from 94% a year ago. The stock has fallen 14.6% over the past year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has risen 5.2%.

Shares of Criteo SA CRTO, -3.77% are down 13% in premarket trading after the company reported better-than-expected earnings but delivered a downbeat revenue forecast. The ad-tech company reported net income of $15 million, or 20 cents a share, up from $8 million, or 9 cents, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted EPS rose to 53 cents from 39 cents a year ago and came in ahead of expectations for 39 cents. Revenue fell to $537 million from $542 million, whereas analysts had been expecting $555 million. For the third quarter, Criteo expects revenue net of traffic-acquisition costs of $218 million to $223 million. Analysts were projecting $244 million. The stock was up 23% so far this year, as of Tuesday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.3%.

Walt Disney Co. and 21st Century Fox shareholders have approved Disney's DIS, -1.30% $71.3 billion acquisition of Fox's FOXA, -0.26% entertainment assets. With the deal, Disney will acquire the Twentieth Century Fox TV and film studios, cable networks including FX and National Geographic Channel, Star India, a 39% stake in Sky PLC SKY, -0.10% and majority control of streaming service Hulu. Disney and telecommunications giant Comcast CMCSA, -1.16% were engaged in a months-long bidding war for the Fox assets, but Comcast dropped its pursuit last week, saying it would turn its attention to acquiring the majority stake in Sky. Fox shares have shot up 31.2% so far this year, while Disney shares have gained 5.2% and Comcast shares have dropped 11.7%. The S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 6%.

Exchange-traded funds tracking the biotechnology sector rallied on Tuesday, supported by stronger-than-expected quarterly results from a pair of major components. The iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF IBB, -0.55% gained 1.4%, climbing to its highest level since September 2015, while the SPDR S&P Biotech ETF XBI, -0.31% was up 0.6%, trading near record levels. The gains came after strong results from both Biogen Inc. BIIB, -1.12% and Eli Lilly & Co. LLY, +0.06% Biogen shares jumped 5% while Lilly was up 2%. Thus far this year, the iShares ETF has gained more than 12% while the SPDR fund is up 18.3%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% rose 0.8% on Tuesday while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was up 0.8% and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% was up 1%.

Shares of MoviePass parent company Helios and Matheson Analytics Inc.HMNY, -19.87% dropped more than 9% in after-hours trade Tuesday after the company announced it had initiated a public offering to sell shares of its common stock, as well as warrants to purchase shares of its common stock. This comes after the company filed a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on July 2 to raise $1.2 billion over three years. Helios and Matheson's statement didn't provide exact details about the planned sale, including when it would be completed. The company said it may use the net proceeds for "general corporate purposes" and "transaction expenses." Shares of Helios and Matheson have fallen 97% so far this year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has risen 4.5%.

Financial stocks pared some losses in premarket trade Friday, after the the June jobs data showed that nonfarm payrolls increased by more than expected, although the unemployment rate increased. The SPDR Financial Select Sector ETF XLF, -1.17% was unchanged, after being down 0.5% just before the jobs data was released. Shares of J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% swung to a gain of 0.1%, after being down 0.4% pre-data. Among other more-active bank stocks, Bank of America Corp.'s BAC, -1.30% slipped 0.1%, paring pre-data losses of 0.3%, while Wells Fargo & Co. shares WFC, -0.67% eased 0.1%, compared with a pre-data loss of 0.3%. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average YMU8, -0.34% swung to a gain of 30 points, compared with a pre-data loss of 81 points.

Shares of AT&T Inc. T, -0.71% are up 1.1% in Wednesday trading after Morgan Stanley analyst Simon Flannery resumed coverage of the stock with an overweight rating and $37 price target. He wrote that while there is "significant uncertainty" about how the company's various efforts will play out, the stock's valuation seems to reflect those already. "We retain some of our longer term concerns around the sector and stock, but believe that over the next 12 months, the path of least resistance for AT&T's stock is to trade higher," Flannery wrote. He will be watching for the company's ability to reduce leverage and realize synergies from its Time Warner deal. AT&T shares are down 16% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13%.

Shares in Intel Corp. INTC, -2.57% are up 2.4% in premarket trading Thursday after the company said its chief executive officer Brian Krzanich has resigned after violating the company's "non-fraternization policy." Intel said it recently became informed that Krzanich had a "past consensual relationship with an Intel employee" but investigations by internal and external counsel showed that he violated the policy, which applies to Intel managers. "Given the expectation that all employees will respect Intel's values and adhere to the company's code of conduct, the Board has accepted Mr. Krzanich's resignation," the company said in a release. Chief Financial Officer Bob Swan will serve as Intel's interim CEO effective immediately. Intel's stock is up 55% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

PayPal Holdings Inc. PYPL, -0.18% shares are up 0.3% in premarket trading Wednesday after Wedbush analyst Moshe Katri said that the company's recently announced acquisition of Hyperwallet had strategic benefits. The purchase "strengthens its merchant-facing platform," Katri wrote of PayPal. "Combined with recently acquired iZettle, it also enhances the company's ongoing monetization effort." He wrote that the two deals help place PayPal "on par competitively" with Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% and Adyen NV ADYEN, -0.18% PayPal said Tuesday that it would be acquiring Hyperwallet, a payouts platform, for $400 million. Hyperwallet enables companies like Expedia to pay gig-economy sellers who, say, make their homes available to guests via a home-sharing platform. PayPal shares are up 61% in the past year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13%.

Shares of cloud-based security company Zscaler Inc. ZS, -0.26% are up more than 15% in premarket trading after the company reported better-than-expected results and analysts hiked their price targets. "Impressively, Zscaler achieved 81% non-GAAP [gross margin] vs. consensus 80% given its purpose-built platform and high degrees of automation," wrote Credit Suisse analyst Brad Zelnick, who raised his price target to $38 from $33. "This is unique for a company of this scale." Needham's Alex Henderson upped his target to $40 from $35, writing: "We continue to believe Zscaler is a unique company positioned to disrupt a major sector and in the early stages of its emergence." Shares of Zscaler were up 11% over the past month, as of Wednesday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 3.7%.

Shares of Boeing Co. BA, -1.25% shot up 2.6% in midday trade Wednesday, to pace the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% gainers, and to put them on track for the first record close in over three months. The aerospace and defense contractor's stock-price gain of $9.36 was adding about 64 points to the Dow, which was up 229 points. Analyst Harry Breach at Raymond James said he believes the joint venture in auxiliary power units announced by Boeing and Safran SA SAFRY, -2.62%earlier this week is a "significant move," although it could take decades to have its full impact. Boeing shares' last record close was $264.64 on Feb. 27. They have now nearly doubled (up 98%) over the past 12 months, while the Dow has climbed 18.4%.

Merck & Co. Inc. MRK, +0.11% said Monday its Keytruda drug showed positive results in a late-stage trial as a treatment for advanced melanoma. The company said a new analysis of four-year data for Keytruda from a Phase 3 study showed that 86% of patients were progression-free 20 months after completing two years of Keytruda. Five-year data from a Phase 1 trial showed the overall survival rate was higher than 40% in treatment-naive metastatic melanoma patients, the longest follow-up for the drug so far. Melanoma is one of the most common types of cancer diagnosed in the U.S. and is behind most skin cancer deaths. Merck shares rose 1% in premarket trade, and are up 7.6% in 2018 so far, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.3%.

Palo Alto Networks Inc. PANW, -0.23% shares ticked higher Friday after the cybersecurity company named a new chairman and chief executive and forecast revenue that topped Wall Street estimates. Palo Alto Network shares rose 2.4% after hours, following a 0.5% rise to close at $209.19 in Friday's regular session. The company said that Nikesh Arora, a former C-level executive at SoftBank 9984, -0.49% and Alphabet Inc.'s GOOG, -0.92%GOOGL, -0.95% Google, will start as chairman and chief executive of Palo Alto Networks beginning June 6. Arora succeeds Mark McLaughlin, who will become vice chairman. The company, which reports earnings on Monday, said it expects third-quarter revenue of $567.1 million, and billings of $721 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast revenue of $546.1 million and billings of $668.8 million.

Shares of Zuora Inc. ZUO, +0.82% are up 12% in Friday trading after the company, which sells software that helps businesses transition to subscription models, reported a strong quarter. It was the company's first earnings report since its IPO. "Our biggest impression from the call was deal flow suggests accelerating demand and accelerating organic revenue growth throughout the company with similar sales execution," wrote Needham analyst Scott Berg, who rates the stock a buy. "Net dollar retention rates (112%) continue to increase, which we view as signs of more up-selling and improvement in gross retention rates." Berg raised his price target to $27 from $24. Shares are currently trading near $25. The stock is up 29% over the past month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.8%.

Shares of Netflix Inc. NFLX, -1.00% sank 11% in morning trade on heavy volume, after the streaming video service reported disappointing second-quarter results, to pace its peers and and the broader market in losses. With 12 million shares traded in the first half hour after the open, which was already more than the full-day average of 11.6 million shares, the stock was the most actively traded on the Nasdaq exchange. The percentage decline would be the biggest in two years, since the company reported second-quarter results in July 2016. The stock was also the biggest decliner among components of the SPDR Consumer Discretionary Select Sector ETF XLY, -0.84% the Nasdaq 100 Index NDX, -0.79% and the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% The next biggest decliner in the Nasdaq 100 was Dish Network Corp. shares DISH, -3.88% down just 1.7%, while the next biggest decliner in both the consumer discretionary ETF and the S&P 500 was Omnicom Group Inc.'s stock OMC, -0.12% which fell 6.3%.

Twitter Inc. TWTR, +0.16% said Wednesday it is removing 'locked' accounts from its platform as part of a broader effort to build trust with users. In a blog post, Vijaya Gadde, legal, policy and trust and safety lead, said the company regularly reaches out to account owners when it detects sudden changes in behavior. The company then locks the account if the owner fails to validate it and change their password. Most of the activity will take place in the next few days and is likely to mean a change of four followers or fewer for most account holders. "Follower counts are a visible feature, and we want everyone to have confidence that the numbers are meaningful and accurate," said Gadde. The move is not expected to affect Twitter's monthly active user or daily active user metrics, two key measurements of the business. Shares were up 0.5% on Wednesday, and have gained 83.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

Tintri Inc. tntr said Tuesday it filed for bankruptcy, just a little over a year after the flash storage company went public. The company said it will keep operating its businesses as a "debtor-in-possession" under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the District of Delaware. Tintri said it has entered into a non-binding letter of intent with DataDirect Networks for the purchase of substantially all of its assets. Tintri has also arranged for financing, which is intended to bridge the company to the deal with DataDirect, under funds available under a debtor-in-possession credit facility with TriplePoint Capital LLC. Trintri's stock was up 9.1% to 20 cents in afternoon trade. The company went public on June 30, 2017 at an initial public offering price of $7. In March, the company announced that both its chief executive and chief financial officer were leaving the company. Tintri's stock has plunged 90% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.1%.

Shares of Nike Inc. NKE, -0.65% soared 9.2% toward a record high in premarket trade Friday, after the athletic apparel and accessories company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that beat expectations and announced a $15 billion share buyback program. The stock's early price gain would add about 45 points to the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% and Dow futures YMU8, -0.34% were up 76 points ahead of the open. No less than 16 of 35 analysts surveyed by FactSet have increased their stock price targets Friday, lifting the average target to $79.33, compared with an average of $71.73 at the end of May. Susquehanna analyst Sam Poser raised his target to $78 from $64, citing better-than-anticipated revenue and margins in all geographies and most merchadise categories. The stock is currently trading well above the June 15 record close of $75.84 and the June 7 intraday record of $75.91. The stock has rallied 15% year to date through Thursday, while the Dow has slipped 2%.

Micron Technology Inc. MU, -1.70% shares are down 0.6% in Monday morning trading, despite a wave of positive sentiment from analysts. Cowen & Co. analyst Karl Ackerman wrote that while the company's pre-announcement of its May quarter results "leaves little to the imagination," there's still opportunity for "a few pennies of upside" given positive momentum in average selling prices during the month of May. J.P. Morgan analyst Harlan Sur also advised bullishness on Micron ahead of the company's earnings report, due out Wednesday afternoon. "We see further upside in MU shares as the team is executing well in an overall constructive S/D memory environment," Sur wrote, referring to supply and demand. "We continue to believe memory suppliers are focused on profitability and not market share and any near-term supply/demand imbalance would likely be quickly mitigated." Micron's stock is up 94% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14% and the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has risen 33%.

Shares of General Electric Co. GE, -1.31% slumped 1.5% toward a two-month low, after Fitch Ratings downgrade the industrial conglomerate's credit rating, and warned that further downgrades may be coming. The stock was headed for a third-straight loss, and has shed 4.8% during that streak. Fitch lowered its rating one notch to A, which is just five notches above "junk" status, from A+. The rating outlook is negative. "The downgrade of GE's ratings incorporates Fitch's expectation that the company's cash flow and earnings will continue to be constrained while it addresses underperformance in the power business, evaluates its business portfolio and carries out extensive restructuring actions to reduce its cost structure," Fitch said in a statement. Standard & Poor's also rates GE's credit at A, while Moody's Investors Service rates it at A2. GE's stock has tumbled 24% year to date, while the SPDR Industrial Select Sector ETF XLI, -0.88% has slipped 0.8% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 1.5%.

Shares of Weight Watches International Inc. WTW, -2.98% soared 6.2% to a record high Tuesday, after a bullish call from J.P. Morgan, which said it was time to "stop watching from the sidelines." Analysts started coverage of the stock with an overweight rating and price target of $105, which is 14% above current levels. "Following three years of double-digit revenue and earnings pressure through 2015, management stabilized the trajectory, repositioning the company for outsized growth by revamping its points program, significantly improving the mobile platform, and recruiting pivotal social media influencers," J.P. Morgan analysts wrote in a note to clients. The company had announced in October 2015 that Oprah Winfrey bought a 10% equity stake. Although the stock has already performed "extremely well" this year--it's up 108% year to date while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.2%--J.P. Morgan still sees more upside driven by positive earnings revisions and multiple expansion, "as investors gain comfort around the sustainability of [Weight Watchers's] growth story."

Shares of CRISPR Therapeutics AG CRSP, -1.75% tumbled 12% in active midday trade Monday, after a STAT report that edited cells might cause cancer. Volume spiked to 3.1 million shares, already nearly double the full-day average of about 1.7 million shares. CRISPR Therapeutics is a gene editing company that develops treatments for serious diseases using its proprietary CRISPR/Cas9 platform, which allow precise and directed changes to genomic DNA. The STAT report said that in studies published in Nature Medicine, scientists found that cells in which genomes were edited by CRISPR-Cas9 had the potential to seed tumors inside a patient. CRISPR was not immediately available for comment. The stock, which went public in October 2016 at an initial public offering price of $14, closed at a record $73.59 on May 30. It has rocketed 156% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.3%. Separately, shares of Intellia Therapeutics Inc. NTLA, +0.65% also a genome-editing company using the CRISPR/Cas9 system, dropped 8.2%.

Vical Inc. VICL, -0.74% said Monday a phase 2 trial of its treatment for genital herpes failed to meet its primary endpoint of annualized lesion recurrence rate. The stock was still inactive in premarket trade. In a study of 261 healthy adults with herpes simplex virus type 2, aged 18 to 50, with a self-reported history of 4 to 9 recurrences a year, Vical said the annualized recurrence rate in the placebo group was "far less" than what was expected, meaning there was "significantly less power" to show a vaccine effect in the trial. "We are extremely disappointed with the outcome and based upon these results, we will be terminating the HSV-2 program," said Chief Executive Vijay Samant. Vical said it will remain focused on antifungal VL-2397, which is in a phase 2 trial. The stock had tumbled 30.3% over the past 12 months, while the iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF IBB, -0.55% has gained 12.3% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has climbed 14.3%.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average was attempting to turn higher and extend a multiday string of victories to a third day on Friday, with gains in shares of McDonald's Corp. MCD, -0.39% and Procter & Gamble Co. PG, +0.04% lifting the the blue-chip benchmark. The Dow was trading near break-even territory in late-morning action, up less than 0.1% at 25,250, but the levels represented a paring of an opening slump of more than 75 points at session lows, according to FactSet data. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% also was trimming its earlier decline to trade flat at 2,769, as was the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% at 7,625, most recently. Tensions around global trade, amid a gathering of seven prominent developed economies, including the U.S. and those in Europe, known as the G-7, was sparking unease in the early session, as investors express anxieties about President Donald Trump's protectionist policies and the potential impact of tariff clashes on the domestic and global economies.

LyondellBasel Industries NV LYB, -0.71% said Friday its shareholders have approved a new program to buy back up to 10% of the plastics and chemicals company's outstanding shares over the next 18 months. Based on Thursday's stock closing price of $112.12, and 392.1 million shares outstanding as of April 24, the buyback could be valued at $4.4 billion. Separately, shareholders approved the plan to transition to a unitary board of directors from a dual board structure, and the company declared a regular quarterly dividend of $1.00 a share, to be payable Jun 18 to shareholders of record on June 11. The current dividend rate implies a dividend yield of 3.57% at Thursday's stock closing price, compared with the yield on the SPDR Materials Select Sector ETF XLB, -1.44% of 1.84%. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has gained 3.7% over the past three months, while the materials ETF has lost 1.4% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has tacked on 1.0%.

Walmart Inc. WMT, +1.31% said Wednesday that it has launched a higher-education program in partnership with Guild Education that will offer the retailer's workers associate's and bachelor's degrees in business or supply chain management. Degrees will be offered through the University of Florida, Brandman University and Bellevue University. Walmart estimates the contribution from their workers at the equivalent of $1 per day. The retailer will subsidize the cost of tuition, books and fees. Charlie O'Shea, Moody's lead retail analysts, calls the program one more way that Walmart is investing in its employees. "In combination with increased pay, training, and improved career opportunities, Walmart is recognizing the positive impact across the board of a stable workforce, and increases the pressure on other companies inside and outside of retail as this heats up the competition for quality employees," he wrote. Walmart shares are down nearly 15% for the year to date while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% is up nearly 2% for the period.

Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% Model 3 earned a recommendation from Consumer Reports after the magazine's testers found that an over-the-air update from Tesla improved the mass-market sedan's braking distances, the magazine said Wednesday. Braking distances had been one of the sticking points for Consumer Reports in not bestowing the Model 3 its recommendation last week. Tesla had said it would be able to make adjustments with over-the-air updates, and it did so within days. The improved braking distances raised the Model 3's overall score enough to earn the recommendation, Consumer Reports said. The magazine has other concerns about the sedan, such as wind noise and uncomfortable rear seats, that Tesla Chief Executive Elon Musk has said already have been addressed, so Consumer Reports is renting another Model 3 from Tesla to see if the changes made a difference and will update its review, the magazine said. Tesla shares have lost 6.5% this year, versus a 1.8% gain for the S&P 500 index. SPX, -0.71%

Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% on Friday announced several executive hires, including a new vice president of engineering and a chief financial officer for its China business. Stuart Bowers, the engineering VP, joined from Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% and is responsible for Tesla's software and hardware engineering, Tesla said in a blog post. Neeraj Manrao, previously at Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% has joined as director of energy manufacturing. Kevin Mukai has been named director of production engineering for Tesla's Nevada battery factory. James Zhou is Tesla's new CFO for China. The hiring spree comes after a few high-profile executives left Tesla in recent weeks. Tesla shares were poised to end the week 0.1% higher, compared with a 0.2% advance for the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% "We're excited to welcome a group of such talented people as we continue to ramp Model 3 and accelerate towards a more sustainable future. We'll be announcing more hires in the coming days, so stay tuned," the company said.

The Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% board of directors plans to meet with advisers next week to make formal the process of exploring Chief Executive Elon Musk's proposal to take the company private, according to a CNBC report that cited people familiar with the matter. The board is likely to ask Musk to recuse himself, and the board told him that he'd need his own set of advisers, the report said. Musk earlier this week stunned markets by tweeting and later on expanding on an email to employees that he was considering taking Tesla private at $420 a share. Wall Street has decried the lack of details around the plan, and shares ended Thursday down 4.8%.

CenturyLink Inc. CTL, +1.96% shares advanced more than 4% in the extended session Wednesday after the telecommunications company reported earnings above expectations and raised its 2018 guidance. CenturyLink said it earned $292 million, or 27 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $69 million, or 6 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue fell to $5.90 billion, compared with $6.04 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 18 cents a share on sales of $5.92 billion. CenturyLink also raised its outlook for the year, predicting adjusted profits between $9 billion and $9.15 billion for 2018, compared with a previous outlook of profit between $8.75 billion and $8.95 billion.

Shares of Caterpillar Inc. CAT, -1.88% rallied 2.4% in afternoon trade Tuesday, which puts them at the top of the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% gainers list. The machinery maker's stock has now gained 3.5% amid a three-session winning streak. The price gain on Tuesday was adding about 23 points to the Dow, which was up 158 points with 22 of 30 components gaining ground. During the win streak, the price gain has Caterpillar's stock has now edged up 0.2% since the company reported before the market opened on July 30 second-quarter earnings that beat expectations. Still, the stock has lost 4.7% over the past three months, while the Dow has tacked on 5.4%.

U.S. stock-market indexes opened higher on Wednesday as upbeat results from Apple Inc and strong labor-market data supported positive sentiment. Companies in the private sector added 219,000 new employees to their payrolls in July. Still, gains were limited as investors continued to grapple with uncertainty surrounding tariff disputes. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was 5 points, or 0.2%, higher to 2,820. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% opened 7 points, or less than 0.1%, higher to 25,420. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% advanced 30 points, or, 0.4%, to 7,701 at the open. Among the biggest gainers on the S&P 500, shares of Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% rallied 4% after the company's upbeat earnings.

Kroger Co. KR, +1.07% said Wednesday that it has launched Ship, a direct-to-consumer e-commerce platform, in four markets: Cincinnati, Houston, Louisville and Nashville. Additional markets will offer the service in the coming months. To start, Kroger Ship will offer 4,500 products from the Our Brands line and more than 50,000 other grocery and household items. Orders over $35 will be shipped for free, otherwise there's a $4.99 shipping charge that will be applied after the launch phase. There is also a 15% off coupon available for one-time use in the initial phase. Kroger shares are up 5.7% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 5.3% for the period.

The American Petroleum Institute reported Tuesday that U.S. crude supplies rose by 629,000 barrels for the week ended July 13, according to sources. The API data also showed supplies of gasoline also climbed by 425,000 barrels, while distillate stockpiles added 1.7 million barrels, sources said. Supply data from the Energy Information Administration will be released Wednesday. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts expect the EIA to report a fall of 3 million barrels in crude supplies. They also forecast supply declines of 1 million barrels for gasoline, and 45,000 barrels for distillates. August crude clq8 was at $67.63 a barrel in electronic trading, down from the contractâ€™s $68.08 settlement on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Goldman Sachs GS, -1.78% is planning to name President David Solomon to succeed Lloyd Blankfein as chief executive officer as early as this week, the New York Times reported late Sunday, citing unnamed sources. People had widely expected Solomon to be tapped for the powerful post since his appointment as the investment bank's president in March, the newspaper said. However, the official announcement of his promotion had not been expected until later this year, the report said. Goldman Sachs is scheduled to report second-quarter earnings on Tuesday. The bank's stock fell 0.4% to close at $226.41 on Friday and is down 11% for the year, underperforming the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% which is up 4.8%.

J.C. Penney Co. Inc. JCP, -0.41% said Thursday that it has revamped the Arizona brand, the company's biggest private label, in time for the back-to-school selling season. The department store retailer said it gathered feedback from teen focus groups and used the information for its denim, redesigned the store presentation, partnered with teen influencers Brooklyn and Bailey McKnight, and launched new social media channels to reach teens. One out of three J.C. Penney customers makes a purchase from the Arizona line, according to Jodie Johnson, the company's head of merchandising. J.C. Penney shares are down nearly 25% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 4.4% for the period.

Shares of L Brands Inc. LB, -0.86% fell 2.6% in premarket trade, after the Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works parent reported June same-stores sales rose 3% from a year ago, after a 5% increase in May. Total sales for the five weeks ended July 7 increased 6% to $1.28 billion, after a 10% increase to $851.9 million in May. The FactSet consensus for the fiscal second-quarter, which ends in July, is for same-store sales growth of 2.5% and total sales of $2.92 billion. The stock has tumbled 39% year to date through Wednesday, while the SPDR S&P Retail ETF XRT, +0.06% has climbed 8.8% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

Fastenal Co. shares FAST, +0.35% rose 4.6% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the wholesale distributor of industrial and construction supplies beat earnings estimates for the second quarter. The company said it had net income of $211.2 million, or 74 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $148.9 million, or 52 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Salres rose to $1.268 billion from $1.122 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of 66 cents and sales of $1.257 billion. The company said it signed 5,537 industrial vending devices in the quarter, up 13.4% from the year-earlier period. Shares are down 9.4% in 2018 through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.5%.

Electronic Arts Inc. EA, +2.74% said late Monday that it had acquired Industrial Toys, a Pasadena, Calif.-based game maker that is responsible for "Midnight Star." Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The acquisition includes hiring Industrial Toys boss Alex Seropian, who is a former Walt Disney Co. DIS, -1.30% executive and founder and former chief executive of Bungie Studios. After Bungie was acquired by Microsoft Corp. MSFT, -0.61% Seropian and Bungie launched the popular videogame "Halo" for Microsoft's Xbox. EA stock was flat in after hours trading and closed down 0.3% to $144.64 during the regular session. EA shares have climbed 38% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.1%.

Shares of Arista Networks Inc. ANET, -0.18% are up 2% in premarket trading after Piper Jaffray analyst Andrew Nowinski upgraded the stock to overweight from neutral. He is more upbeat about Arista's prospects now that the company has received "favorable rulings" related to litigation issues, which he thinks "should no longer delay deals and should drive better growth & free cash flow." Nowinski also sees potential in the company's campus-switching efforts, as Cisco Systems Inc. CSCO, +0.00% struggles, and he expects that routing will remain a growth opportunity. He raised his price target to $315 from $268. Arista shares are up 11% so far this year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.2%.

BJ's Wholesale Club Holdings Inc.'s BJ, -0.12% credit was upgraded to B1 from B3 at Moody's after the company used the proceeds from its "successful" IPO to repay a $625 million second lien term loan. BJ's began trading on June 28, with shares surging 23%. ""he prior rating was hamstrung by high leverage emanating from the aggressive sponsor-driven financial policy, which this significant repayment largely alleviates," wrote Charlie O'Shea, Moody's vice president. "BJ's operating performance continues its steady favorable trend, which we expect to continue." BJ's shares are down 0.8% in Friday trading and down 0.3% for the month to date. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 1.6% for the month so far.

The Securities and Exchange Commission and a parallel criminal action has been brought against Sudhakar Reddy Bonthu, a former Equifax EFX, -0.03% software engineering manager, for allegedly trading on inside information of the company's data breach. That's the second insider-trading case on the Equifax breach the SEC has brought. According to the complaint, Bonthu violated company policy when he traded on the non-public information by purchasing Equifax put options. Less than a week later, after Equifax publicly announced the data breach and its stock declined nearly 14%, Bonthu sold the put options and netted more than $75,000, the SEC said. He was terminated by Equifax in March after not cooperating with the company's internal investigation.

Shares of Chinese streaming company iQiyi Inc. IQ, +0.79% are down 8.7% in Friday morning trading, extending their recent slide. The stock fell more than 12% in Thursday's session, marking its biggest single-day percentage drop on record. If the current losses hold, Friday's decline would constitute the stock's second-worst single-day performance. IQiyi was spun out of Baidu Corp. BIDU, +0.10% through an initial public offering in March. Shares of Huya Inc. HUYA, +4.14% another Chinese internet name that recently held an IPO, are down more than 7% in Friday's session. Despite losses Thursday and Friday, iQiyi's stock is up 57% over the past month, compared with a 1.3% rise for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71%

Cascend Securities analyst Eric Ross wrote Friday that Apple Inc.'s AAPL, -0.30% iPhone supply chain was "healthy and growing again." He said that it's too early in the iPhone production cycle for the supply chain to be fully ramped ahead of the new iPhone launch, but suppliers are "starting to build select parts." Ross wrote that some of the increased activity could also be due to a "slight restocking of iPhone X driven by better than expected sell-through." Ross rates Apple's stock a buy, and he has a $220 price target on the stock. Apple shares are up 27% over the past 12 months, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 14%.

AT&T Inc. T, -0.71% is in talks to buy digital ad firm AppNexus, which would likely signal the company's plans to challenge advertising titans Alphabet Inc. GOOGL, -0.95%GOOG, -0.92% and Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% Cheddar reported late Tuesday. AppNexus is privately held and has raised an estimated $344 million, according to FactSet. AppNexus operates a large advertising exchange, which handles programmatic online ads. Citing an anonymous source, Cheddar reported that AppNexus would not sell itself for less than $2 billion. AT&T stock is flat after hours, and closed up 0.6% to $32.39 during the regular session. AT&T stock has lost 17% this year as the benchmark S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.3%.

Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% said Tuesday that it has a new "Instagram-worthy" addition to its menu: Mango Dragonfruit Starbucks Refreshers. The magenta beverage is hand-shaken, can be customized with coconut milk and contains no artificial colors and sweeteners. It joins other Refreshers, including Very Berry Hibiscus and Strawberry Acai. Mango Dragonfruit is available in the U.S. and Canada. Starbucks is encouraging customers to photograph and post pics of their orders on social media with the hashtag #AfternoonMade, part of the company's push for afternoon sales. Starbucks shares are down 1.2% in Tuesday premarket trading and down 6% for the past year. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 13.1% for the last 12 months.

U.S. stock-market indexes closed mostly higher on Thursday, as the European Central Bank announced that it plans to end its bond-buying program at the end of the year but pledged to keep rates at present levels until at least next summer. Stronger-than-expected economic data also lent support to stocks. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% closed at a record thanks to a rally in technology shares. The index gained 65.34 points, or 0.9%, to 7,761.04. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 6.86 points, or 0.3%, to 2,782.49. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% lost 25.89 points, or 0.1%, to 25,175.31. Among the biggest gainers on the S&P 500, Twitter Inc. TWTR, +0.16% soared 6.1%.

Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% has data-sharing agreements with at least four Chinese tech companies -- including Huawei, which U.S. intelligence agencies has cited as a national security threat, the New York Times reported late Tuesday. The deals allowed Huawei, Lenovo 0992, +1.59% Oppo and TCL 000100, -0.35% to access detailed information about device users and their friends, the Times said. The agreements date back to 2010, but Facebook told the Times that it may end its Huawei deal this week. U.S. intelligence agencies have warned that Huawei has close ties with the Chinese government. On Monday, the Times reported that Facebook had data-sharing deals with more than 60 companies, including Apple Inc. and Amazon.com Inc.

Shares of Brazil-based oil and gas giant Petroleo Brasileiro S/A PBR, -3.51% known as Petrobras, tumbled 8.3% toward a 4 1/2-month low in active morning trade Tuesday, after the Brazilian government agreed to a discount on diesel fuel prices as part of a deal to end a truckers strike. Volume in Petrobras jumped to 23.4 million shares, already above the full-day average of 22.6 million shares, and enough to make the stock the NYSE's most actively traded. After closing at a 3 1/2-year high on May 16, the stock had plunged 26% over the past seven sessions. Also weighing on Petrobras shares is the 5.3% drop in crude oil pricescln8 the past two sessions.

U.S. stocks closed mostly lower on Friday, largely due to a selloff in energy shares. The S&P 500 energy sectors slumped 2.6%, weighing on the broader index. But all three main benchmarks posted weekly gains. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% closed 58.67 points, or 0.2%, lower at 24,753.09, but posted a 0.2% weekly gain. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% fell 6.43 points, or 0.2% to 2,721.33 but ended the week 0.3% higher. Meanwhile the Nasdaq Composite COMP, -0.67% advanced 9.42 points, or 0.1% to 7,433.85 and gained 1.1% over the week. Among the worst performers on the S&P 500, Gap Inc. GPS, +0.48% shares fell 15% as the retailer reported disappointing earnings.

The U.S. Postal Service reported a third-quarter loss of $1.49 billion, but that was narrower than the $2.14 billion it lost in the same period a year ago, as the mail carrier continued to push for Congressional reform to make it more competitive. The controllable loss, which excludes non-recurring and items outside of management control, such as workers' compensation expenses, widened to $889 million from $587 million.
