Revenue increased to $17.07 billion from $16.67 billion, as the decline in first-class mail revenue to $5.92 billion from $6.05 billion was offset by the increase in shipping and packages revenue to $5.15 billion from $4.68 billion and in marketing mail revenue to $3.98 billion to $3.92 billion. "The root cause of our financial instability is a flawed business model that is imposed by law," said Postmaster General Megan Brennan. "We support legislation under consideration in the current Congress which would provide immediate flexibility to the organization, allow the Postal Service to invest in our future and continue to provide the prompt, reliable, efficient and universal service the public expects."

Shares of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings Ltd. NCLH, -0.67% climbed 5.3% in premarket trade Thursday, after the cruise operator reported second-quarter profit and revenue that beat expectations and raised its full-year outlook. Net income rose to $226.7 million, or $1.01 a share, from $198.5 million, or 87 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to $1.21, above the FactSet consensus of $1.03. Revenue increased 13.2% to $1.52 billion, beating the FactSet consensus of $1.50 billion. Passenger ticket revenue rose to $1.08 billion from $938.0 million, to top the FactSet consensus of $1.04 billion, while onboard and other revenue increased to $445.1 million from $406.1 million but missed expectations of $453.2 million. Total cruise operating expenses grew 14.7%, as fuel price per metric ton rose to $481 from $469. Looking ahead, the company raised its 2018 adjusted EPS guidance range to $4.70 to $4.80 from $4.55 to $4.70. The stock has lost 4.4% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.9%.

Shares in Applied Optoelectronics Inc. AAOI, +5.99% experienced a strong rebound in late trading Tuesday, after the company reported an earnings beat. The optical-networking company reported second-quarter profit of $8 million, or 40 cents a share, on sales of $87.8 million, down from $117.4 million a year ago. After adjusting for stock-based compensation and other effects, the company claimed earnings of 64 cents a share, down from $1.54 a share a year ago. Analysts on average expected adjusted earnings of 44 cents a share on revenue of $77.8 million, according to FactSet. Applied Opto guided for earnings of 39 cents a share to 52 cents a share on sales of $75 million to $81 million. "We are pleased with our second quarter results, which were driven by increased demand for our market-leading datacenter products," Chief Executive Thompson Lin said in Tuesday's release. Shares jumped about 19% in late trading, after closing with a 4.5% decline at $37.23. Before any post-earnings bounce, the stock had fallen 1.6% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% gained 6.6%.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. BMY, -0.37% shares rose 1.8% in Thursday premarket trade after the company reported second-quarter profit and revenue beats. Earnings for the latest quarter declined to $373 million, or 23 cents per share, from $916 million, or 56 cents per share in the year-earlier period. Adjusted earnings-per-share were $1.01, above the FactSet consensus of 87 cents. Revenue rose to $5.70 billion from $5.14 billion, above the FactSet consensus of $5.49 billion. The latest results include sales beats for Opdivo, Eliquis, Orencia, Sprycel, Yervoy and Empliciti, while Baraclude sales missed the FactSet consensus. Bristol-Myers decreased its 2018 EPS guidance from a range of $2.70 to $2.80 to a range of $2.68 to $2.78, compared with the FactSet consensus of $2.78. The company increased its 2018 adjusted EPS guidance from between $3.35 and $3.45 to between $3.55 and $3.65, compared with the FactSet consensus of $3.42. Bristol-Myers shares have surged 13.5% over the last three months, compared with a 6.7% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% and a 4.5% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average.

Goldman Sachs analysts downgraded Illinois Tool Works Inc. ITW, -1.47% stock to neutral from buy and removed it from its Americas Conviction List, after the company's second-quarter earnings fell short of expectations. "The bottom line is that after two disappointing quarters, we have less conviction that ITW can deliver differentiated margin/EPS growth over the next 12 months," analysts led by Joe Ritchie wrote in a note. Goldman was buy-rated on the stock based on strong execution and a differentiated margin story, which it expected would lead to beats on earnings estimates. The company has outperformed margin expectations for at least the last five years, as it streamlined its portfolio. "After two quarters of missed expectations, our conviction has waned," said the note. "Specifically, we under-appreciated the margin headwinds associated with price/cost. Additionally, the company called out growth investments (60bps) for the first time, highlighting that margins could remain pressured for the near-to-medium term." Illinois Tool Works shares were up 2.2% on Tuesday, but are down 16.5% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.5%.

Shares of General Electric Co. GE, -1.31% sank 3.3% on heavy volume in morning trade Friday, turning sharply lower soon after the opening bell, just as the post-earnings conference call concluded. In premarket trade, the stock jumped as much as 2.7% right after the quarterly report was released, with earnings and revenue beating expectations, but pulled back to trade little changed just before the open. On the conference call, Chief Executive John Flannery said he expects 2018 adjusted earnings per share to be "at the low end" of the previously provided guidance range of $1.00 to $1.07, while the FactSet EPS consensus is 93 cents. Among other comments made during the call, the power business is going to require a "multi-year fix," with some volatility. Regarding the China tariff situation, Flannery said "we are a company built for fair and open trade," so GE's current view is "hope" that trade matters eventually reach a "sensible negotiated conclusion." The stock has now shed 24% year to date, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 1.4%.

German owners of the Tesla TSLA, +0.86% Model S have been ordered by a government agency to repay a 4,000 euros ($4,640) subsidy on electric vehicles, because the cars are too expensive to qualify for the government program. The Federal Office for Economic Affairs and Export Control, which goes by the acronym BAFA, said it has attempted to hold talks with Tesla in recent months on the issue, but has failed to reach agreement. The subsidy is available for electric cars that cost no more than 60,000 euros, which is the list price for the basic Model S. But Tesla has been unable until now to deliver the basic model to its German clients, and more expensive trims do not qualify. About 800 customers are affected, according to a BAFA release. Customers who ordered a Model S after March 6 will receive the subsidy, after Telsa said it can deliver a basic version of the car. Tesla shares were down 0.9% Wednesday, but have gained 2.7% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5%.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged KBR Inc.KBR, -0.49% on Monday for inflating a key performance metric known as work in backlog. KBR agreed to pay a $2.5 million penalty to settle the SEC's charges without admitting or denying the allegations. The backlog metric represented the amount of revenue that KBR expected to receive in the future from firm orders under awarded contracts. The SEC allegedly found KBR included $459 million in its publicly disclosed backlog in the second quarter of 2012 for one of seven contracts it entered into to complete pipe fabrication and modular assembly contracts in Canada, even though KBR had not received -- and the counterparty was not obligated to provide -- any orders under the contract. KBR violated its internal reporting policies and misled investors by overstating its work in backlog for almost two years. KBR was forced to restate its financial statements for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2013 and its unaudited consolidated financial statements for the third quarter of 2013 for a total negative impact of $156 million.

MetLife Inc. MET, -3.19% has been charged with fraud by the Commonwealth of Massachusetts for failing to make pension payments to retirees that were wrongly designated as "presumed dead." A complaint filed by Secretary of the Commonwealth William Galvin alleges that public filings from the company contained "material misstatements" about the company's finances, because it was not making the pension payments. "Under these pension plans, MetLife was responsible for reserving enough money to make payments to Massachusetts pensioners, whose average age was 72," Galvin said in a statement. "Instead, some reserves were released and became assets which inflated MetLife's bottom line." The charges come after a probe launched in December 2017, after MetLife acknowledged that it had lost track of tens of thousands of pensioners to whom it owned payments after acquiring their pension obligations from the retirees' employers. Galvin is seeking full payment with interest of the pensions, as well as sanctions, censure and a fine. MetLife shares were down 1.7% and have fallen 8% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2%.

Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% shares sank 6.7% in Wednesday trading after the coffee retailer was downgraded to neutral from buy at BTIG. "We believe the company's blizzard of sales initiatives are falling short of driving positive transactions and causing us to moderate our comp outlook," wrote analysts led by Peter Saleh. "We believe Starbucks is slowly transitioning from a global growth concept to a more mature company, as evidenced by the increased focus on G&A efficiency and cash returns, which we believe should warrant a lower valuation multiple." Starbucks announced on Tuesday that it is its lowering its fiscal 2018 earnings per share guidance by 10 cents to between $2.39 and $2.43. The company expects third-quarter same-store sales to rise 1%, missing the FactSet consensus for 1.5% growth. "Our previous view has been there was still enough to keep us positive but the persistent comp degradation causes us to finally give in," wrote BTIG. Starbucks shares are down 6.6% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 3.7% for the period.

Tesla Inc. shares TSLA, +0.86% surged almost 4% premarket Wednesday, after Chief Executive Elon Musk told shareholders at the company's annual meeting that it is "quite likely" it will meet its 5,000 a week production target for the Model 3. Baird analyst Ben Kallo reiterated his outperform rating on the stock and said news that Tesla expects to achieve positive GAAP net income and cash flow in the third and fourth quarters was a highlight. "While we do not model GAAP profitability for conservatism, we believe TSLA will be able to achieve sustainable operating cash flow and operating profit in the intermediate-term, which would be a significant catalyst, in our opinion," Kallo wrote in a note. Shareholders approved the re-election of the board of directors by a significant margin, "which we believe provides a vote of confidence in management," he wrote. Baird is upbeat on the company's energy storage opportunity, which may be underappreciated by some investors, he said. Tesla shares have fallen 6.5% in 2018 so far, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.8%.

J. Jill Inc. JILL, -1.16% shares are up nearly 5% in Friday trading after the women's apparel company's price target was raised by multiple analysts. J. Jill reported earnings and revenue that blew past estimates on Thursday. Cowen analysts raised their price target to $9 from $7, saying that they are "encouraged" by consistent traffic trends, which "bodes well for customer loyalty and retention." Cowen rates J. Jill stock outperform. SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analysts raised their price target to $7 from $5. "While we are encouraged by recent results we prefer to wait on the sidelines until carryover inventories are cleared through and we can get a true read on customer reaction to new full-priced assortments," wrote SunTrust. They rate J. Jill stock hold. Wells Fargo analysts raised their price target to $8 from $5, but also expressed concerns about low visibility going forward. Wells Fargo rates J. Jill shares market perform. J. Jill stock is up 5.4% for the year to date, outpacing the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% which is up 2.2% for the period.

The Securities and Exchange Commission charged Woojae "Steve" Jung on Thursday, an investment banker at Goldman Sachs GS, -1.78% who worked in San Francisco and New York, with insider trading in the securities of 12 different companies. Jung allegedly made $140,000 in profits trading in advance of public announcement of market-moving events using an account held in the name of a friend living in South Korea, Sungrok Hwang, who is charged as a relief defendant that will be required, if the SEC prevails, to disgorge illicit gains that Jung generated in his account. The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York also filed criminal charges against Jung in Thursday. The SEC's complaint alleges that Jung used his friend's account in an attempt to evade Goldman Sachs' requirements that he pre-clear his trades and use an approved brokerage firm that would have reported the trading to his employer. In its press release an SEC official said that the regulator used data analysis to uncover a suspicious trading pattern that could be traced back to Jung.

CareDX Inc. CDNA, +13.49% shares surged 17% in the extended session Thursday after the company reported second-quarter earnings. The company reported second-quarter net losses of $14.1 million, or 40 cents a share, compared with losses of $4 million, or 19 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for changes in the value of stock warrants and derivative liabilities losses were 4 cents a share, narrowing from 17 cents a share in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $17.8 million from $12.1 million in the year-ago period. The company said it expects full-year sales of $68 million to $70 million. CareDX shares have gained 104% this year, with the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% rising 6.7%.

Salesforce.com Inc. CRM, -0.21% has promoted Chief Operating Officer Keith Block to co-chief executive alongside founder Marc Benioff, the company announced in a surprise move Tuesday night. "Keith has been my trusted partner in running Salesforce for the past five years, and I'm thrilled to welcome him as co-CEO," Benioff said in a statement. "Keith has outstanding operational expertise and corporate leadership experience, and I could not be happier for his promotion and this next level of our partnership." The company said Benioff would remain chairman of the board and lead Salesforce's "vision and innovation," while Block would lead the company's growth strategy, execution and operations. Salesforce shares are up more than 40% year to date.

Bloom Energy Corp. BE, +3.48% shares rose 2.3% after hours Tuesday after the energy company reported its first quarterly results post its initial public offering last month. Bloom said it lost $46 million, or $4.36 a share, in the second quarter, compared with a loss of $63 million, or $6.24 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, the company lost 27 cents in the quarter, compared with a loss of 68 cents a year ago. Revenue rose to $169 million, from $87 million a year ago. Bloom is in a post-IPO mandatory quiet period and did not schedule a conference call with analysts. It will do so in the third quarter, Bloom said.

Shares of Oracle Corp. ORCL, -0.45% took a dive into negative territory in afternoon trade Wednesday, after CNBC reported that Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% will completely stop using Oracle software by 2020. The stock was trading up about 0.3% just before the CNBC report, which cited people familiar with the matter, then fell as much as 0.7% to an intraday low of $47.34 within minutes after the report before paring some losses. The stock was last down 0.3%. The CNBC report said Amazon has been moving off Oracle for several years. Oracle's stock has lost 5.3% over the past 12 months, while Amazon shares have soared 80% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13.5%.

Shares of Anadarko Petroleum Corp. APC, +1.15% fell 1.6% late Tuesday after the energy company reported mixed second-quarter results. Anadarko said it earned $29 million, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter, versus a loss of $415 million, or 76 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, the company earned $278 million, or 54 cents a share, in the quarter, versus a loss of $423 million, or 77 cents a share, a year ago. Revenue totaled $3.29 billion, from $2.72 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of 57 cents a share on sales of $3.07 billion. Anadarko shares ended the regular trading day down 0.8%.

U.S. oil prices settled lower Monday, giving up earlier gains as the market played down the impact of rising tensions between the U.S. and Iran. "There's a lot of uncertainty in oil right now, which can cause some of the ups or downs to quickly change the market direction, especially after Iran drew Trump's ire over the weekend," Patrick DeHaan, head of petroleum analysis at GasBuddy, told MarketWatch. "Uncertainty brought some buyers to the table this morning but overall, it was lipstick on a pig." September WTI oil CLU8, -0.12% on its first full session as a front-month contract, settled at $67.89, down 37 cents, or 0.5%, for the session, after tapping a high of $69.31.

Shares of Microsoft Corp. MSFT, -0.61% surged 1.5% toward a second-straight record high, in the wake the software giant's better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter results. The stock's rally has lifted Microsoft's market capitalization to $828.3 billion to close in on Alphabet Inc. GOOGL, -0.95% which is the third-largest U.S. company by market cap, at $835.5 billion. Microsoft is still well behind second-place Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% at $874.6 billion and first-place Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% at $935.2 billion. Microsoft's stock rose 1.8% on Friday after results were reported late Thursday. It has run up 26% year to date, while the Nasdaq Composite COMP, -0.67% has rallied 13% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 1.2%.

Shares of Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% are down 1.8% in Tuesday trading after Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% announced that it had started to launch augmented-reality ads in the core Facebook news feed. The ads are currently in a test phase, and Michael Kors Holdings Ltd. KORS, +0.46% is the first brand to try them out through a feature that lets users virtually try on sunglasses and then buy them. Snap popularized AR ads through its lenses feature, which lets brands create overlays that users can apply to their photos and videos. Snap shares have fallen 21% over the past 12 months, while Facebook shares have gained 33% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has climbed 15%.

Shares of Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% are up 1.5% in premarket trading Thursday after Instinet's Dan Dolev raised his price target on the stock to $82 from $65. "The launch of Square for Restaurants marks Square's entry into the $650-700 billion U.S. restaurant industry," Dolev wrote. "We see at least ~30% potential upside to adj. revenue over a three-year period, a combination of payment processing revenue and cross-selling of ancillary software and services." He said that while all merchant acquirers have restaurant exposure, Global Payments Inc. GPN, -0.40% seems "most at risk" to disruption by Square. Shares of Square are up 180% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Cheniere Energy Inc. LNG, -0.10% has agreed to acquire its 48.6%-owned subsidiary Cheniere Energy Partners LP Holdings LLC CQH, +0.46% in a stock deal that values Cheniere Partners at $30.93 a share, the companies said Tuesday. Cheniere Partners shareholders will receive 0.4750 Cheniere Energy shares for each share owned. The deal is expected to qualify as a tax-free reorganization for Cheniere Partners shareholders and to close by the end of the third quarter. Houston-based Cheniere Energy is engaged in liquid natural gas-related businesses and owns and operates the Sabine Pass LNG terminal in Louisiana. Cheniere Energy shares were slightly higher premarket, and have gained 20.9% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

Shares of GameStop Inc. GME, +0.72% are up 7.5% in Monday afternoon trading after it was reported that the videogame retailer was having talks with private-equity firms about a possible buyout. The Reuters report, which cited people familiar with the matter, said that GameStop has hired a financial advisor to help as it undergoes these talks. Sycamore Partners is among the firms that are potentially interested in buying GameStop, according to Reuters. GameStop shares were halted briefly in Monday's session due to volatility. GameStop has struggled amid declining mall traffic and the increased popularity of digital game downloads. Its stock is down 26% over the past year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has climbed 14%.

Advanced Micro Devices Inc. AMD, -0.21% shares are up 2% in Wednesday morning trading after the company announced overnight that its Epyc 7000 series processor would be powering a new Hewlett Packard Enterprise Inc. HPE, -1.61% server, the ProLiant DL325 Gen10. The server will be available in July. Stifel analyst Kevin Cassidy hiked his AMD price target last week partly because of the company said that a Cisco server platform would use the Epyc 7000 processor. Cassidy predicted that other server companies would be making "similar announcements." AMD shares are up 23% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 13% and the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has risen 29%.

At least seven people were killed and 20 injured in a volcanic eruption in Guatemala on Sunday, according to the Associated Press. Hundreds of local residents were evacuated, and officials said an undetermined number of people were missing and feared the death toll would rise, the AP reported. The volcano erupted around noon local time, and lava flowed down the mountain into a nearby village. The AP said four people died when lava caught a house on fire, and two children were burned to death on a bridge. The volcano, Volcan de Fuego, is about 25 miles outside the capital, Guatemala City. Video posted on social media showed cars fleeing a towering cloud of volcanic ash.

The U.S. economy appears to have gotten quick out of the gate in the second quarter and it could be on track for 4% growth or higher, analysts say. After strong gains in personal income and consumer spending in April, a bevy of Wall Street firms upped their GDP forecasts. Amherst Pierpont Securities raised its estimate to 4.5% from 4.2%. Macroeconomic Advisers increased its forecast to 4% from 3.6%. Natwest raised its projection to about 4% from 3.2%. Barclays also upped its estimate, but it was near the low end of forecasts. It raised its target to 3.3% from 3%. GDP has only topped 4% three times since the end of the Great Recession in mid-2009.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, who is visiting Pyongyang, North Korea, on Thursday, has invited North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to Russia, the Russian Foreign Ministry said, according to Reuters. Lavrov told Kim that Moscow supported peace and progress on the Korean peninsula and highly valued a declaration signed by Pyongyang and its South Korean counterparts, the report said. Meanwhile, U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo met with North Korean Gen. Kim Yong Chol, often described as the North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's right-hand man, this week as White House teams work on logistical and substantive issues ahead of the potential summit between President Donald Trump and Kim, the timing of which remains uncertain.

Shares of Dropbox Inc. DBX, -9.82% are up 7.6% Thursday ahead of the company's earnings report, which takes place after the bell. Analysts surveyed by FactSet expect the company to post adjusted earnings per share of 6 cents on revenue of $330.9 million. The earnings report will be Dropbox's second since its March initial public offering. Shares are up 59% from their $21 IPO price. The stock was recently upgraded to buy from hold at Jefferies, "based entirely on valuation" and the potential for new subscription plans to help on pricing. Shares are up 5.5% over the past three months, compared with a 6.1% gain for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71%

Shares of Qualcomm Inc. QCOM, -0.40% are up 1.1% in premarket trading after Cowen & Co. analyst Matthew Ramsay upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. He raised his price target on the stock to $80 from $64. Ramsay sees several potential catalysts for the stock, including "the NXP bid abandoned, a $30 billion buyback program underway, recent $700 million in good faith catch-up payments from a large OEM royalty dispute (we believe Huawei), pending court dates suggesting progress in royalty disputes with Huawei/Apple, and solid progress demonstrated on cost-cutting initiatives." Qualcomm shares are up 24% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 15%.

Shares of Yum China Holdings Inc. YUMC, -0.84% skidded in Wednesday's extended session after the fast-food chain announced its quarterly earnings. The operator of KFC and Pizza Hut in China reported its second-quarter net income rose to $143 million, or 36 cents a share, from $125 million, or 31 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue grew 12% to $2.1 billion while same-store sales slid 1% on the back of a 4% drop at Pizza Hut. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 33 cents on revenue of $2.1 billion. Yum China had spun off from Yum Brands at the end of 2016. Yum China shares slid 3.2% after hours.

Shares of Zendesk Inc. ZEN, -0.10% rallied in Tuesday's extended session after the enterprise-software company posted stronger-than-projected earnings. Zendesk reported its second-quarter net loss widened to $34.4 million, or 33 cents a share, from a loss of $26.3 million, or 26 cents a share, a year earlier. However, on an adjusted basis, the company earned 3 cents a share. Revenue rose to $141.9 million versus $102.1 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had projected the company to break even and post a revenue of $137 million. Zendesk projected third-quarter revenue of $150 million to $152 million and 2018 revenue in a range of $582 to $586 million. Shares rallied 7.4% after hours.

Walmart Canada announced plans on Thursday to invest more than $175 million to build a 300,000-square-foot fulfillment center in Surrey, British Columbia. The frozen grocery facility will provide products to 60 stores in British Columbia. It will also create 150-to-200 long-term jobs and 300 jobs for construction and engineering pros. The fulfillment center, which is expected to open in early 2022, will be a zero-waste facility using efficient refrigeration systems and taking other sustainability measures. Walmart Canada operates 410 stores across the country. Walmart Inc. WMT, +1.31% shares are down nearly 10% for the year to date while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 2.8% for the period.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average midday Friday held on to solid gains after 12 Russian intelligence officers were indicted for hacking into the Democratic National Committee's server. The Dow DJIA, -0.77% was up 0.4% at 25,013, the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% gained 0.1% at 2,802, while the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% advanced 0.1% at 7,832, after hitting an intraday record earlier in the session. All three benchmarks are on pace to post solid weekly returns, on the back of trade fears receding--at least momentarily--for stock-market investors. Friday's indictment comes as Special Counsel Robert Mueller has been investigating interference by Russia into the 2016 presidential election won by Donald Trump.

Shares of BioCryst Pharmaceuticals Inc. BCRX, +1.39% and Idera Pharmaceuticals Inc. IDRA, -14.50% were active in the extended session Tuesday following a brief halt after BioCryst shareholders voted down a merger between the two drug companies. BioCryst shares rallied 7.5% after hours, following flat trade Tuesday to close at $6.14. Idera shares dropped 16% after hours, following a 0.7% decline to close the regular session at $1.37. BioCryst said it would reimburse Idera for $6 million in transaction-related expenses as a result of terminating the merger agreement, which was announced in January. As of Tuesday's close, BioCryst shares had advanced 9.8% since the January announcement, while Idera shares had fallen 46%.

Canadian cannabis company Tilray TLRY, +0.86% has set the terms for its planned initial public offering, saying in a filing Monday that it plans to offer 9 million shares priced at $14 to $16 each. The company would raise $135 million at the midpoint of that range. Tilray is planning to list on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol "TLRY." Shares will be offered in the U.S. by a syndicate comprising Cowen, Roth Capital Partners and Northland Capital Markets. In Canada, they will be offered by a syndicate of BMO Nesbitt Burns and Eight Capital. Proceeds of the deal will be used to increase liquidity and develop cultivation and processing capacity.

Nike Inc.'s stock NKE, -0.65% fell 1.4% in premarket trade, to pace the 28 Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% components that traded lower ahead of the open, after tennis star Roger Federer appeared to end his apparel deal with Nike, after Uniqlo said Federer was its new global brand ambassador. Among other leading Dow decliners in the premarket, shares of Intel Corp. INTC, -2.57% shed 1.2%, Boeing Co. BA, -1.25% dropped 1.1% and Caterpillar Inc. CAT, -1.88% gave up 1%. The lone gainer was Walmart Inc.s' stock WMT, +1.31% which inched up 0.1%, and Procter & Gamble Co. shares PG, +0.04% were unchanged. Dow futures YMU8, -0.32% fell 159 points.

U.S. stocks opened mostly lower on Thursday, as ongoing uncertainty surrounding trade policy weighed on investor sentiment. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was flat at the open at 2,700. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% fell 38 points, or 0.2%, to 24,084. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% declined 8 points, or 0.1%, to 7,436 at the open. Among the biggest losers on the S&P 500, shares of Walgreens Boots Alliance Inc WBA, +0.48% and CVS Health Corp CVS, +0.70% dropped nearly 10% after Amazon.com AMZN, -0.64% announced that it has agreed to acquire PillPack, an online pharmacy that pre-sorts medications into different doses and handles both refills and renewals.

Members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed in principle Friday to a deal that would lift output by a nominal 1 million barrels a day, though the effective increase would be smaller, reports said. According to The Wall Street Journal, the deal would effectively add 600,000 barrels a day to global markets. The effective boost would be smaller than the headline figure because although each country would share a portion of the boost, not all can boost production right now. August Brent crude futures uk:lcoq8 was up $1.55, or 2.1%, to $74.60 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate futures clq8 advanced $1.70, or 2.6%, to $67.24 a barrel.

The U.S. Energy Information Administration reported Thursday that domestic supplies of natural gas rose by 91 billion cubic feet for the week ended June 15. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts had forecast a climb of 85 billion cubic feet, while the average over the last five years for the same week was a rise of 83 billion. Total stocks now stand at 2.004 trillion cubic feet, down 757 billion cubic feet from a year ago, and 499 billion below the five-year average, the government said. July natural gas ngn18 was up less than a penny, or 0.3%, at $2.971 per million British thermal units, down from $3 before the data.

Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, -0.10% said late Friday that Senior Vice President Michael J. Dolan will retire on Aug. 1 after 38 years of service. Dolan was elected to his current position and as a member of Exxon's management committee in 2008. Earlier this week, Exxon announced the retirement of its long-time investors relation VP, Jeff Woodbury, who will be replaced by Neil Hansen on July 1. In a note this week, analysts at Barclays called that change "as another positive step in the process of increasing transparency and better listening to investor / market criticism." Exxon shares were flat in late trading after ending the regular trading day up 0.9%.

Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has admitted defeat ahead of no-confidence vote to be held in parliament, according to media reports Friday. "It has been an honor to be president of the Government of Spain," Rajoy said in Congress, according to Spain's El Pais newspaper. Rajoy acknowledged he would be replaced after the opposition Socialist Party won enough support from lawmakers to hold the no-confidence vote, which was prompted by corruption convictions for senior members of Rajoy's People's Party. "Pedro SÃ¡nchez will be the prime minister of the government and I want to be the first to congratulate him," said Rajoy, referring to the Socialist Party's chief, according to El Pais.

Spanish Prime Minister Mariano Rajoy has admitted defeat ahead of no-confidence vote to be held in parliament, according to media reports Friday. "It has been an honor to be president of the Government of Spain," Rajoy said in Congress, according to Spain's El Pais newspaper. Rajoy acknowledged he would be replaced after the opposition Socialist Party won enough support from lawmakers to hold the no-confidence vote, which was prompted by corruption convictions for senior members of Rajoy's People's Party. "Pedro SÃ¡nchez will be the prime minister of the government and I want to be the first to congratulate him," said Rajoy, referring to the Socialist Party's chief, according to El Pais.

Shares of General Electric Co. GE, -1.31% fell 1% in midday trade Friday, after Bloomberg reported the industrial conglomerate is preparing to sell its power-conversion business for a lot less than what it paid for it. Citing people familiar with the matter, the report said the unit, formerly known as Converteam, could fetch about $1.5 billion, while GE paid about $3.2 billion for the assets in 2011. The sale process could begin as soon as next month, Bloomberg reported. GE's stock has slumped 49% over the past 12 months, while the SPDR Industrial Select Sector ETF XLI, -0.88% has gained 11% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has climbed 16%.

Nordson Corp. NDSN, +0.26% said Friday it will raise its quarterly dividend by 17% to 35 cents a share from 30 cents a share. The maker of products used to dispense adhesives and coatings said the new dividend will be payable Sept. 4 to shareholders of record on Aug. 21. Based on Thursday's stock closing price of $133.08, the new annual dividend rate implies a dividend yield of 1.05%, compared with the implied dividend yield for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% of 1.89%, according to FactSet. Nordson's stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has lost 9.1% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.7%.

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has made inquiries to Tesla Inc TSLA, +0.86% over Elon Musk's going-private tweet, including examining whether the chief executive's statement was factual and why the disclosure was made on Twitter rather than on a filing, according to aWall Street Journal report that cited sources familiar with the matter. Musk stunned markets Tuesday, tweeting he was "considering" taking Tesla private at $420, adding that funding was "secured." The company later posted on its website an email to employees from Musk expanding on the idea. Tesla shares rallied 11% on Tuesday, but lost 2.4% Wednesday asWall Street faulted the plan for being lean on funding details.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% said Wednesday that Whole Foods Market shoppers in Sacramento and Virginia Beach will now have access to grocery pickup service. Prime members use the Prime Now app to make their grocery selections and in as little as 30 minutes, can pick up their order at the local Whole Foods without leaving their car. Free pickup is available in an hour on orders of $35, and for pickup in 30 minutes, the fee is $4.99. more cities will offer the service in 2018. Amazon shares have gained 59.3% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up nearly 7% for the period.

Crude-oil prices finished higher Monday on the back of a pair of factors that threaten to disrupt near-term supplies - bullish factors for futures. West Texas Intermediate crude oil for September delivery trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange CLU8, -0.38% rose 52 cents, or 0.8%, at $69.01 a barrel.Reports on Friday indicated that Saudi crude production dropped to around 10.3 million barrels a day in July, down from 10.49 million barrels a day in June, according to OPEC representatives, while President Donald Trump's administration has made good Monday on its vow to reimpose sanctions on Iran, which could cut 1 million barrels a day in global exports from Tehran.

Shares of Baidu Corp. BIDU, +0.10% are down 6.1% in premarket trading after a report from the Intercept said that Alphabet Inc.'s GOOGL, -0.95% Google plans to launch a censored search engine in China. Baidu also reported better-than-expected earnings results late Tuesday. The story from the Intercept cites leaked documents and says that Google's planned search engine will automatically filter out results for websites that are blocked in China, and it will also "blacklist sensitive queries." Alphabet didn't immediately respond to MarketWatch's request for comment. Baidu currently dominates Chinese mobile search. Its shares are up 9.5% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has climbed 14%.

Cummins Inc. CMI, -1.22% said Tuesday it had net income of $545 million, or $3.32 a share, in the second quarter, up from $424 million, or $2.53 a share, in the year-earlier period. The number includes a charge of $181 million to cover the costs of a previously disclosed product campaign. The maker of engines for the power industry said revenue rose 21% to $6.1 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $3.64 and revenue of $5.823 billion. The company is now expecting full-year revenue growth of 15% to 17%. Shares rose 2.8% premarket, but are down 22.3% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.8%.

Mohawk Industries Inc. MHK, -1.07% shares dropped in the extended session Wednesday after the flooring company's earnings and outlook fell short of Wall Street expectations. Mohawk shares fell 14% after hours. The company reported second-quarter net income of $196.6 million, or $2.62 a share, compared with $260.7 million, or $3.51 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were $3.51 a share. Revenue rose to $2.58 billion from $2.45 billion in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated $3.90 a share on revenue of $2.58 billion. For the third quarter, Mohawk estimates earnings of $3.54 to $3.64 a share , while analysts expect earnings of $4.29 a share.

Shares of W.W. Grainger Inc. GWW, +0.29% rocketed $32.28, or 10.6%, toward a record high in midday trade Wednesday, after the maintenance and repair products supplier's better-than-expected second-quarter earnings report. The stock was the biggest percentage gainer within the SPDR Industrial Select Sector ETF XLI, -0.88% and within the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% and was the biggest price gainer on the NYSE. The stock is headed for the biggest one-day price and percentage gain since it soared $42.52, or 18.5%, after reporting fourth-quarter results on Jan. 24. It has now run up 42.8% year to date, while the industrial ETF has slipped 1.4% and the S&P 500 has gained 5.2%.

Agricultural company Alliance One International Inc. AOI, -7.42% said Monday it is seeking to change its name to Pyxus International Inc. and will ask shareholders to approve the move at its Aug. 16 annual meeting. the company is in the midst of a transformation plan, that aims to move beyond its leaf tobacco business to new business lines including e-liquids, industrial hemp under a federal pilot program and legal cannabis in Canada. The name Pyxus is inspired by the Greek word for compass, the company said in a statement. Shares were not yet active premarket, but have gained 23.8% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.8%.

Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% increased the prices of its Model S and Model X in China by about $22,600 to $37,600 over the weekend after the imposition of tariffs on imported cars, the automotive news website Electrek reported on Monday. Tesla does not yet produce any of its electric cars in China, although it was planning to set up a facility in Shanghai's Free-Trade Zone. The U.S. and China each imposed levies on $34 billion worth of the opposing country's goods on Friday. Tesla shares were up about 1% in premarket trade, but are down 0.8% in the year through Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3%.

Shares of Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% sank 1.4% in premarket trade Thursday, after the coffee seller said Chief Financial Officer Scott Maw is retiring, effective Nov. 30, after about 4 1/2 years in the role. The company has launched a external search for a new CFO. Maw had joined Starbucks in 2011 as global controller, and was promoted to CFO in February 2014. Just prior to the CFO announcement, the stock was up less than 0.1% in premarket trade. Earlier this month, executive chairman Howard Schultz said he was stepping down. The stock has shed 13% year to date through Wednesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1%.

European Central Bank officials could start to discuss raising short-term interest rates in fall 2019, a top ECB policy maker said Monday, according to a report in The Wall Street Journal. "I think from the current perspective, maybe we can think about the possibility to discuss further steps in autumn [next year], but as I said, discuss," said Vitas Vasiliauskas, who sits on the ECB's rate-setting committee as head of Lithuania's central bank, in an interview. He also indicated that the ECB will not take rate action at its September 2019 meeting. His comments suggest it could be the end of next year before the ECB actually increases interest rates.

Gap Inc. GPS, +0.48% announced Wednesday afternoon that Neil Fiske would take over the role of president and chief executive of its Gap brand. Fiske had previously been chief executive of Billabong, Eddie Bauer and Bath and Body Works. He will permanently replace Jeff Kerwin, who left the company in February; Brent Hyder had been filling in on an interim basis during the search. "Neil brings significant retail and apparel experience to Gap Inc. and a track record of transforming and repositioning brands," Gap CEO Art Peck said in Wednesday's announcement. Gap stock has declined 5.4% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has increased 4.2%.

Shares of Twitter Inc. TWTR, +0.16% are up for the ninth straight day after S&P Dow Jones Indices said late Monday that the company would get a place in the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% The stock has gained more than 21% in the past nine days, which would be its best nine-day performance since February, according to the WSJ Market Data Group. The stock is on pace to close at its highest level since April 28, 2015, when shares ended the day at $42.27. Twitter's stock recently changed hands at just under $40. Shares are up 119% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 has gained 13%.

Maxim Group analyst Nehal Chokshi upgraded HP Inc. HPQ, -0.37% shares to buy from hold on Wednesday following the company's better-than-expected earnings report. The latest results are "indicative that printing supplies are positioned for low single digit growth," he wrote. Chokshi is also upbeat about the company's opportunities in 3D printing. "Recent checks give us confidence 3D printing will be ~5x current operating profit run rate, and likely will come to fruition," he said. Chokshi raised his price target to $28 from $27. HP shares are up 4.2% in premarket trading and up 12% over the past 12 months. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% is up 11% in that time.

Roku Inc. ROKU, +1.27% stock rose to a record high in late morning trading Thursday, two days after the company released second-quarter earnings that handily beat Wall Street expectations. Roku stock is up 4.3% as of 11:11 a.m. Eastern time to $59.80 as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has slid 0.6%. The move comes after Roku said it planned to launch its ad-supported free streaming offering called the Roku Channel on the web, playable on desktops and mobile devices; one analyst has said that aspect of the business could be worth $1 billion in market valuation on its own. Roku currently enjoys a market capitalization of roughly $6 billion, according to FactSet.

Mesa Air Group Inc. MESA, -2.08% announced Thursday afternoon that it would sell fewer shares at a lower price than it originally expected in its initial public offering. The regional airline said it now plans to sell 9.63 million shares at $12 apiece, after targeting the sale of 10.7 million shares at a price ranging from $14 to $16 a share. The company will bring in about $115.6 million at that price, though underwriters - led by Raymond James and BofA Merrill Lynch - have access to another 1.44 million shares for overallotment. Mesa Air shares are now expected to begin trading on the Nasdaq exchange Friday morning under the ticker symbol MESA.

Shares of Infinera Corp. [s; infn] are down 6.6% in Wednesday trading after the company reported in-line revenue for its June quarter but beat on the bottom line. "Stepping back, we still have concerns about the company's competitiveness," wrote Jefferies analyst George Notter, who acknowledged that the latest quarterly results were "solid." He said that the increased scale that would come with the company'a acquisition of Coriant will likely help, but Notter sees "significant execution risk with the transaction." Notter rates the stock at underperform and lowered his price target to $7.75 from $8. The stock is down 11% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 15%

The Securities and Exchange Commission late Tuesday delayed a decision on an application for the first bitcoin-related exchange-traded-fund. The regulator said it planned on making a decision on the proposed ETF from VanEck and SolidX on Sept. 30. A decision was expected no earlier than Aug. 10, 45 days from the time the ETF duo submitted their application for the fund. The price of bitcoin moved lower after the news, with a single bitcoin [s:btcusd] last changing hands at $6,877.26, down 0.6%, since Monday 5 p.m. Eastern Time on the Kraken exchange. The SEC's announcement comes 12 days after a similar bitcoin ETF by Cameroon and Tyler Winklevoss was rejected on July 26.

Cushman & Wakefield PLC's stock CWK, -1.21% opened 5.9% above its initial public offering price, as the real estate services company raised at least $765 million. The first trade was at $18 at 10:18 a.m. ET for 3.5 million shares, before paring some gains be up 5.3%. The IPO pricing late Wednesday values the company at about $3.1 billion. The company, which had been owned by a private-equity consortium since 2014, has gone public at a time that the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% has gained 3.5% over the past three months, the SPDR Real Estate Select Sector ETF XLRE, -0.96% has climbed 6.8% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has rallied 7.5%.

Eleven conservative Republican House members, led by Rep. Mark Meadows of North Carolina and Jim Jordan of Ohio, introduced a resolution to impeach Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein late Wednesday. The move by the House Freedom Caucus leaders is not seen as a sign that the full House will soon vote to impeach, as it appears to lack support from some Republican leaders. It also comes just a day before the House leaves for a monthlong recess. The impeachment articles accuse Rosenstein, who is overseeing special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation into Russian election meddling since Attorney General Jeff Sessions recused himself, of withholding documents, hiding materials and failing to comply with oversight requests.

Verizon Communications Inc. stock VZ, -1.02% rose 3.1% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the telecommunications company beat second-quarter earnings and revenue expectations. Profit for the latest quarter fell to $4.246 billion, or $1.00 a share, from $4.478 billion, or $1.07 a share, in the same period a year ago. Adjusted earnings-per-share were $1.20, compared with the FactSet consensus of $1.14. The company had 531,000 retail postpaid net additions, down from 614,000 in the second quarter last year. Revenue rose 5.4% to $32.2 billion from $30.5 billion, in line with the FactSet consensus of $31.8 billion. The stock has lost 4.1% over the past year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has risen 5%.

Gold prices finished with a gain on Friday as comments President Donald Trump, showing his displeasure with Federal Reserve interest-rate increases, prompted a decline in the benchmark dollar index. Prices for the yellow metal, however, still suffered a loss for a second week in a row. Overall strength in the dollar and a "slow but steady rise in real interest rates have been the two most notable bearish influences on gold" since the first quarter, say Tyler Richey, co-editor for the Sevens Report. August gold GCQ8, -0.59% settled at $1,231.10 an ounce, up $7.10, or 0.6%, for the session. Prices were down 0.8% for the week, after settling Thursday at a one-year low.

Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% said Thursday that it will open a cafe in October that caters to the needs of the deaf and hard of hearing. All of the associates in the new Washington, D.C., store, about 20 to 25, will be fluent in American Sign Language. It will be located near Gallaudet University, whose campus is an ASL-immersive environment. The idea for the store came from the Starbucks Signing Store in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, which opened in 2016 with nine deaf workers. Starbucks shares are down 0.3% in premarket trading, and are down 11% for the year so far. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 5.3% for 2018 so far.

Shares of Mednax Inc. MD, +0.29% and Envision Healthcare Co. EVHC, -0.02% declined midday Wednesday after prominent short-seller Jim Chanos, the founder of Kynikos Associates, recommended betting against stocks of those companies. Shares of Envision, a health-care company and national hospital-based physician group, were most recently down 0.4%, while those for Mednax, which focuses on neonatal and pediatric health services, were off 1.3%. Chanos has previously stated his bets against Envision but reiterated the call at CNBC's Delivering Alpha conference. He described both bets as rooted in potential accounting issues. Shares of Mednax are down nearly 19% so far this year, while those for Envision are up about 29%, according to FactSet data.

Check Point Software Technologies Inc. CHKP, -0.11% shares are up 2% in Tuesday trading after BTIG analyst Joel Fishbein upgraded the stock to buy from neutral. "After three quarters of stagnant stock performance and four quarters of disappointing guidance from Check Point, we believe it is now time to get constructive on the name again," he wrote. Fishbein had been looking for signs that the company's sales force was becoming more effective and that the company had finally hit its trough. "We believe both of the criteria are now true," he wrote. Shares of the security company are little changed over the past year, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.5%.

Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% ticked up more than 2% Monday after a report surfaced about the hardware and software maker producing a visual search product that will send users to Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% listings. Snap stock has lost 5.7% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.9%. The visual search is codenamed "Eagle" and details of its inner workings are buried within the code of the company's Snapchat Android software, according to a tech blog which reported the news. Should Snap work out a deal with Amazon to get paid for affiliate referrals to the e-commerce giant, it could add another source of revenue for the California-based company.

Shares of Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% are up 1.1% in premarket trading after Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Jamie Friedman raised his price target on the stock to $74 from $53. Friedman cited "good fundamental trends" as well as the company's recent acquisition of website-creation company Weebly as reasons for his heightened optimism. He raised his earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda) estimates for the company due to his expectation of higher-term margins, "although we would note Street Q1 '19 margins look way off to us." Friedman has a positive rating on the stock. Shares are up 177% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

Galapagos NV GLPG, -4.24% shares plummeted more than 14% in after-hours trading Thursday after the company said that AbbVie Inc. ABBV, +0.35% was pulling out of development plans for a potential cystic fibrosis drug. Galapagos announced that AbbVie would not proceed with a previously contemplated study of a combination therapy for cystic fibrosis, and that "Galapagos was reviewing the future of its CF collaboration with AbbVie." Galapagos also said that a study of one of the elements of the potential combination therapy reached its primary endpoint. Galapagos shares closed with a 0.5% decline at $95.81, and have gained 2.2% so far this year as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has increased 1%.

PayPal Holdings Inc. PYPL, -0.18% said Thursday afternoon that it has agreed to acquire a fraud-prevention startup for $120 million, the third significant acquisition the payments company has announced since mid-May. Simility, the latest purchase for PayPal, had raised $24.7 million from venture investors that included PayPal, according to FactSet. In May, PayPal announced a $2.2 billion deal for iZettle, and just two days ago, it said it was buying HyperWallet for $400 million. PayPal stock was quiet after Thursday's announcement in after-hours trading, after gaining a couple pennies in the regular session to $85.97. Shares are up 16.8% so far this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.5%.

Shares of Micron Technology Inc. MU, -1.70% are up 1.4% in premarket trading Friday after Mizuho analyst Vijay Rakesh defended the stock following Thursday's pullback. The stock dropped 8% on Thursday after a Morgan Stanley downgrade. Mizuho's Rakesh still sees reasons for optimism in regards to both the DRAM and NAND businesses. "We continue to see upside in 2H18 driven by data center, server and PC demand," he wrote. "While NAND should see mid-single digit ASP declines, it should also drive significant demand elasticity." Micron shares are up 87% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 11% and the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has risen 26%.

Shares of II-VI Inc. IIVI, +1.00% are up 7.7% in premarket trading Tuesday after the maker of optoelectronic components reported better-than-expected earnings and revenue for its fiscal fourth quarter. The company posted net income of $27.2 million, or 42 cents a share, down from $32.6 million, or 50 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. On an adjusted basis, the company reported earnings per share of 52 cents, ahead of the FactSet consensus expectation of 47 cents. Revenue rose to $321.1 million from $273.7 million and exceeded expectations of $301.2 million. Shares were up 5.6% over the past year, as of Monday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 15%.

Goldman Sachs analyst Piyush Mubayi downgraded shares of Chinese streaming company iQiyi Inc. IQ, +0.79% to neutral from buy on Thursday. The stock is down 3.1% in premarket trading. Mubayi continues to like iQiyi's growth prospects and fundamentals but argued that "the rallied market price has factored in positive upsides and we see greater upside potential elsewhere in our coverage universe." That said, he saw a number of positives in the company's earnings report from earlier in the week, including membership gains aided by a JD.com Inc. JD, -0.64% partnership and new original programming. Shares are up 85% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.7%.

With shares down 3.2% in morning trade, Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% has entered bear-market territory. The stock has now fallen 22% from its record close of $217.50 on July 25, and will officially be in a bear market if it closes at that level. Many chart watchers say a new bear market starts after a fall of 20% or more from a bull-market high. Shares of Facebook sold off 19% in Thursday's session after the company delivered a sharp warning about its future revenue growth, and the stock dropped another 0.8% in Friday's session. Facebook's stock is down 2.7% so far in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.3%.

AbbVie Inc. shares ABBV, +0.35% rose 1.4% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the company said the U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved its Orilissa oral gonadotropin-releasing hormone antagonist as a treatment for endometriosis pain. The approval will bring to market the first oral treatment for moderate to severe pain from endometriosis in more than a decade. The medication is expected to be in U.S. retail pharmacies in early August. Endometriosis causes painful symptoms and affects about one in 10 women of reproductive age, making it one of the most common gynecologic disorders in the U.S. AbbVie shares have fallen 7.6% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.9%.

U.S. oil prices climbed Friday, extending gains from a day earlier when comments from Saudi Arabia's OPEC governor eased concerns over the potential for an oversupplied market. Rising U.S.-China trade war tensions, however, raised expectations of a slowdown in commodity demand, helping to pull prices lower for the week. August West Texas Intermediate crude clq8 rose $1, or 1.4%, to settle at $70.46 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. It settled at its highest level in a week, but was still down 0.8% from last Friday's finish. September WTI oil CLU8, -0.10% which became the front-month contract at the session's end, finished at $68.26, up 2 cents for the day.

Things are shifting at AT&T Inc.T, -0.71% and Time Warner Inc. post-merger. John Stankey, a long-time AT&T executive who will be running the Time Warner properties, announced several rebranding and structural changes in an internal memo Friday afternoon. Time Warner will be renamed WarnerMedia, and former Time Warner head Jeff Bewkes and Turner cable-TV unit chief John Martin will be departing. Several other Time Warner executives, including CFO Howard Averill, executive vice president of global public policy Carol Melton and executive vice president Olaf Olafsson, are also leaving. AT&T shares are down 14.9% so far this year and Time Warner shares are up 29.1%. The S&P500SPX, -0.71% is up 4.0%.

Thomson Reuters Corp. TRI, -0.83% said Thursday it is adding $1 billion to its share buyback program, adding to the $500 million authorization announced in May. The company has repurchased about $231 million since resuming its buyback program last month. The news and financial data company said the buybacks will allow it to reduce the size of a planned $9 billion to $10 billion issuer bid/tender offer that the company is planning to make to all shareholders, tied to the sale of a 55% stake in its financial & risk division. Shares rose 1.1% premarket, but are down 9.3% in 2018 so far, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.7%.

The United States Supreme Court Monday ruled that a Colorado baker who refused to create a cake for a gay couple's wedding did not violate Colorado human rights laws. Justice Anthony Kennedy, writing for the court in the 7-2 decision, said that the Colorado Human Rights Commission was "neither tolerant nor respectful" of the baker's religious beliefs when it ruled against him. The decision reversed a lower court ruling that found in favor of the gay couple, who had claimed discrimination based on the refusal. Kennedy acknowledged in his opinion that the circumstances of the case were "difficult" and legal experts said the decision was not likely to set a broad precedent.

Qorvo Inc. QRVO, -2.71% shares are up 2.3% in premarket trading after KeyBanc Capital Markets analyst John Vinh upgraded the stock to overweight from sector weight. "We believe the healthy handset demand environment for China and Apple AAPL, -0.30% sets up well for the stock to outperform in the second half in conjunction with share gains in China and content gains in the new iPhone," Vinh wrote. His price target of $95 reflects expectations for market-share gains as well as interest-expense savings stemming from the company's debt pay down. Qorvo shares are up 19% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

The largest exchange-traded fund to track Germany's equity market rose on Tuesday, after the country's government reached a last-minute deal for tighter control over immigration. The deal was seen as preventing a full-blown crisis that could have cost Chancellor Angela Merkel her position as leader. The iShares MSCI Germany ETF EWG, -3.03% gained 0.9% in early trading. The fund has struggled throughout 2018, having fallen in 10 of the past 13 sessions. It is down 8.84% thus far this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% rose 0.5% on Tuesday while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% was up 0.3%. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% dipped 0.1%.

Shares of Square Inc. SQ, +1.76% are up 0.7% in Tuesday trading after Stephens analyst Brett Huff downgraded the stock to equal weight from overweight. Shares initially opened lower. "After a truly remarkable stock price acceleration over past two years and tougher comps coming," Huff thinks that the company's current share price is appropriate. "We think that the 13.5x forward adjusted revenue appropriately captures most of this value especially when compared with a high-value high-growth set of comps." Huff prefers PayPal Holdings Inc. PYPL, -0.18% shares at current levels. Square shares are up 157% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

General Motors Co. GM, -2.45% said Wednesday that Chief Financial Officer Chuck Stevens will retire, effective March 1, 2019, after more than 40 years at the company. Stevens was appointed CFO on Jan. 15, 2014. The automaker said it will appoint Dhivya Suryadevara as CFO, effective Sept. 1, 2018. Suryadevara has been vice president in corporate finance since July 2017, and was vice president, finance and treasurer, from 2015 to 2017. The stock edged up 0.3% in premarket trade. It has climbed 7.8% year to date through Tuesday, while rival Ford Motor Co. shares F, -1.72% have slipped 3.0% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.2%.

Harley-Davidson Inc. HOG, -1.14% has partnered with apparel company G-III Apparel Group Ltd. GIII, -0.48% to sell a lifestyle clothing line in Asia. G-III, whose brands include DKNY and Calvin Klein, will develop a network of Harley-Davidson stores in the Asia-Pacific region, with the first opening in February in Shanghai. The stores will target 18-to-35-year-olds. Harley-Davidson said during its last earnings report that it will look to attract new customers both in the U.S. and abroad. Harley-Davidson shares are down 17.4% for the year to date, G-III shares are up 14% for the period, and the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 1.2% for 2018 so far.

Roku Inc. ROKU, +1.27% shares are up 4.5% in Friday trading after short sellers at Citron Research said they had changed their stance on Roku and now have a long position in the stock. "Roku is trading at the largest discount ever to over-the-top peers despite being the only OTT pure play that generates ad revenue," wrote the Citron team in a report. "With the recent surge in Netflix Inc. NFLX, -1.00% stock, Netflix could look towards advertising to generate new revenue and could easily acquire Roku." Citron initiated a short position in Roku in late November. Shares are up 168% from Roku's September IPO price of $14.

Synaptics Inc. SYNA, -11.38% shares plunged in late trading Tuesday after the company's merger talks with Dialog Semiconductor PLC DLG, -1.18% fell apart. Synaptics stock was down 13.6% at the end of the extended session, after reports that Dialog had called off talks to acquire Synaptics. Synaptics confirmed the end of discussions in a press release later Tuesday evening. "Synaptics is a global leader and technology innovator in multiple high growth markets, and interest by a number of industry players underscores the tremendous value inherent to our company," Chief Executive Rick Bergman said in the release. Synaptics shares soared last month after talks between the companies were first reported.

MoviePass parent Helios and Matheson HMNY, -19.87% announced it would be raising its monthly subscription fee to $14.95 from $9.95 in the next 30 days as part of a cost-reduction plan. The company said it would also limit the availability of first-run movies during the first two weeks of release on over 1,000 screens. MoviePass has experienced service issues in the past few days, most notably over the weekend when users complained of being unable to watch "Mission: Impossible -- Fallout." Shares of Helios and Matheson rose 127% after the news broke, but shares have fallen 100% so far this year. The S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.3%.

Shares of Chipotle Mexican Grill Inc. CMG, -0.45% jumped in Thursday's extended session after the gourmet burrito chain posted better-than-expected earnings. Chipotle reported its second-quarter earnings fell to $46.9 million, or $1.68 a share, from $66.7 million, or $2.32 a share, a year earlier. On an adjusted basis, Chipotle would have earned $2.87 a share. However, revenue rose 8.3% to $1.27 billion and comparable restaurant sales grew 3.3%. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of $2.81 a share on revenue of $1.26 billion. The company raised its 2018 comparable restaurant sales growth outlook to low to mid-single digits from low-single digit previously. Chipotle shares rallied 6.5% after hours.

Shares of Micron Technology Inc. MU, -1.70% are up 1.6% in Thursday morning trading after South Korea's SK Hynix Inc. 000660, +0.40% reported quarterly results. The numbers indicated that DRAM demand remains strong. "Hynix is expecting 2H DRAM prices to trend stronger (positive for Micron with ~65% of revenues from DRAM)," wrote Mizuho analyst Vijay Rakesh, who rates Micron's stock a buy. Cowen & Co. analyst Karl Ackerman said that he viewed the results as "largely in-line" for Micron Technology Inc. MU, -1.70% and Silicon Motion Technology Corp. SIMO, +1.27% Micron shares are up 81% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% shares plunged even lower Wednesday afternoon, falling more than 17% after the company followed a revenue miss with a weaker-than-expected forecast. Shares were down about 7% before the conference call, when Chief Financial Officer David Wehner disclosed the social-media giant expects a revenue deceleration to continue. "Our total revenue growth rates will continue to decelerate in the second half of 2018, and we expect our revenue growth rates to decline by high single digit percentages from prior quarters sequentially in both Q3 and Q4," he said on the conference call. Wehner also said Facebook still expects expenses to grow 50% to 60% from last year.

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - The manufacturing and service sides of the U.S. economy showed steady and rapid growth in July, according to a preliminary or "flash" reading by IHS Markit . The manufacturing index rose a tick to 55.5 from 55.4. The services index slipped to 56.2 from 56.5. Readings over 50 indicate growth . The latest report indicates the economy continued to expand in midsummer at a healthy pace despite heightened tensions over trade. The biggest worry for companies are rising prices. IHS Markit said the increase in what companies charge rose at the fastest clip since the firm first began to collect information in the fall of 2009.

U.S. stock-index futures pared their losses to turn slightly positive on Friday, after a report on the labor market in June showed better headline employment figures than had been estimated. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures YMH9, -0.80% rose 0.2%, while S&P 500 futures ESH9, -0.26% were up less than 0.2%. Nasdaq-100 futures NQH9, -0.64% added 0.1%. In the report, 210,000 jobs were added last month, above the 200,000 that had been expected. The unemployment rate also rose to 4% from 3.8%. Futures had been pointing to a lower open prior to the release of the report, following the implementation of much-anticipated import tariffs by the Trump administration and China.

Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Monday that a forthcoming Trump administration announcement won't be specific to China. In a tweet, Mnuchin called stories by The Wall Street Journal and Bloomberg "false, fake news." The Journal reported late Sunday that President Donald Trump plans to bar many Chinese companies from investing in U.S. technology firms, and block additional tech exports to Beijing. A Bloomberg story on Monday said the White House is planning to declare China's investment in certain U.S. companies a threat to economic and national security. Mnuchin said a statement "will be out not specific to China, but to all countries that are trying to steal our technology."

The U.S. Energy Information Administration reported Thursday that domestic supplies of natural gas rose by 96 billion cubic feet for the week ended June 8. Analysts polled by S&P Global Platts had forecast a climb of 88 billion cubic feet, while the average over the last five years for the same week was a rise of 91 billion. Total stocks now stand at 1.913 trillion cubic feet, down 785 billion cubic feet from a year ago, and 507 billion below the five-year average, the government said. July natural gas ngn18 declined by 3 cents, or 1%, to $2.933 per million British thermal units, down from $2.969 before the data.

Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% and J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% said Monday that they're launching a Starbucks Rewards Visa V, -0.20% Prepaid Card, a payment card that can be reloaded without fees and earn Starbucks rewards. The two companies launched a co-branded credit card in February. The card offers 125 bonus "stars" the first time it's used to load $10 or more onto the card, one star for every purchase of $10 among other perks. Starbucks shares are down 1.5% for the year so far, J.P. Morgan is up 3.9% for 2018 so far, and the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 4% for the period.

Lowe's Companies LOW, -1.63% announced Monday that Chief Financial Officer Marshall will retire, effective Oct. 5, after a little over a year in the role, and 21 years at the company. Croom had become CFO of the home improvement retailer in March 2017, after joining the company in 1997. The company is conducting an external search for its next CFO. Lowe's stock was still inactive in premarket trade. It has rallied 19.5% over the past 12 months, while rival Home Depot Inc.'s stock HD, -0.90% has climbed 20.6%, the SPDR S&P Retail ETF XRT, +0.06% has gained 12.9% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has advanced 16.2%.

U.S. stock futures trimmed gains but were still trading higher Friday after a government report showed the economy added 223000 jobs last months, while the unemployment number fell to 3.8%. The headline number was better than expected. The yearly rate of pay increases rose to 2.7% from 2.6%. Earlier, futures showed little reaction when President Trump tweeted that he was looking forward to the jobs report. The futures for Dow Jones Industrial Average YMZ8, -0.30% were up 110 points, or 0.4%, to 24,531. The S&P 500 index futures esm8 were up 10 points, or 0.4% to 2,715. Meanwhile the Nasdaq-100 futures nqm8 advanced 16 points, or 0.2% to 6,996.

Investors can blame the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% decline Friday on two stocks, those of Chevron Corp. CVX, +0.66% and Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, -0.10% which are shaving a combined 36 points off the Dow as oil prices sink. Chevron shares were the Dow's biggest losers, as they shed 3.0%, with the price decline of $3.84 taking about 26 points off the Dow. Exxon's stock slumped $1.45, or 1.8%, to reduce the Dow's price by about 10 points. Meanwhile, the Dow was down just 7 points. Crude oil futures cln8 tumbled 3.5%, as Russia and the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) are reportedly discussing boosting supply.

Evolution Fresh, which specializes in cold-pressed juices and smoothies, is entering the tea category with the launch of organic kombucha in seven U.S. cities. Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% acquired Evolution Fresh in 2011. Evolution Fresh Organic Kombucha will be available in six flavors including pink grapefruit and mango pineapple, and will be available in Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Francisco, San Diego, Seattle and New York City. The new kombucha will be available at natural and grocery stores. Starbucks shares are down 10% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained nearly 7% for the period.

U.S. stocks closed mostly higher Thursday on the back of strong technology shares as Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% became the first U.S. company to hit a $1 trillion market capitalization. Apple's milestone comes on the heels of strong quarterly earnings and an upbeat outlook issued earlier in the week. However, trade-related concerns as President Donald Trump pursues his hard-line trade policies capped the upside. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 13 points, or 0.5%, to 2,827 and the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% added 95 points, or 1.2%, to 7,802. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% slipped 7 points to 25,326.

HP Inc. HPQ, -0.37% said Wednesday that it planned to acquire Apogee Corp., a U.K.-based printing company. Apogee provides printing services and document technology. HP said that the deal values Apogee at Â£380 million, or approximately $500 million. The company sees the acquisition as beneficial for its efforts to "disrupt" the market for A3 copiers, which it says is valued at $55 billion. The deal is expected to close by the end of the calendar year. HP shares are unchanged in premarket trading and up 21% over the past 12 months. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14% in that time.

Cheesecake Factory Inc. CAKE, -0.42% shares fell in the extended session Tuesday after the restaurant chain's earnings missed the Wall Street consensus. Cheesecake Factory shares were down 3.8% after hours following a 2.1% decline to finish the regular session at $56.03. The company reported second-quarter net income of $28.4 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $38.2 million, or 78 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 65 cents a share. Revenue rose to $593.2 million from $569.9 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated 81 cents a share on revenue of $592.7 million.

Shares of Papa John's International Inc. PZZA, -2.34% and Wendy's Co. WEN, -0.62% rose late in the trading session Wednesday after a report in The Wall Street Journal said ousted founder and chairman John Schnatter had held talks to merge the pizza company with Wendy's. The talks between officials from both companies were preliminary and started before Schnatter stepped down as chairman last week over the use of a racial slur, according to the report, which cited people familiar with the matter. Talks have cooled since Schnatter's ousting, the report said. Papa John's shares rose 4% while Wendy's shares were up 2%.

The stocks of air carrier United Continental Holdings Inc. UAL, -1.24% rallied 4.9% in morning trade Wednesday, and of rail transport company CSX Corp. CSX, +0.30% jumped 3.9%, after both companies reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings. The stocks paced the gains in all 20 Dow Jones Transportation Average's DJT, -0.45% components. The price gains for the stocks were adding a combined 36 points to the Dow transports, with about 22 points coming from United's gain and 14 points coming from CSX's rally. The Dow transports was up 138 points, or 1.3%, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% was down 4 points.

The Boeing Co. BA, -1.25% said Tuesday it has received orders and commitments from Air Lease Corp. AL, +2.17% for 78 jets in a deal valued at $9.6 billion. The aerospace giant made the announcement at the Farnborough air show, saying the order includes 75 737 MAX 8s and three 787-9 Dreamliners. ALC has now placed orders and commitments for 361 Boeing airplanes since 2010. Boeing shares were flat premarket, but have gained 20.8% in 2018, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% which counts Boeing as a member, has gained 1.4%, and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.7%.

All of the banks met the regulatory minimums for capital after undergoing what's called the "severely adverse" stress test that would cause $578 billion in losses for 35 lenders, the Federal Reserve announced Thursday. The Fed said the aggregate common equity tier 1 capital ratio would fall from an actual level of 12.3% in the fourth quarter of 2017 to 7.9%. That is just the first round of the stress tests, as the results of the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review are announced next week. It's only then that bank shareholders will know how much in dividends and buybacks they can receive.

Nvidia Corp. NVDA, -0.65% will replace Time Warner Inc. in the S&P 100 index prior to the opening bell on June 20, S&P Dow Jones Indices said late Friday. Nvdia stock was flat in after hours trading and closed down 0.6% to $265.26 during the regular session. The change in the index comes as the AT&T Inc. T, -0.71% -Time Warner merger closed earlier this week. FleetCor Technologies Inc. FLT, +0.75% will replace Time Warner in the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% FleetCor stock is up nearly 5% in after hours trading and closed up 0.8% to $216.29 during the regular session.

Stitch Fix Inc. SFIX, +4.91% had its best trading day on Friday since the company went public, closing up 26% to $24.87 during the regular session after posting strong first-quarter earnings after the bell Thursday. Stitch Fix shares were up a fraction during the after hours session. The company beat top- and bottom-line expectations Thursday, logging net income of $9.5 million on sales of $316.7 million, well above analyst expectations, according to FactSet. The company also announced a line of kids apparel. Stitch Fix stock has gained 67% since its November IPO, as the benchmark S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% rose 7.4%.

Twitter Inc.
