TWTR, +0.16% shares rallied in the extended sesion Monday after S&P Dow Jones Indices announced the microblogging platform would join the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% Twitter shares rose 3.8% after hours, following a 3.4% rise to close at $37.88 in the regular session. Twitter shares are up 58% for the year, compared with a 2.7% rise in the S&P 500. Twitter will replace Monsanto Co. MON, +2.33% which is being acquired by Bayer AG BAYN, -11.05% on Thursday. On the S&P 100 index OEX, -0.76% Netflix Inc. NFLX, -1.00% will replace Monsanto. Netflix shares were up 0.2% after hours.

Wells Fargo WFC, -0.67% CEO Timothy Sloan should be fired after the bank admitted that an error may have contributed to hundreds of people losing their job, Sen. Elizabeth Warren tweeted Monday. The Massachusetts Democrat said setting aside a "few thousand dollars" for those affected was "pathetic." Wells Fargo admitted in a regulatory filing that as many as 400 homeowners between April 2010 and Oct. 2015 may have needlessly lost their homes to foreclosures because of errors in the way the bank evaluated applications to participate in the Home Affordable Modification Program. Wells Fargo set aside $8 million to deal with the consequences.

Shares of Chinese game-streaming company Huya Inc. HUYA, +4.14% are down 1% in Friday morning trading after Goldman Sachs analyst Piyush Mubayi initiated coverage of the stock with a neutral rating and $34 price target. "We believe the company is well-positioned to benefit from both the fast growing online game sector (especially mobile game) as well as live streaming updraft," he wrote. However, Mubayi thinks shares look fully valued. The stock is currently trading near $33, far above its May IPO price of $12 a share. Shares are up 5.9% over the past month, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.5%.

President Trump has waived attorney-client privilege in relation to the conversation secretly recorded by longtime Trump lawyer Michael Cohen, Trump's personal attorney, former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani, said Saturday, according to NBC News. Trump earlier Saturday had called the tape "totally unheard of [and] perhaps illegal." NBC's Kelly O'Donnell said Giuliani explained the decision to waive privilege by saying word of the tape's existence -- it reportedly includes pre-election discussion of payment to a former Playboy Playmate who has said she had an affair with Trump -- "was already out there." Giuliani said Friday that the tape was "exculpatory" for his client.

The Boeing Co. BA, -1.25% said Thursday it has secured commitments from Dubai-based aircraft lessor Novus Aviation Capital for up to four 777-300 ERs (extended range) with a list price of $1.44 billion. Novus has an aircraft portfolio under management of about 50 aircraft worth nearly $4 billion. The 777-300ER can hold up to 386 passengers in a three-class configuration and has a maximum range of 7,930 nautical miles. Boeing shares were slightly lower premarket, but have gained 22.2% in 2018, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which counts Boeing as a member, has gained 1.9% and the S&P 500 has gained 5.3%.

It is uncertain how the Trump administration's fight to lower trade barriers will turn out, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell said Thursday. "It's very hard to sit here today and say which way it's going," Powell said in an interview with Marketplace. Powell said he could imagine situations which could be "very challenging" for the Fed, for instance where inflation is going up and the economy is weakening. Powell said he was unconcerned about pressure from the Trump White House to keep interest rates low. "Nothing has been said to me publicly or privately that gives me any concern about our independence," he said.

Natus Medical Inc. BABY, -1.11% said late Wednesday it appointed Jonathan Kennedy its new chief executive and president. Kennedy, who has served as chief finanical officer, replaces Jim Hawkins, who is retiring after 14 years as CEO, Natus said. The company, which makes medical products for newborns, also named Barbara Paul as chairwoman. Natus narrowed its forecast second-quarter revenue to a range of $130 million to $131 million, compared with a previous forecast $129 million to $131 million. Analysts surveyed by FactSet estimate revenue of $130.5 million. Natus shares, which closed down 3% at $34.20 in regular trading Wednesday, were flat after hours.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% weakness in morning trade Friday belies the overwhelmingly positive market breadth data. The Dow was down 19 points, but 16 of its 30 components are trading higher. The number of advancing stock outnumbered decliners 1,856 to 814 on the NYSE and 1,752 to 684 on the Nasdaq exchange. The volume of advancing stocks represented 67.6% of total volume on the Big Board and 68.8% of total volume on the Nasdaq. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 0.3% and the Nasdaq Composite COMP, -0.67% gained 0.5%, while the Dow Jones Transportation Average DJT, -0.45% fell 0.2%.

United Parcel Service Inc. UPS, -1.32% said Friday it has reached a handshake agreement with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters on a new national master agreement for some of the union's members. The five-year agreement must now be ratified by those members, who play roles in small package delivery. Talks on extra agreements covering local work rules and a separate agreement for the 11,000 Teamster-represented employees in the UPS Freight division will continue. if ratified, the new agreements will become effective August 1. UPS shares rose 1.3% premarket, but are down 4.3% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.9%.

Shares of Charah Solutions Inc. CHRA, -1.62% are down in their first day of trading, after the company, which provides services to the coal and nuclear industries, priced its initial public offering significantly below its expected range. The IPO priced at $12, while the company had expected it to price in the range of $16 to $18. The first trade was executed at 9:54 a.m. for $11.80. Shares are now trading a bit lower, down 4.3% at $11.48. Charah's IPO comes as the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% is up 11% this year, and as the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% is up 4.1%.

The euro EURUSD, -0.2804% was sent on a rollercoaster ride on Thursday after the European Central Bank said it'll extend it's quantitative easing program until the end of December and then end it altogether. The shared currency immediately jumped to $1.1852, but quickly turned lower to trade around $1.1746. The ECB said it'll continue to buy 30 billion euros a month until September and then cut the monthly pace to 15 billion euros a month until the end of the year. On interest rates, the central bank said rates will remain at their present all-time lows "at least through the summer of 2019."

White House press secretary Sarah Sanders and her top aide, Raj Shah, are planning to leave their jobs, CBS News reported Wednesday night. Citing multiple sources, CBS said Sanders planned to leave before the end of the year, while Shah had no timeline yet. More departures in the White House communications office are expected in the coming weeks, CBS said, and many currently vacant jobs will not be filled. "There will be even more people leaving the White House sooner rather than later, laid off or just leaving out of exhaustion," one source told CBS. Sanders was appointed press secretary by last July.

Treasury yields rose Wednesday after the Federal Reserve raised its benchmark fed funds rate by 0.25% to a range of 1.75% to 2%, as expected. The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -0.25% rose 1.5 basis points to 2.972%. The 2-year note yield TMUBMUSD02Y, -0.32% , sensitive to shifting expectations for Fed policy, picked up 2.9 basis points to 2.570%, while the 30-year bond yield TMUBMUSD30Y, -0.01% was mostly unchanged at 3.095%. Bond prices move in the opposite direction of yields. The central bank dropped language about rates remaining "below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run" in its policy statement.

21st Century Fox shares hit a record high early Wednesday, shooting up 7.4% after a U.S. judge gave the green light late Tuesday for AT&T [s:T] to acquire Time Warner TWX, -28.57% . The ruling paves the road for a bidding war between Comcast Corp. CMCSA, -1.16% and Walt Disney Co. DIS, -1.30% for some of Fox's [s:FOXA] valuable entertainment assets, including the Twentieth Century Fox TV and film studios, a controlling interest in Hulu and a 39% stake in Sky PLC. Fox shares are up 26.1% so far this year, while Comcast shares have fallen 21.3% and Disney shares have retreated 1.5%.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% said Wednesday that the Echo Look, a device to help users organize their wardrobe, is now available to all with new features. Previously, the device, which launched last year, was available by invitation only. Now, among the features, the Echo Look can help users with suggestions based on items they already own using machine learning algorithms coupled with fashion advice from a specialist. There's also an Echo Hearts List so users can tag items they love. Amazon shares are up nearly 70% for the past year while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 13.5% for the period.

Booking Holdings Inc. BKNG, -2.30% the online travel company formerly known as Priceline, said Thursday it had net income of $977.4 million, or $20.13 a share, in the second quarter, up from $720.2 million, or $14.39 a share, in the year-earlier period. Adjusted per-share earnings came to $20.67, ahead of the FactSet consensus of $17.30. Revenue rose to $3.537 billion from $3.025 billion, also ahead of the FactSet consensus of $3.451 billion. Chief Executive Glenn Fogel said the company will continue to work on its long-term strategy of driving profitable growth and investing in increasing customer loyalty and building a larger direct business. The company is now expecting third-quarter revenue to grow 6% to 9%. EPS is expected to range from $35.85 to $36.85. The FactSet consensus is for EPS of $39.79. The company has a history of beating earnings, but offering downbeat outlooks that it later exceeds. Shares fell 8% premarket, but have gained 17.7% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.9%.

Papa John's International Inc. PZZA, -2.34% shares fell in the extended session Tuesday after the pizza chain's earnings and lowered outlook missed Wall Street estimates. Papa John's shares dropped 10% after hours, following a 3% decline to close the regular session at $41.07. The company reported second-quarter net income of $11.7 million, or 36 cents a share, compared with $24.1 million, or 65 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted earnings were 49 cents a share. Revenue declined to $408 million from $434.8 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated 54 cents a share on revenue of $424.4 million. Papa John's lowered its forecast earnings of the year to a range of $1.30 to $1.80 a share, while analysts expect $2.05 a share. At the close, Papa John's shares were down nearly 27% for the year, compared with a 6.9% gain on the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% Papa John's founder John Schnatter recently sued the company following his resignation as chairman.

Shares of Avis Budget Group Inc. CAR, -2.09% rallied 2.1% in premarket trade Monday, after the car rental company announced a partnership with ride-hailing company Lyft. As part of the partnership, Avis will add thousands of vehicles to Lyft's Express Drive program, making it easier for people to drive for Lyft without owning a car. Lyft drivers will be able to reserve an Avis rental car from the Lyft app. The vehicles are expected to become available in the next few months. "With a global fleet of approximately 600,000 vehicles, we are well positioned to take advantage of the continued growth in the ride hailing space by providing on-demand access to a clean, safe and well-maintained vehicle for those who want to become ride hailing drivers," said Joe Ferraro, president of the Americas at Avis. The stock has shed 19% year to date through Friday, while car-rental rival Hertz Global Holdings Inc. HTZ, +0.00% shares hve slumped 28% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.2%.

Exxon Mobil Corp. shares XOM, -0.10% slid 2.2% in premarket trade Friday, after the oil giant's second-quarter earnings fell short of estimates. The company said it had net income of $3.95 billion, or 92 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $3.350 billion, or 78 cents a share, in the year-earlier period. Revenue rose to $73.501 billion from $58.077 billion. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.27 and revenue of $74.153 billion. The numbers "were primarily impacted by significant scheduled maintenance undertaken to support operational integrity," chief Executive Darren Woods said in a statement. "In addition, while we were pleased with the return of full production following the PNG earthquake, extended recoveries from first quarter operational incidents in the Downstream were disappointing. However, good progress was made during the second quarter in fully recovering from these incidents." Shares are down 0.7% in 2018 through Thursday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 3.3% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.1%.

The worst one-day slump in Facebook's short history as a public company risks wiping out all of the social-media giant's gains thus far this year. Facebook Inc.'s shares FB, -1.55% are trading about 19.1%% lower Thursday afternoon, with that daily drop representing its steepest since it went public in 2012 and erasing its gains in the first seven months of 2018. Year to date, Facebook's stock is off 0.2%, at last check. The plunge in the company's shares comes after i delivered an earnings report it reported earnings that were weaker than analysts expected, showing slowing user growth, capped by a weaker-than-expected outlook for revenues as it tweaks its business model in the face of its Cambridge Analytica scandal. Meanwhile, the technology and internet laden Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% was down 1.1% on the session, the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% was trading 0.3% lower, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% was bucking the downbeat trend engendered by Facebook's slide, up 0.4% at 25,517.

Teradyne Inc. TER, -2.34% shares shot up more than 8% in the extended session Tuesday, after the company beat on the top and bottom line. The industrial automation supplier reported second-quarter net income of $101 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $175 million, or 87 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for amortization of acquired assets, among other things, earnings were 59 cents a share. Revenue fell to $526.9 million from $696.9 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated adjusted earnings of 49 cents a share on revenue of $507 million. For the third quarter, analysts model adjusted earnings of 52 cents a share on revenue of $518 million. The company said it expects adjusted third-quarter earnings of 59 cents to 66 cents a share on sales of $540 million to $570 million. The stock has fallen 3.6% this year, with the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% rising 5%. Teradyne shares closed down 0.9% to $43.62 during regular trading.

Shares of Hasbro Inc. HAS, -0.52% shot up 7% in premarket trade Monday, after the toymaker reported second-quarter profit and revenue beat expectations by wide margins. Net income fell to $60.3 million, or 48 cents a share, from $67.7 million, or 54 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The FactSet consensus for earnings per share was 29 cents a share. Revenue declined to $904.5 million from $972.5 million, but was well above the FactSet consensus of $839.3 million, as better-than-expected franchise brands and Hasbro gaming sales offset a miss in partner brands. "2018 is unfolding as expected as our teams manage the liquidation of Toys 'R' Us in many markets and address the rapidly evolving European retail landscape," said Chief Executive Brian Goldner. "Consumer takeaway is up for our brands, and we further strengthened our brand portfolio through the acquisition of POWER RANGERS." The stock has gained 3.3% year to date through Friday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has tacked on 4.8%.

Larry Kudlow, economic adviser to President Donald Trump, said additional pro-growth measures could be coming soon, which could deliver a further jolt to the U.S. economy. Speaking Wednesday morning at CNBC's Delivering Alpha conference in New York, he said the additional fiscal stimulus measures, coming after Trump's late-2017 corporate tax cuts, could boost gross domestic product to a range around 4%. He noted, however that GDP rate could lead to short-term revenue losses. On the note of trade, Kudlow said he wasn't a fan of blanket tariffs, reiterating his standard position on trade and tariffs. The Trump adviser said China should lower its tariff and non-tariff barriers and open up for business. However, he didn't believe President Xi Jinping of China wanted to make a deal, and with little progress in talks so far, Trump would keep on the pressure. Next week, Jean-Claude Juncker, President of the European Commission, was scheduled to come to Washington with a "very important free trade offer", Kudlow said he was told.

Marriott International Inc. MAR, -0.52% said Wednesday that it will remove plastic straws and stirrers at more than 6,500 properties around the world. The hotel chain joins a list of companies that includes Hyatt Hotels Corp.H, -1.28% Starbucks Corp. SBUX, -0.79% and McDonald's Corp.MCD, -0.39% that have also unveiled plans to eliminate plastic straws. Marriott says the move would end the use of one billion plastic straws and a quarter billion plastic stirrers each year. The company is also removing plastic straws from its corporate headquarters. Earlier this year, Marriott began replacing the small plastic toiletry bottles at 450 select-service hotels with in-shower dispensers. They will be in more than 1,500 hotels in North America by the end of the year. The efforts are part of a plan to reduce landfill waste and responsibly source its top 10 products by 2025. Marriott shares are down nearly 4% for the year so far while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.1% for the period.

Berkshire Hathaway Inc. [S: brka] BRK.B, -1.18% on Tuesday said it approved the amendment of its stock buyback program to give its Chairman and Chief Executive Warren Buffett and Vice Chairman Charlie Munger more flexibility and power in deciding when to repurchase Berkshire shares. The previous program only allowed buybacks when the price for the stock did not exceed 20% premium of the book value. With the change, Buffett or Munger can decide to buy back shares when they deem that the price is below the stock's intrinsic value, on a conservative basis. "The current policy whereby share repurchases will not be made if they would reduce the value of Berkshire's consolidated cash, cash equivalents and U.S. Treasury Bills holdings below $20 billion will continue," said the company in a statement. It also said it will not buy back shares until it has released its second-quarter earnings on Aug. 3. Berkshire's Class B shares rose 1.2% in Tuesday's extended session after closing down 0.8% in regular trade.

Shares of Chesapeake Energy Corp. CHK, +0.65% surged 4.4% to a more-than one-year high in active morning trade Monday, fueled a run up in crude oil prices to a 3 1/2-year high. Volume topped 5.6 million shares, making the stock the third-most active on the NYSE. Continuous crude oil futures CLU8, -0.22% jumped 1.6% to $75.14, which would be the highest close seen since November 2014, amid growing concerns over supply. Natural gas futures edged up 0.2%. The correlation coefficient between Chesapeake's stock and crude oil futures is 0.85 over the past 5 years, in which a 1.00 correlation would mean the move exactly in sync. The correlation coefficient between Chesapeake shares and natural gas futures is 0.79 over the same time. Chesapeake's stock was on track to close at the highest level since May 24, 2017. It has rocketed 85% over the past three months, while the SPDR Energy Select Sector ETF XLE, +0.61% has rallied 13% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.6%.

Shares of Micron Technology Inc. MU, -1.70% are up 1.7% in Tuesday trading after UBS analyst Timothy Arcuri upgraded the stock to neutral from sell. "Major producers are taking a more anticipatory approach to DRAM [dynamic random-access memory] bit supply - averting the downside case that we laid out when launching Micron" with a sell rating in April, Arcuri wrote. "While we maintain fairly draconian views on NAND pricing and 2H recovery seems unlikely, these dynamics force us to reconsider the downside case for MU especially considering our long-term bullish demand view." He thinks that Micron could face some gross-margin pressure next year, as the company's cost-reduction efforts slow, but Arcuri predicts that the company's "more proactive approach to capacity" can limit how much the company's margins may fall. Arcuri raised his price target to $60 from $42. Micron shares are up 66% over the past 12 months, while the PHLX Semiconductor Index SOX, -2.47% has gained 24% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has risen 12%.

Okta Inc. OKTA, -1.06% shares are up 9.8% in Thursday morning trading after the single-sign-on company reported better-than-expected results for its most recent quarter and saw a flurry of price target increases as a result. Canaccord Genuity analyst Richard Davis raised his target to $60 from $55, highlighting the company's billings growth and operating cash flow. "We suggest focusing on the fact that Okta is doing a good job creating broader 'concentric circles' of adjacent functionality that extends the firm's TAM without abandoning the core cloud SSO [single-sign-on] market," wrote Davis, who has a buy rating on the stock. SunTrust Robinson Humphrey analyst Terry Tillman upped his price target to $63 from $43 after the report and kept his buy rating intact. "Outperforming on all counts, the company continues to exhibit significant momentum with benefits from Okta Integration Network, customer identity initiatives and play on security," he wrote. The stock is up 111% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Express Inc. EXPR, +1.54% shares jumped 7.5% in Thursday premarket trading after the apparel and accessories retailer reported first-quarter earnings and revenue that beat expectations. Net income totaled $517 million, or a penny per share, after a loss of $2.7 million, or 3 cents per share, last year. Revenue was $479.4 million, up from $474.2 million last year. The FactSet consensus was for a loss of 2 cents per share and sales of $460.0 million. Same-store sales rose 1%, beating the flat FactSet guidance. E-commerce sales rose 35%. Chief Executive David Kornberg said customer reaction to the company's launch of plus sizes was positive. Express expects second-quarter same-store sales between a 1% decrease and a 1% increase and EPS between 2 cents and a loss of 2 cents. The FactSet outlook is for a same-store sales decline of 0.7% and breakeven EPS. Express shares are down 9.8% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up nearly 2% for 2018 so far.

Box Inc. BOX, -1.30% shares dropped nearly 6% before pulling back to 3.5% in the red during the extended session Wednesday after the the company reported earnings that beat Wall Street expectations. Shares closed up 1.9% to $27.78 during the regular session. The company reported first-quarter net losses of $36.6 million, or 26 cents a share, compared with losses of $40.1 million, or 30 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted losses were 7 cents a share. Revenue rose to $140.5 million from $117.2 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated adjusted losses of 8 cents a share on revenue of $139.6 million. For the second quarter, analysts model adjusted losses of 7 cents a share on sales of $146.1 million. The company said that it expects second-quarter adjusted losses of 5 cents to 6 cents a share on sales of $146 million to $147 million. Box stock has gained 31% this year, with the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% rising 0.6%.

Shares of World Wrestling Entertainment Inc. WWE, +0.38% climbed 1.4% toward a record high in midday trade Wednesday, and have nearly doubled so far this year, in the wake of reports that the media and entertainment company's new deal to air "SmackDown" was for a lot more money. On Wednesday, CFRA analyst Tuna Amobi raised the stock price target by 36% to $60 from $44. Amobi said reports that WWE agreed to license its "SmackDown" programming to Fox broadcast network starting in October 2019, as part of a five-year licensing pact reportedly worth $1 billion, "could portend a potentially significant upside to its current licensing pact with the NBC network." The stock has rocketed 96.2% year to date, and has tripled over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1.9% this year and run up 12.9% over the past year. Shares of 21st Century Fox Inc. FOXA, -0.26% the parent of Fox Television Group, have rallied 43.1% over the past 12 months.

PayPal Holdings Inc. PYPL, -0.18% said Thursday at its analyst day in San Francisco that it is raising its three-to-five-year outlook. The company now expects adjusted earnings growth of 20% and revenue growth of about 18% Following the lapse of the payment company's agreement with eBay EBAY, -0.18% executives told analysts that the company plans to spend $1 billion to $3 billion on mergers and acquisitions to expand its merchant and financial services products, according to The Wall Street Journal. Chief Financial Officer John Rainey said that the company plans to return as much of half of its free cash flow to shareholders. Rainey also said that PayPal volume on the top 20 online stores, which is about what it processes on eBay, is growing at 42% versus eBay, which is growing at 8%. PayPal stock was flat after hours and closed up 0.6% to $81.55 during the regular session. PayPal shares have gained 11% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.2%.

Shares of Mesa Air Group Inc. MESA, -2.08% fell in their debut, and were trading 4.2% below the initial public offering price of $12 in afternoon trade Friday. The regional air carrier's IPO priced late Thursday below the expected range of $14 to $16. The first trade was at $12 at 10:50 a.m. Eastern, and it has traded in a range of $11.50 to $12 since then. The air carrier has gone public at a time that the NYSE Arca Airline Index XAL, -1.22% has lost 2.0% over the past three months and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.8%.

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is "intensifying" its probe into Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% public statements after Chief Executive Elon Musk's tweet on Tuesday about taking the company private, according to a Bloomberg News report that cited two people familiar with the matter. The commission's attorneys in San Francisco office were already looking at Tesla's announcements around manufacturing and sales goals, according to the report on Thursday. Losses mounted for Tesla stock near the end of the trading day, with shares off more than 5% recently. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that the SEC had inquired about the tweet.

Shares of Microsoft Corp. MSFT, -0.61% rose 0.5% in morning trade, putting them on track for an eighth-straight gain, as they approach the July 25 record close reached in the wake of upbeat fiscal fourth-quarter results. An eight-session win streak would be the longest since the eight-day streak ended Oct. 8, 2015. The software giant's stock has rallied 4.5% during its current streak, compared with a 9.6% surge during the October 2015 streak. It has run up 28.7% year to date, while the Nasdaq Composite COMP, -0.67% has climbed 14.5% and the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% has gained 3.5%.

Tronc Inc. TRNC, +4.78% shares rallied Wednesday following a report that the media company may be considering an offer to sell off the Chicago Tribune and its other newspaper assets. Tronc shares jumped 14% to $16.87 after touching an intraday high of $17.30. An offer that would value the entire company at up to $700 million, or $19 to $20 a share, is being considered from an unnamed private equity firm, the Chicago Tribune reported citing sources. Wednesday's run-up puts Tronc shares at a 3.5% decline on the year, compared with a 7% gain on the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71%

Cummins Inc. CMI, -1.22% said Wednesday it has entered into a $500 million accelerated stock repurchase (ASR) agreement with Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC. The engine maker's stock edged up 0.2% in premarket trade. Under terms of the ASR, Cummins will buy back $500 million of its common stock from Goldman, with an initial delivery of about three million shares. The final number of shares delivered will be based on the volume-weighted average price of shares during the deal, less a discount. The stock has tumbled 19% year to date through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 6.9%.

Shares of Ford Motor Co. F, -1.72% slipped 0.2% in premarket trade Wednesday, after the automaker reported a decline in U.S. sales for July. Total sales fell 3.1% to 194,026 vehicles, as car sales tumbled 27.7% to 34,879 vehicles and SUV sales fell 1.5% to 69,994 vehicles, offsetting a 10.2% increase in truck sales to 89,153 vehicles. By brand, Ford sales fell 2.7%, as Fusion sales declined 22.1% and Mustang sales dropped 4.4%, while F-Series truck sales rose 2.1%. Lincoln brand sales dropped 11%. Ford's stock has tumbled 20% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.3%.

Shares of Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% fell more than 5% in late morning trading Monday, putting them on track for their lowest close since June 5. The losses followed a report in The Wall Street Journalsaying that Tesla had asked some suppliers for refunds in an effort to turn a profit. The shares traded as low as $292.86. Tesla shares have lost more than 4% so far this year, and more than 9% in the past 12 months, which contrasts with S&P 500 index's SPX, -0.71% gains of more than 4% for the year and 13% in the last 12 months.

All 30 of the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% components' shares were falling in premarket trade Wednesday, as worries over the escalation of a trade war with China weighed on the broader stock market. Dow futures YMU8, -0.36% slid 164 points. The biggest Dow decliner was United Technologies Corp.'s stock UTX, -0.85% which fell 2.4%, followed by the 1.2% decline in both McDonald's Corp. MCD, -0.39% shares, and the 1.2% slide in 3M Co.'s stock MMM, -1.38% The most active Dow stock ahead of the open was Apple Inc.'s AAPL, -0.30% which shed 0.8% on volume of over 186,000 shares.

Celgene Corp. CELG, -0.77% and Acceleron Pharma Inc. XLRN, +2.22% shares pushed higher in the extended session Monday after the biotech companies said a clinical trial showed their jointly developed drug was effective in treating a certain type of inherited blood disorder. Celgene shares advanced 1.3% after hours, following a 1.7% gain to close the regular session at $83.85, while Acceleron shares rallied 9.2% after hours, following a 1.5% gain to close at $47.40. The companies said the drug luspatercept significantly lowered the rate of transfusions needed in patients with transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia, a blood disorder where abnormal hemoglobin production causes anemia.

RBC Capital Markets analyst Mitch Steves raised his price target on Nvidia Corp. NVDA, -0.65% shares to $310 from $300 on Monday, but the stock fell sharply amid a general tech rout. Shares were down more than 5% in morning trading. RBC's Steves wrote that the company could record $13 in earnings per share come fiscal 2021. He is upbeat about data-center spending and predicts that softness in gaming demand could be made up for by "revenue ramps" in the second half. Nvidia shares have gained 55% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 11%.

Shares of Dropbox Inc. DBX, -9.82% are up 14% in Thursday trading, putting the stock on pace for its best single-day gain in history as it surges to new record levels. The stock closed up 6.9% on March 26, shortly after the file-storage company's initial public offering. Dropbox shares have been up in the last four trading sessions. Earlier this week, the company announced updates on its shingled magnetic recording (SMR) storage technology and said it would be the first to deploy this technology "at exabyte scale." Dropbox shares are up more than 70% from their March IPO price of $21.

The German government has ordered Daimler AG [xe: dai] to recall 774,000 diesel-powered vehicles in Europe in order to update engine-management software, but the recall will likely be "immaterial" for Daimler as the costs are estimated to be less than 100 million euros, or about $118 million, analysts at Evercore ISI said in a note Monday. It is also clear that there will be no fines, and German courts could only threaten penalties in case the company didn't act, the analysts said. Moreover, "we don't see any evidence that Daimler was designing software to deliberately cheat on emission testing," they said.

Shares of Immunogen Inc. IMGN, +0.90% fell more than 4% late Tuesday after the biotech company said it plans to offer and sell 12 million shares of its common stock in a public offering. Underwriters will be granted a 30-day option to buy up to an additional 15% of the shares, the company said. Plans for the proceeds include research and development activities, clinical trial activities, manufacturing, and commercialization preparation, the company said. J.P. Morgan Securities, Goldman Sachs, and Cowen and Co. are joint book-runners. Canaccord Genuity LLC is lead manager. Shares of Immunogen ended the regular trading session up 7.4%.

Verrica Pharmaceuticals VRCA, -0.66% set the terms for its initial public offering on Tuesday, saying it will offer 5 million shares priced at $14 to $16 each. The company would raise $75 million at the midpoint of the range. The company is planning to list on Nasdaq, under the ticker symbol "VRCA." BofA Merrill Lynch, Jefferies and Cowen are underwriters on the deal. The company is a clinical-stage drug company that specializes in dermatological products for the treatment of skin diseases with significant unmet needs. Proceeds of the deal will be used to advance clinical trials of its main product candidates.

Italian bank UniCredit UCG, -2.15% is considering a merger with France's Societe Generale GLE, -0.75% according to a report Sunday night by the Financial Times. While no formal offer has yet been made, officials from both banks are in the early stages of talks, the FT said. UniCredit CEO Jean-Pierre Mustier, who is French and a former SocGen executive, has been developing the plan for months, the FT said. Italy's volatile political situation has reportedly pushed back the timeline for a potential merger. UniCredit and SocGen are among Europe's biggest banks, each with a market cap of around 32 billion euros.

Fulton Financial Corp. FULT, +0.00% shares declined in the extended session Thursday after the financial holding company reported that potentially fraudulent activities at an unnamed customer will result in a hit to second-quarter earnings. Fulton shares, which had been paused and fell as much as 6% after hours, were last down 0.9% in the extended session. Shares closed the regular session down 0.9% at $17.45. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Fulton said it expects an 18-cents-a-share headwind from "fraudulent activities" at one of its large commercial borrowers. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had forecast earnings of 31 cents a share.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% has expanded its recently announced discount on Whole Foods Market sale items to an additional 121 Whole Foods locations and all Whole Foods Market 365 stores. Prime members will receive an additional 10% off of sale items and exclusive weekly discounts on other select items. Among the items on sale this week are organic raspberries, antibiotic-free rotisserie chicken, and 40% off probiotic supplements. The offer is available in states including California, Oklahoma, and Arkansas. Amazon shares are up 38.4% for the year to date while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 1% for the period.

Missouri Gov. Eric Greitens on Tuesday said he'll resign, responding to pressure to step down after being indicted on a felony invasion-of-privacy charge. He said he'll resign on Friday. "This ordeal has been designed to cause an incredible amount of strain on my family," he said. "I cannot allow those forces to cause pain and difficulty for the people that I love." He repeated that he has not broken any laws while admitting mistakes. His political action committee also is accused of trying to illegally circumvent the state's campaign disclosure laws. Lt. Gov. Mike Parson, a fellow Republican, will take over.

Gold prices settled with a modest loss on Friday, holding above the key $1,300 an ounce as uncertainty surrounding geopolitical risks tied to North Korea helped to offset pressure from a stronger U.S. dollar. The settlement above $1,300 "may indicate the worst of the selling is over," said Mark O'Byrne, research director at GoldCore. "Despite the short term technical risks, the medium and long term outlook remains bullish. Elevated geopolitical risk should see safe haven demand remain robust." June gold gcm8 fell 70 cents, or less than 0.1%, to settle at $1,303.70 an ounce. It rose roughly 1% for the week.

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - An independent review of President Trump's proposed 2019 budget proposal estimates that future deficits would be twice as large as the White House projects. The federal deficit would total $965 billion in fiscal 2027 and $1.1 trillion in 2028, according to the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office. The White House had predicted the deficits would total $450 billion in 2027 and $445 billion in 2028. In a report issued Thursday, the CBO concluded government spending would be higher and tax revenues lower than the White House predicts. Lower tax revenue would stem in part from the Trump tax cuts.

Nektar Therapeutics NKTR, +0.64% shares swung lower in the extended session Wednesday after the biotech company reported quarterly earnings. Nektar shares, which had been up as much as 5% after hours, were last trading down 4.6% in the extended session, following a 2.5% gain to close the regular session at $55.96. The company reported second-quarter net income of $971.5 million, or $5.33 a share, compared with a loss of $59.9 million, or 39 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Revenue rose to $1.08 billion from $34.6 million in the year-ago period. Analysts surveyed by FactSet had estimated $5.22 a share on revenue of $1.03 billion.

Shares of GoDaddy Inc. GDDY, -0.80% fell more than 4% late Thursday after the internet registrar and web-hosting company beat second-quarter profit and revenue expectations but its bookings fell short. GoDaddy said it earned $18 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter, compared with $21 million, or 10 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales rose 17% to $652 million. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected earnings of 8 cents a share on sales of $644 million. Bookings reached $754 million, up 13% year-on-year, but off FactSet consensus expectations around $766 million. Shares of GoDaddy had ended the regular trading day up 2.1%.

Oil futures extended gains Wednesday after government data showed a larger-than-expected drop in crude inventories last week. The Energy Information Administration said oil stocks fell by 6.1 million barrels in the week ended July 20. Analysts surveyed by The Wall Street Journal had produced a consensus forecast for a fall of 2.9 million barrels, while the American Petroleum Institute, an industry group, on Wednesday had reported a 4.2 million barrel decline. West Texas Intermediate crude for September delivery CLU8, -0.19% was up 67 cents, or 1% at $69.19 a barrel after trading as high as $69.37. Ahead of the data, the U.S. benchmark traded near $68.67.

The U.S. Energy Information Administration reported Thursday that domestic supplies of natural gas rose by 46 billion cubic feet for the week ended July 13. S&P Global Platts had forecast a climb of 59 billion cubic feet, while the average over the last five years for the same week was a rise of 62 billion. Total stocks now stand at 2.249 trillion cubic feet, down 710 billion cubic feet from a year ago, and 535 billion below the five-year average, the government said. August natural gas ngq18 rose 3.3 cents, or 1.2%, to $2.754 per million British thermal units, up from $2.721 before the supply data.

The Food and Drug Administration issued a voluntary recall late Friday of high-blood pressure and heart drugs containing the ingredient valsartan because of impurity issues. Affected companies include Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries Ltd. TEVA, +0.67% Solco Healthcare, and Major Pharmaceuticals, the FDA said. The agency said valsartan used in the affected products contained N-nitrosodimethylamine, which is classified as a probable human carcinogen. "We have carefully assessed the valsartan-containing medications sold in the United States, and we've found that the valsartan sold by these specific companies does not meet our safety standards," said Janet Woodcock, director of the FDA's Center for Drug Evaluation and Research, in a statement.

Dunkin' Brands Group Inc. DNKN, -0.15% said Wednesday that David Hoffmann has been named chief executive officer, effective immediately. He will serve on the board and continue as the president of Dunkin' Donuts U.S., a role that brought him to the company in October 2016. Prior to joining Dunkin' Brands, Hoffman worked with McDonald's Corp. MCD, -0.39% for 22 years. Hoffmann succeeds Nigel Travis, who is retiring after serving as CEO since 2009 and has been appointed executive chairman of the board. Dunkin' Brands shares are up 31% for the past year, outpacing the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% which is up 15.2% for the period.

B. Riley Financial Inc. RILY, +0.66% said late Tuesday that it had appointed Bryant Riley and Tom Kelleher as co-chief executives of the company. B. Riley stock was flat in after hours trading and closed without a price change during the regular session at $23. The company also said that Kenny Young was appointed President. "This new leadership structure is reflective of the evolution and growth the company has seen in recent years with the completion of several acquisitions and equity investments," the company said in a statement. B. Riley stock is up 27% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.5%.

Shares of Cirrus Logic Inc. CRUS, -2.14% are up 8.5% in Monday trading after Susquehanna analyst Christopher Rolland said that the company will have its products in the second-generation Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.30% AirPods. The stock is among the few tech gainers Monday amid general weakness in the sector. Rolland wrote that the AirPod business amounts to "just $50 million" in revenue "but a more serious 50 cent... EPS impact." Cirrus makes chips that factor into audio products. The company didn't immediately respond to MarketWatch's request for comment. Shares are down 39% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

President Donald Trump's trade adviser Peter Navarro said Tuesday that tariffs against China will be "ultimately bullish" for American businesses, as the administration tries to bring "structural change" to the U.S.-China trading relationship. Trump on Monday asked his administration to identify $200 billion in imported goods from China to be penalized with tariffs. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% fell more than 300 points in late-morning action as trade-war fears roiled markets. Navarro said the U.S. and China are having "a trade dispute, nothing more, nothing less." He said Trump is willing to talk to China and other nations about trade, but "talk is cheap."

BrightView Holdings Inc. BV, -5.38% set terms for its planned initial public offering on Monday, saying it will offer 21.3 million shares priced at $22 to $25 each. The provider of commercial landscaping services has applied to list on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol "BV." Proceeds of the offering will be used to repay debt. Goldman Sachs, JPMorgan, KKR Capital Markets and UBS are joint bookrunners on the deal, with Baird, Credit Suisse, Macquarie Capital, Jefferies, Mizuho Securities, Morgan Stanley and RBC Capital Markets acting as co-bookrunners and Nomura, Stifel, William Blair, Moelis & Company and SMBC Nikko are acting as co-managers.

Marvel Studios' "Avengers: Infinity War" crossed the $2 billion box-office mark, the Walt Disney Co. DIS, -1.30% announced on Tuesday. The movie, which was released in late April, reached $2 billion on Monday and joins just three other films in the industry's history to hold the distinction: "Avatar," "Titanic" and "Star Wars: The Force Awakens." Domestically, "Infinity War" is the fifth-highest grossing movie of all time, bringing in $656.1 million through June 11. Overseas, it has grossed $1.346 billion. Disney shares are down 2.5% this year, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% is up 2.4% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% is up 4.2%.

Shares of Snap Inc. SNAP, +0.00% are up 5.6% in Tuesday trading after a report from S3 Partners highlighted "an avalanche of stock loan recalls" that hit during Monday's session and suggested that borrowing rates could increase due to limited supply. The report from S3's Ihor Dusaniwsky said that more than 5 million shares were recalled on Monday. "If stock loan availability dries up, we can expect a significant amount of short covering driving up Snap's stock price even further from its recent historical low," he wrote. The stock has fallen 23% in the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 15%.

Sears Holdings Corp. SHLD, -0.52% shares rose 8.1% on Tuesday after the retailer said it had expanded its partnership between its Sears Auto Centers and Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% to 118 locations. Sears announced last month that it started allowing customers to ship tires to 47 Sears Auto Center locations to have them installed. Now the tire service has been added to 71 stores. DieHard brand all-season tires are available on Amazon. Sears shares are down more than 63% for the past year while Amazon shares have rallied 76% for the period. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 14.8% for the last 12 months.

Shares of ad-tech company The Trade Desk Inc. TTD, +37.13% are down 2.7% in premarket trading Monday after Wells Fargo analyst Peter Stabler lowered his rating on the stock to market perform from outperform. Stabler sees several potential risks ahead for TTD, including "relatively high concentration of spending with a small number of agency holding companies" and a drop in spending on desktop banner-ad placements. "We view TTD's share appreciation (up 89% YTD vs. S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% up 2%) as fully capturing the near-term opportunity," Stabler wrote. He raised his price target on the stock to $88 from $75. TTD shares closed Friday near $87.

Kroger Co. KR, +1.07% could sell its Turkey Hill beverage and ice cream business after exploring all of its strategic options, the grocer said Tuesday. The company has hired Goldman Sachs & Co LLC GS, -1.78% to review strategic alternatives for the brand, including a sale. Turkey Hill has nearly 800 full-time, part-time and seasonal associates working to produce its line of ice teas, fruit drinks, milk, ice cream and more at its Pennsylvania manufacturing and distribution facility. Kroger shares are up 1.3% in Tuesday trading and up 10.4% for 2018 to date. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 7% for the year so far.

Shares of Marriott International Inc. MAR, -0.52% fell more than 4% late Monday after the hotel chain beat adjusted profit expectations for the second quarter but its quarterly revenue fell short. Marriott earned $610 million, or $1.71 a share, in the quarter, compared with $489 million, or $1.28 a share, in the year-ago period. Adjusted for one-time items, Marriott earned $1.73 a share, compared with $1.11 a share a year ago. Revenue rose to $5.35 billion, from $5.21 billion a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet had expected adjusted earnings of $1.38 a share on sales of $5.84 billion. Shares ended the regular trading session up 0.9%.

Mesa Air Group MESA, -2.08% set the terms for its planned initial public offering on Monday, saying it will offer 10.7 million shares priced at $14 to $16 each. The Phoenix, Ariz.-based regional air carrier would raise $160.5 million shares at the midpoint of the range. Proceeds of the deal will be used to pay down debt and for general corporate purposes. The stock will trade on Nasdaq, under the ticker symbol "MESA." Raymond James and BofA Merrill Lynch are lead bookrunners on the deal with Cowen, Stifel and Imperial Capital acting as co-managers. Mesa Air was previously a public company, before filing for bankruptcy in 2010.

Tilray Inc. TLRY, +0.86% late Wednesday raised $153 million via an inital public offering of 9 million shares of which 6.524 million shares will be offered in the U.S. at $17 a share, above its expected pricing range of $14 to $16. Another 2.476 million shares classified as subordinate voting shares will be offered in Canada and other countries at 22.45 Canadian dollar a share. Tilray, a federally-licensed marijuana cultivator, processor and distributor, will receive the bulk of the proceeds and will be majority controlled by the Seattle, Wash.-based Privateer Holdings. Shares are expected to begin trading Thursday morning on the Nasdaq under the ticker symbol TLRY.

Canada's loonie was showing its strength against the U.S. dollar Wednesday morning after the country's central bank lifted key interest rates, as had been widely expected. Bank of Canada hiked interest rates to 1.5% from 1.25%. One U.S. dollar last bought C$1.3087 of the Canadian currency USDCAD, +0.1370% on Wednesday, down 0.2% from C$1.3114 late Tuesday in New York. The interest-rate increase comes as the U.S.'s northern ally has been contending with trade-related worries, including negotiations over the North American Free Trade Agreement--also including Mexico-- which have been on pause for weeks as President Donald Trump adopts an increasingly protectionist posture against the rest of the world.

Shares of Spotify Technology SA SPOT, +0.90% are down 0.4% in premarket trading after Oppenheimer analyst Jason Helfstein initiated coverage of the stock with a perform rating. "We question whether scale begets market leadership in music streaming, as it does in many other internet-enabled industries," Helfstein wrote. He said that the ability to drive up engagement using machine-learning algorithms is "overestimated, and will diminish over time." Helfstein also doubts that the company will be able to improve its gross margins much through renegotiating deals with the record labels. Spotify's stock is up 15% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.8%.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% unveiled rewards that Prime Members can enjoy on Prime Day 2018, which kicks off July 16 at 3 p.m. ET. From July 11 through July 17, Prime members can get $10 on Amazon for Prime Day when they shop at Whole Foods. Amazon Prime Rewards Visa card members will enjoy double rewards, in the form of 10% back on up to a total of $400 in purchases at Whole Foods. Prime members will also have access to exclusive offers on certain foodstuffs. Amazon shares were slightly higher premarket and have gained 48.7% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.1%.

U.S. stocks closed higher Friday to finish the week on an upbeat note on the back of a better-than-expected jobs report. The U.S. created 213,000 new jobs in June, more than the 200,000 that had been forecast, an indication that the U.S. economy remains on its expansionary path. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% gained 99 points, or 0.4%, to 24,456 for a weekly advance of 0.8%. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 23 points, or 0.8%, to 2,759 to close up 1.5% higher on the week while the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% added 101 points, or 1.3%, to 7,688 for weekly gain of 2.4%.

Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% is in talks for a reality show about soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo, according to a report in Variety Thursday. The project could be worth about $10 million to Ronaldo, and would appear in Facebook's Watch, the social network's platform for video content, the report said. Ronaldo already does business with Facebook in the form of a scripted drama series about a diverse high school girls soccer team in upstate New York, according to Variety. Facebook stock is flat after hours, and closed up 3% to $198.45. Facebook shares have climbed 13% this year, as the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has gained 2.4%.

HyreCar Inc.'s stock HYRE, -2.61% surged 15% in midday trade, extending gains after opening 11% above the initial public offering price. The stock's first trade was at $5.55 at 12:00 p.m. ET, on 77,533 shares. The stock traded as high as $6.50 earlier in the session. The peer-to-peer car-sharing company's IPO priced at $5 late Tuesday, at the low end of the expected range of $5 to $6. The company sold 2.5 million shares to raise $12.5 million. The company went public at a time that both the Renaissance IPO ETF IPO, -0.65% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% have gained 4.8% over the past three months.

Crude-oil production from seven major U.S. shale plays is expected to see a climb of 141,000 barrels a day in July to 7.339 million barrels a day, according to a report from the Energy Information Administration released Monday. Oil output from the Permian Basin, which covers parts of western Texas and southeastern New Mexico, is expected to see the largest climb among the big shale plays, with an increase of 73,000 barrels a day. The report was released ahead of the settlement for futures prices. July West Texas Intermediate oil cln8 was up 87 cents, or 1.3%, to $65.93 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

U.S. stock benchmarks ended the day lower, after the White House approved new tariffs on Chinese imports, causing trade-war jitters to ripple across markets. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% came off 0.4% and slipped 0.9% on the week, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% closed 0.1% lower and stood unchanged in positive territory on the week. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% fell 0.2% on the day, but jumped 1.3% on the week. In individual stocks, energy producers such as Exxon Mobil Corp XOM, -0.10% fell on the expectation that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries would agree to increase output next week.

Walt Disney Co.'s stock DIS, -1.30% surged 2.6% in morning trade Thursday, to pace the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% gainers. The rally comes after Comcast Corp. CMCSA, -1.16% made $65 billion cash bid for some coveted 21st Century Fox Inc. FOXA, -0.26% assets, which was higher than Disney's $52 billion all stock deal announced in December. Analyst Daniel Ives at GBH Insights said for Disney to compete with Comcast's bid, it would not only have to raise the value of its bid, but also change it to all cash from stock. That would be better for Disney's investors, because a stock deal dilutes shareholder value.

General Electric Co.'s stock GE, -1.31% climbed 0.8% in morning trade, to pace the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% gainers and to put it on track for a fourth-straight gain. That would be the longest win streak for the industrial conglomerate's shares since the five-day stretch ending Jan. 5, 2018. GE shares have gained 3.3% during the current streak. The stock is the biggest percentage gainer of the 16-of-30 Dow stocks that are trading higher. Among the other leaders, shares of Exxon Mobil Corp. XOM, -0.10% tacked on 0.6%, J.P. Morgan Chase advanced 0.6% and Caterpillar Inc. CAT, -1.88% rose 0.5%. The Dow slipped 4 points.

Rockwell Automation Corp. ROK, -0.99% said it will add $300 million to its stock buyback program, to lift its target for repurchases to $1.5 billion for fiscal 2018. Earlier, Rockwell said it would make a $1 billion equity investment in PTC Inc. PTC, +0.64% as part of a strategic partnership. "Our decision to increase our share repurchase target for 2018, together with our strategic investment in PTC announced earlier today, reflects our commitment to value-creating capital allocation," said Rockwell Chief Executive Blake Moret. The stock, which was still inactive in premarket trade, has lost 9.3% year to date, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.9%.

PepsiCo Inc. PEP, -0.73% said Friday that it has reached an agreement to acquire Bare Foods Co., a U.S.-based food company making fruit- and vegetable-based snacks. Details of the transaction were not disclosed. Bare Foods, which does business as Bare Snacks, was founded in 2001 by a family-owned apple farm in Washington state, selling packaged baked apple chips. It has expanded into other fruits and, more recently, vegetables. When the deal closes, Bare Foods will continue to operate independently out of its San Francisco headquarters. PepsiCo shares are down 15% for the past year while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 12.7% for the period.

President Donald Trump said he and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker agreed to work toward "zero tariffs" and "zero subsidies on non-auto industrial goods." At an unscheduled news conference following a joint meeting, Trump also said the EU would buy more U.S. soybeans almost immediately and that he and Juncker would work to resolve tariffs on European steel and aluminum. U.S. stocks DJIA, -0.77% jumped on reports that the U.S. and EU had reached a deal to resolve trade tensions. Trump has threatened to impose tariffs on European autos but said he'll hold off on any retaliation as long as talks are taking place.

Facebook Inc. FB, -1.55% stock hit a record high in early afternoon trading Wednesday, ahead of the company's second-quarter earnings. The stock was up 1.6% to $218.21 at 12:56 p.m. Eastern Time after closing at $214.67 Tuesday. The S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% was up 0.3% Wednesday. Investors appear to continue to shrug off the seemingly daily gaffes Facebook has been confronted with during the quarter. Despite the issues with privacy and security, Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg has said that thus far the company has not seen an impact on the company's top line. The company is set to report earnings after the close.

Shares of KemPharm Inc. KMPH, +4.35% shot up 13% in premarket trade Monday after the specialty pharmaceutical company said a trial of its treatment of ADHD in patients between the ages of 6 and 12 (KP415) met primary and secondary efficacy endpoints. The company expects to develop additional clinical data throughout 2018, which it believes will allow it to submit a new drug application (NDA) for KP415 in the first quarter of 2019. The stock had soared 67% year to date through Friday, while the SPDR S&P Pharmaceuticals ETF XPH, -0.39% had gained 2.1% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had tacked on 3.2%.

U.S. benchmark oil futures finished with a modest loss on Thursday, as traders assessed the news tied to the OPEC summit in Vienna and comments from major oil producers. The joint ministerial monitoring committee comprised of members of OPEC and non-member allies were meeting Thursday to discuss compliance with their output-cut agreement. A decision on whether to raise production is expected within the next couple of days, with OPEC members set to meet Friday and OPEC and non-OPEC members meeting Saturday. July West Texas Intermediate crude cln8 fell 17 cents, or 0.3%, to settle at $65.54 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.64% said Wednesday that Prime Wardrobe will now be available to U.S. Prime customers without an invitation. Prime Wardrobe, which offers discounts when customers order - and keep - multiple eligible items of clothing, shoes or accessories, launched a year ago. Since then, Amazon said, on its blog, that thousands of items were ordered, with women clicking on denim and dresses most and the company's private-label brands, like Lark & Ro, Goodthreads and Daily Ritual, the most requested. Amazon shares are up nearly 75% for the last year while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 13.4% for the period.

Shares of American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc. AXL, -3.16% rose 1.3% in premarket trade Thursday, after the automotive parts maker that it now targets 2018 sales of $7.1 billion to $7.2 billion, up from previous guidance of $7.0 billion. The company affirmed its outlook for U.S. seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales in the range of 16.8 million to 17.0 million light vehicle units, and its adjusted EBITDA (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization) margin target of 17.5% to 18.0% of sales. The stock has run up 16.5% over the past three months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 1%.

scPharmaceuticals Inc. SCPH, +0.22% shares dropped 10.6% in premarket trade on Wednesday after the Food and Drug Administration failed to approve the company's edema treatment. The therapy, Furoscix, was intended for edema, or fluid overload, in heart failure patients. The regulator said more human factors studies, device modifications and possibly a clinical validation study were needed. The company said it plans to address the issues and bring the product to market. scPharmaceuticals shares have dropped 56% over the last three months, compared with a 0.8% rise in the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% and a 1.3% rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77%

WASHINGTON (MarketWatch) - The U.S. created 223,000 new jobs in May, another strong gain that knocked the unemployment rate down to an 18-year low of 3.8%. Economists polled by MarketWatch had expected a gain of 200,000 nonfarm jobs. The average hourly wage paid to American workers rose by 8 cents, or 0.3%, to $26.92. The yearly rate of pay increases rose to 2.7% from 2.6%. Employment gains for April and March were revised up by a combined 15,000, the Labor Department said Friday. The government said 159,000 new jobs were created in April instead of 164,000. March's increase was raised to 155,000 from 135,000.

The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is adding a new Oscars category for popular films, according to a Hollywood Reporter report. In a message to members, the Academy said it would be adding a new category for outstanding achievement in popular film, and said more details would be forthcoming. The Academy also said it would begin limiting the Oscars telecast to three hours. ABC, a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company DIS, -1.30% , will be airing the 91st Oscars telecast in February 2019. Shares of Disney have gained 6.8% so far this year, while the S&P 500SPX, -0.71% has gained 7%.

Delta Air Lines Inc. DAL, -1.14% reported July load factor that increased from a year ago, as traffic demand outpaced a seat supply. The stock slipped 0.2% in premarket trade. Load factor rose to 88.6% from 88.1%, as traffic increased 4% to 22.61 billion revenue passenger miles and capacity gained 3.5% to 25.51 billion available seat miles. Domestic load factor rose to 88.4% from 87.8% while international load factor edged up to 89.0% from 88.6%. The stock has lost 4.3% year to date through Wednesday, while the NYSE Arca Airline Index XAL, -1.22% has shed 10% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 5.2%.

Target Corp. TGT, +0.11% said Friday it will offer special deals all day long on Target.com on July 17, overlapping with Amazon.com Inc.'s AMZN, -0.64% Prime Day. Target said it will have free two-day shipping on orders greater than $35 in value and free shipping and a 5% discount for Target REDcard holders. The retailer plans deals on items including furniture and home items, beauty and personal care, toys, electronics and more. Amazon's Prime Day starts on July 16 and runs through July 17. Shares rose 1.8% in premarket trade and have gained 17.2% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.7%.

U.S. Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross said late Thursday he would sell all his equity holdings, according to a report by Bloomberg News. In a statement, Ross said he has made "inadvertent errors" in completing his stock sales as required by his ethics agreement, Bloomberg reported. He said he'll now sell all his equity holdings to "maintain the public trust," according to Bloomberg. The billionaire investor has been criticized for some of his stock sales while serving in the Trump administration, including shorting stock in a shipping company with Russian government ties and selling Air Lease stock well after he had promised to divest his holdings.

Chicago Fed President Charles Evans, who had been skeptical of the need for higher interest rates, on Wednesday said he now supported more tightening this year. "The economy seems so strong it seems natural that businesses and consumers can live with" slightly higher rates, Evans said, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal. He said whether the Fed raised rates one or two more times this year was not very important in the overall picture. Evans had been in the dovish camp at the Fed, worried about persistent low inflation. In the interview, Evans said inflation now "looks quite good" after its recent rebound.

Caterpillar Inc.'s stock CAT, -1.88% rallied 3.8% in afternoon trade Monday, to put it on track for the biggest gain in nine months, and enough to pace the Dow Jones Industrial Average's DJIA, -0.77% gainers, as investors set aside worries about trade to focus on recent upbeat economic data. The stock's rally comes as the Dow surges 306 points. Caterpillar shares were still the worst Dow performer over the past month, falling 9.6%, as the machinery maker has a lot to lose in an escalating trade war since most of its revenue is from overseas. Meanwhile, the Dow has lost 2.2% over the past month.

U.S. stock-market indexes opened higher on Wednesday, attempting to recoup some of the losses from several days of selling, which was primarily driven by fears over trade issues. The S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% rose 8 points, or 0.3%, to 2,770. The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% advanced 77 points, or 0.3%, to 24,777, rising after six days of declines. The Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% gained 40 points, or 0.5%, to 7,766 at the open. Among the biggest gainers on the S&P 500, Twenty-First Century Fox, Inc FOXA, -0.26% soared nearly 7% after Walt Disney raised its offer to purchase most of the company.

Rent-A-Center Inc. RCII, +0.00% said Monday it has agreed to be taken private by Vintage Capital, a private and public equity firm, in a deal valued at about $1.365 billion. Vintage will pay $15 per share of the company, which operates in the rent-to-own industry. The deal is expected to close by year-end. The $15 price is equal to a premium of 49% over Rent-A-Center's closing price on Oct. 30, 2017, prior to the announcement that its board was evaluating its strategic options. Shares were halted premarket for the news, but have gained 8.4% in 2018, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 3.9%.

Idera Pharmaceuticals Inc.'s stock IDRA, -14.50% plummeted 19% in premarket trade Tuesday, after the biopharmaceutical company said a phase 2 trial of its treatment for dermatomyositis (IMO-8400) failed to meet its primary endpoint. The company, which develops toll-like receptors and RNA therapeutics for patients with rare cancers and diseases, said the primary endpoint was for statistically significant change from baseline versus placebo. The company did not provide a plan for IMO-8400 after the trial's failure. The stock had lost 8.5% year to date through Monday, while the iShares Nasdaq Biotechnology ETF IBB, -0.55% had gained 3.0% and the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had advanced 4.1%.

Ingersoll-Rand PLC IR, -0.27% said Monday it has raised its quarterly dividend by 18%, to 53 cents a share from 45 cents a share. The new dividend will be payable Sept. 28 to shareholders of record on Sept. 7. Based on Friday's stock closing price of $90.69, the new annual dividend rate implies a dividend yield of 2.34%, compared with the implied yield for the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% of 1.90%. Shares of Ingersoll-Rand, which makes building environment control and perishable foods transport systems, were still inactive in premarket trade. They have gained 1.7% year to date, while the S&P 500 has tacked on 3.9%.

Tyson Foods Inc. TSN, +0.80% said late Friday it found a buyer for certain lines of non-meat food businesses after searching more than a year. Tyson said it entered an agreement to sell its Sara Lee frozen bakery and Van's frozen waffle and breakfast cereal business to private-equity firm Kohlberg & Co. for an undisclosed price. In April 2017, Tyson said it was shopping around for a buyer for the brands so it could focus more on core meat brands like Tyson, Jimmy Dean and Hillshire Farm. Tyson shares were unchanged in after hours trading, having closed up 0.9% at $68.09 in Friday's regular session.

Shares of LogMeIn Inc. LOGM, -2.07% are down 22% in premarket trading after the company delivered a disappointing third-quarter forecast. J.P. Morgan analyst Sterling Auty downgraded the stock to neutral from overweight following the earnings report. "The issues in the collaboration segment of the business, the largest portion of revenue at 57%, are causing management to lower the full-year outlook and likely will place the stock in the penalty box as changes will take a couple of quarters to get worked out," he wrote. "LogMeIn's valuation on a cash flow basis appears to be a sizable discount, but investors will likely question the ability to deliver the results in the near-term keeping a lid on shares, especially given management commentary about competition and prices." Auty also discussed competitive pressures, which he said will remain a concern for investors until the company sees improvement in its collaboration business. LogMeIn makes tools that facilitate remote connectivity. Shares were down 6.3% over the past 12 months, as of Thursday's close, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% had gained 15%.

Shares of Ultra Clean Holdings Inc. UCTT, -2.32% were down more than 11% in after-hours trading after the semiconductor manufacturing company missed earnings expectations for the second quarter and delivered a weaker-than-expected third-quarter outlook. Net income for the second quarter was $19 million, or 48 cents per diluted share, compared with $20.2 million, or 59 cents per share, a year earlier. Adjusted EPS fell to 55 cents from 62 cents in the year-ago period. Analysts had been expecting 57 cents, according to FactSet. Revenue rose to $290.2 million from $228 million a year earlier and came in roughly in line with projections for $289 million. For the third quarter, the company expects revenue of $200 million to $220 million and adjusted EPS of 28 cents to 38 cents. Analysts surveyed by FactSet were predicting $246 million in revenue and 42 cents in adjusted EPS. Ultra Clean's forecast comes as Lam Research Corp. LRCX, -3.46%also delivered a weaker-than-expected outlook for its September period. Earlier this week, Ultra Clean said it would acquire Quantum Global Technologies LLC.

Kimberly-Clark Corp. KMB, -1.01% shares fell 2.6% in Tuesday premarket trading after the consumer products company reported second-quarter revenue that missed expectations and issued a profit warning. Kimberly-Clark brands include Kleenex, Huggies diapers, and Cottonelle. Net income totaled $455.0 million, or $1.30 per share, down from $531.0 million, or $1.49 per share, for the same period last year. Adjusted EPS was $1.59. Sales totaled $4.60 billion, edging up from $4.58 billion last year. The FactSet consensus was for EPS of $1.57 and sales of $4.62 billion. The results "reflect a challenging environment, particularly with commodity inflation," said Chief Executive Thomas Falk in a statement. Higher commodity costs were also the reason the company lowered its earnings guidance. Kimberly-Clark now expects EPS of $6.60 to $6.80 versus prior guidance for $6.90 to $7.20. The company expects net sales to be breakeven to up 1% versus the prior assumption for an increase of 2% to 3%. Kimberly-Clark shares have sunk 12.6% for 2018 so far while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% is up 5% for the period.

U.S. stock-index benchmarks on Friday tipped slightly higher as second-quarter earnings unofficially kicked off with some of the nation's biggest banks, led by JPMorgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, -0.67% and Citigroup Inc. C, -2.39% The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA, -0.77% rose 36 points, or 0.2%, at 24,962, the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% edged slightly higher, up less than 0.1%, at 2,797, while the Nasdaq Composite Index COMP, -0.67% barely edged up 0.1% at 7,829. The subdued opening trade comes after JPMorgan Chase & Co. reported second-quarter results that were better than expected, while Citi reported revenue missed analysts estimates for revenue, Wells Fargo & Co. posted results that came in below expectations. For the week, the S&P 500 was on track for a 1.4% advance, the Nasdaq was eyeing a 1.8% weekly rally and the Dow was set for a 1.9% rise for the week. This is set to be the second straight weekly advance for all three, as well as the Dow's best week since early June.

Shares of Wells Fargo & Co. WFC, -0.67% surged 5.7% in midday trade Friday, putting them on track to close at a 3 1/2-month high, after bank said it would raise its dividend 10% and buy up to $24.5 billion in the aftermath of passing the Federal Reserve's stress test. The rally paces all the stocks of financial companies that passed the stress tests. Among the other biggest gainers, shares of Ally Financial Inc. ALLY, -2.85% hiked up 3.9% and CIT Group Inc. CIT, -0.35% climbed 3.3%. Of some of the more active stress-test passer, share of Bank of America Corp. BAC, -1.30% rose 1.2%, of Citigroup Inc. C, -2.39% rallied 2.5% and J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. JPM, -0.98% gained 1.5%. The financial sector was the best performer of the S&P 500's SPX, -0.71% 11 key sectors, with the SPDR Financial Select Sector ETF XLF, -1.17% rising 1.5%, posting a second day of gains after a record-setting 13-straight losses. The ETF is now down 3.3% year to date, while the S&P 500 is up 2.5%.

Shares of Paychex Inc. PAYX, -0.32% were indicated slightly higher in premarket trade Wednesday, after the human resources services company reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that missed expectations but revenue that beat. Net income for the quarter to May 31 rose to $228.5 million, or 63 cents a share, from $195.3 million, or 54 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. Excluding non-recurring items, adjusted earnings per share came to 61 cents, below the FactSet consensus of 62 cents. Revenue rose 9% to $871.1 million, above the FactSet consensus of $868.0 million. Payroll service revenue grew 3% to $452.4 million, just shy of the FactSet consensus of $453.0 million, while human resources revenue jumped 17% to $401.0 million to top expectations of $397.2 million. For fiscal 2019, the company expects adjusted EPS to increase 11% from 2018, while the current FactSet consensus of $2.79 implies 9.4% growth over 2018 adjusted EPS of $2.55. The stock has rallied 15% over the past three months through Tuesday, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 4.2%.

Shares of Lam Research Corp. LRCX, -3.46% are up 1.6% in Tuesday trading after UBS analyst Timothy Arcuri upgraded the stock to buy from neutral. Shares have sold off in the past month amid concerns that Samsung is delaying memory production, and analysts' estimates have come down as well. Arcuri thinks that the stock has "felt the disproportionate brunt" of these delays, which "sets a low bar" for the company going forward. He predicts that Lam could face the biggest impact from the Samsung delays in the September quarter, while the company's positioning seems poised to improve next calendar year. "Even as we expect less favorable memory pricing in [calendar] 2019, we see a big cushion for memory [wafer fab equipment] and it seems flat or up at all major players in '19," Arcuri wrote. "We have preferred KLA-Tencor KLAC, -2.18% since launch, but see now see upside in Lam Research that is too good to ignore." Lam shares are up 17% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 12%.

Tesla Inc. TSLA, +0.86% Chief Executive Elon Musk claimed that an employee attempted to sabotage the car maker in an email sent to employees Sunday night, according to a Monday report. CNBC reported Monday afternoon that employees received an email from Musk just before midnight Sunday that described "a Tesla employee who had conducted quite extensive and damaging sabotage to our operations." According to Musk, the employee changed code for Tesla's manufacturing operating system and sent internal information to third parties. Musk said the investigation would continue. "We need to figure out if he was acting alone or with others at Tesla and if he was working with any outside organizations," Musk said, before saying that short sellers, oil companies and large car manufacturers want "Tesla to die." CNBC earlier reported that Musk sent out an email Monday about a fire at the company's Fremont, Calif., factory. Tesla stock rose 3.5% in Monday trading to close at $370.83; shares have gained 19.1% so far this year, while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.71% has increased 3.8%.

Shares of ad-tech company The Trade Desk Inc. TTD, +37.13% are up 1.1% in premarket trading Thursday after Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Shyam Patil bumped his price target on the stock up to $105, from $81 previously. The new price target makes Patil the most bullish analyst on the stock among those tracked by FactSet. Patil called TTD "the best way to play the TV ad budget shift," more so than better-known names like Netflix Inc. NFLX, -1.00% and Roku Inc. ROKU, +1.27% "TTD continues to scale inventory partnerships and our checks indicate that TTD is oft-times the first choice for content owners when looking to monetize inventory programmatically," he wrote. Patil thinks the company might actually gain share due to the implementation of the GDPR privacy rules in Europe. "We...think the regulation has caused TTD's top competitor, Doubleclick, to make changes which appear to be leading to global share losses to TTD" and others, he wrote. The stock is up 83% over the past 12 months, while the S&P 500 SPX, -0.71% has gained 14%.

Shares of Adient PLC ADNT, -3.47% tumbled 12% toward a 19-month low in morning trade Monday, after the automotive seating company cut its fiscal 2018 outlook and said Chief Executive Bruce McDonald was stepping down, effective immediately. McDonald has led the company since its separation from Johnson Controls International PLC, which was completed in October 2016. Adient said its operating performance is "running behind plan."
